character/races/humans/quadling.title: Quadling
character/races/humans/quadling.content:
Quadling

"The marshes remember. The water remembers. We remember. And one day, Oz will answer for what was done to us."

Overview

The Quadlings are the survivors of genocide. Once the peaceful inhabitants of the southern marshlands, they were systematically displaced, murdered, and culturally destroyed by the Wizard's regime in the name of "progress." The drainage of the Quadling marshes to build ruby mines and agricultural projects killed thousands. Those who survived were scattered, their traditional ways suppressed, their voices silenced.

Quadling culture before the genocide was rich with spiritual traditions, particularly the Domingon practice—a form of mediumship and trance work that connected practitioners with ancestors and the spirits of the marsh. The Quadlings worked with the land rather than against it, living in harmony with the wetlands. Their red-toned skin and dark hair marked them as different, making them easy targets for discrimination.

Today's Quadlings are a people torn between erasure and remembrance. Some have assimilated into Emerald City life, hiding their heritage to avoid persecution. Others maintain communities in the remaining marshes, preserving what traditions they can. Still others have joined the resistance, determined that Oz will never forget what was done to their people. Quadling characters carry immense trauma and resilience in equal measure.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Wisdom score increases by 1, and one other ability score of your choice increases by 1.
Age Quadlings mature at the same rate as other humans and live less than a century, though marsh-born Quadlings sometimes claim extended lifespans.
Size Medium. Quadlings range from 5 to 6 feet tall, often lean and long-limbed.
Speed 30 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and Quadling. Many older Quadlings refuse to speak Common in private.

Marsh Walker

You have lived in difficult terrain your entire life. You ignore difficult terrain created by water, mud, or marsh conditions. Additionally, you can hold your breath for twice as long as normal, and you have advantage on Constitution saving throws made to resist the effects of extreme heat or humidity.

Survivor's Insight

Your people have learned to read danger and deception. You gain proficiency in the Insight skill. If you are already proficient in Insight, you instead gain proficiency in Perception or Survival.

Memory of Suffering

Quadlings carry generational trauma but also generational strength. When you or an ally you can see within 30 feet takes damage that would reduce them to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to grant them temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

Culture

Quadling culture has fractured into several groups, each dealing with genocide differently:

Marsh-Born (Traditional): These Quadlings still live in the remaining wetlands, practicing Domingon traditions, speaking Quadling, and maintaining the old ways. They are deeply spiritual, distrustful of outsiders, and determined to preserve what fragments of their culture survive. They often serve as the heart of Quadling resistance movements.

Displaced/Refugee: Forced from their homes by drainage projects and military violence, these Quadlings live in makeshift communities on the edges of other provinces. They face discrimination, poverty, and constant harassment from authorities. Many work in the worst jobs for the lowest pay, invisible and exploited.

City-Assimilated: Some Quadlings have moved to the Emerald City and other urban centers, adopting non-Quadling names, dress, and customs to avoid persecution. This assimilation is a survival strategy but comes at the cost of cultural identity. Many struggle with guilt and disconnection from their heritage.

Resistance-Aligned: These Quadlings have taken up arms or joined underground movements dedicated to bringing down the system that destroyed their people. Some work with the Animal resistance, others form their own cells. They are often the most militant voices in opposition movements, and many view violence as justified revenge.

The Domingon Tradition

Central to Quadling spirituality is Domingon—a practice of entering trance states to communicate with ancestors, spirits, and the marsh itself. Dominigons (practitioners) use meditation, chanting, and sometimes mild hallucinogens to achieve these states. The practice was heavily suppressed but has seen a quiet resurgence among traditional communities.

Candle, mother of Rain, is perhaps the most famous modern Domingon. Her healing abilities and spiritual insights made her a figure of hope for many Quadlings.

Naming Conventions

Male Names: Red, Reed, Marsh, Cypress, Murk

Female Names: Candle, Ember, Ruby, Quell, Sedge

Family Names: Marshborn, Waterwalker, Redclay, Stillwater, Reedhand

Traditional Quadling names often reference the marsh environment. Assimilated Quadlings sometimes adopt "Ozian-sounding" names to hide their heritage.

Roleplaying a Quadling

Personality Traits:

  • I speak softly, but my words carry the weight of my ancestors.
  • I never waste anything; everything can be reused or repurposed.
  • I'm more comfortable in silence than in conversation.
  • I watch and listen far more than I speak.
  • I carry small objects from home as reminders of who I am.
  • I refuse to apologize for taking up space or existing.

Ideals:

  • Remembrance: The dead deserve to be remembered, and their stories must be told. (Good)
  • Justice: Those who committed atrocities must answer for their crimes. (Lawful)
  • Survival: I will do whatever it takes to ensure my people endure. (Neutral)
  • Revenge: They destroyed us. I will destroy them. (Evil)
  • Healing: We must rebuild what was broken, not perpetuate the cycle of violence. (Good)
  • Tradition: Our ways are sacred and must be preserved at all costs. (Lawful)

Bonds:

  • My grandmother taught me the old songs before she died. I'm the last who knows them.
  • I'm searching for my family, scattered during the displacement.
  • The marsh where I was born is now a ruby mine. One day I'll reclaim it.
  • A friend gave their life to save mine during the genocide. I owe them everything.
  • I carry a vial of marsh water from home. If I lose it, I lose myself.

Flaws:

  • I can't forgive, and I can't forget. Ever.
  • I assume all Emerald City natives are complicit in genocide.
  • I'm so traumatized that loud noises or sudden movements trigger panic.
  • I hoard resources compulsively, fearing scarcity.
  • I push away people who try to help, certain they'll betray me eventually.

Variants

Domingon-Trained Quadling

Replace Survivor's Insight with Trance Walker: You gain proficiency in the Domingon Trance special skill (see Domingon Trance). Additionally, you know the spare the dying cantrip. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this cantrip.

City-Assimilated Quadling

Replace Marsh Walker with Hidden Heritage: You gain proficiency in Deception and advantage on Charisma (Deception) checks made to conceal your Quadling heritage. Additionally, you can read, write, and speak one additional language of your choice.

GM Notes

Quadling characters bring heavy themes to the table—genocide, cultural destruction, systemic oppression, and trauma. Discuss with your players about comfort levels with these themes. Some plot hooks:

  • The party discovers documents detailing the full extent of the Wizard's genocide plans.
  • A Quadling character is recognized by someone from their past (family, community, or perpetrator of violence against them).
  • The party encounters a Quadling community preparing for a major act of resistance or revenge.
  • Ruby mines built on drained marshland are collapsing, threatening workers—many of whom are Quadlings forced into labor.
  • A character must choose between helping their people or maintaining cover/mission objectives.
  • The Domingon practice reveals crucial information through spiritual means.

Quadling NPCs should be complex—not all are noble victims, and not all resistance fighters are heroic. Some collaborate with oppressors, some have internalized racism, some are consumed by vengeance. Show the full humanity of a traumatized people.

Related Entries

  • Quadling Country (Region)
  • Domingon Trance
  • Candle
  • The Quadling Genocide
  • Quadling Marsh Dweller (Background)
  • Quadling Genocide Survivor (Background)
  • Quadling Rubies (Blood-Touched)

character/races/humans/vinkan.title: Vinkan
character/races/humans/vinkan.content:
Vinkan

"The lowlanders think us savages because we refuse their 'civilization.' We think them fools for trading freedom for green glass."

Overview

The Vinkans are the tribal peoples of the Vinkus, the vast western plains and mountains of Oz. Fiercely independent, culturally distinct, and resistant to central authority, the Vinkans have maintained their traditional ways despite centuries of pressure from the Emerald City. The yellow-toned landscape of the Vinkus has shaped a people who value strength, honor, and autonomy above all.

Vinkan culture is not monolithic. Several major tribes—each with distinct traditions, territories, and customs—coexist in complex political relationships. The Arjiki are the most prominent, known for their matrilineal society and warrior traditions. The Scrow are their traditional rivals, with different marriage customs and territorial claims. The Yunamata dwell in the marsh-edges where the Vinkus meets Quadling Country, blending elements of both cultures. Lowlander-touched Vinkans have adopted some aspects of eastern civilization, creating hybrid identities.

Kiamo Ko, the great castle that overlooks the Thousand Year Grasslands, has been a Vinkan stronghold for generations. It became famous (or infamous) as the refuge of Elphaba, the Wicked Witch of the West, who married into the Arjiki royal line through Fiyero. Her time there and the conflicts that followed have made the Vinkus a place of legend and tragedy.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Strength score increases by 1, and one other ability score of your choice increases by 1.
Age Vinkans mature slightly faster than other humans, reaching adulthood at 14-15, and live into their 70s or 80s.
Size Medium. Vinkans range from 5'6" to well over 6 feet tall, with athletic builds.
Speed 30 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and one tribal language (Arjiki, Scrow, or Yunamata)

Grassland Hunter

You have lived your life on the move across vast territories. You ignore difficult terrain in grasslands and hills. Additionally, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Athletics, Perception, or Survival.

Tribal Weapon Training

You have proficiency with the spear, javelin, longbow, and one martial melee weapon of your choice, reflecting your people's warrior traditions.

Vinkus Resilience

Life in the harsh western lands has toughened you. You have advantage on saving throws against extreme weather conditions (heat, cold, wind). Additionally, you can function on one less hour of sleep per night without penalty.

Culture

Vinkan culture varies significantly by tribe:

Arjiki: The most prominent Vinkan tribe, the Arjiki are matrilineal—lineage and inheritance pass through the mother's line. Women hold positions of power, and the chieftess's word is law. Arjiki are known for their horsemanship, elaborate face paint, and warrior traditions. They value honor, direct speech, and physical prowess. Fiyero Tigelaar, consort to Elphaba, was an Arjiki prince.

Scrow: Traditional rivals of the Arjiki, the Scrow follow patrilineal customs and have different territorial claims. Border skirmishes between Arjiki and Scrow have been common for generations, though rarely escalating to full war. The Scrow use bone and leather armor decorated with feathers and practice different spiritual traditions than the Arjiki.

Yunamata: Living at the edge of the marshlands where the Vinkus meets Quadling Country, the Yunamata have absorbed elements of both cultures. They are skilled at navigating both grassland and wetland, and often serve as intermediaries in trade. They are considered "liminal" by both Vinkans and Quadlings—belonging fully to neither.

Mixed/Lowlander-Touched: Some Vinkans have spent time in the eastern provinces, learned to read and write Ozian script, adopted lowlander clothing or customs, or married into non-Vinkan families. They often face suspicion from traditional Vinkans while never being fully accepted by lowlanders. They walk between worlds.

Kiamo Ko and the Witch

The castle of Kiamo Ko has defined Vinkan history in recent generations. When Fiyero brought Elphaba there as his consort, it set off a chain of events that brought war to the Vinkus. The Wizard's forces attacked the castle. Dragons were unleashed. Fiyero himself disappeared, possibly transformed by Elphaba's magic into the famous Scarecrow.

Liir, son of Elphaba (though this was long uncertain), was raised among the Vinkans. His awkward attempts to fit into Arjiki society and his eventual romance with the Quadling woman Candle created another bridge between cultures.

Today, Kiamo Ko's status depends on the campaign era. Is it still held by the Arjikis? Has it fallen into ruin? Do ghosts walk its halls?

Naming Conventions

Arjiki Male Names: Fiyero, Manek, Irji, Nor (though Nor is female)

Arjiki Female Names: Sarima, Nor, Ama, Kiir

Arjiki Family Names: Tigelaar, Grassthorn, Plainwalker, Sunspear

Scrow Names: Harsher consonants—Krek, Skarn, Drak, Grishna

Yunamata Names: Often blend Vinkan and Quadling elements—Reedwalker, Marshwind

Roleplaying a Vinkan

Personality Traits:

  • I say exactly what I mean; deception is dishonorable.
  • I'm most comfortable outdoors under open sky.
  • I solve conflicts through physical contests when possible.
  • I'm intensely loyal to my tribe/clan but suspicious of outsiders.
  • I find lowlander customs confusing and often ridiculous.
  • I carry tokens from home and perform small daily rituals.

Ideals:

  • Honor: A Vinkan's word is their bond; break it and you are nothing. (Lawful)
  • Freedom: No one has the right to tell me how to live. (Chaotic)
  • Strength: The strong protect the weak; that is the natural order. (Good)
  • Tradition: Our ways have sustained us for generations; change is dangerous. (Lawful)
  • Independence: The Vinkus owes nothing to the Emerald City. (Neutral)
  • Might: Power determines who leads and who follows. (Evil)

Bonds:

  • My tribe raised me; I would die for any of them.
  • I seek to restore honor to my family name after a disgrace.
  • Kiamo Ko holds secrets my bloodline needs to reclaim.
  • I was raised by Elphaba's household; her memory shapes me.
  • A rival tribe killed my [family member]; I seek justice.

Flaws:

  • I respond to insults with violence, even when it's unwise.
  • I'm arrogant about Vinkan superiority and dismissive of other cultures.
  • I can't read or write, and I'm too proud to admit it bothers me.
  • I hold grudges against rival tribes even when alliance is necessary.
  • I'm haunted by the wars that came to the Vinkus because of the Witch.

Variants

Arjiki Vinkan

If your character is specifically Arjiki, replace Tribal Weapon Training with Arjiki Warrior Training: You gain proficiency in all martial weapons and one artisan's tools of your choice (often related to leather-working, bone-carving, or weapon-smithing).

Scrow Vinkan

If your character is Scrow, replace Grassland Hunter with Scrow Raider: You gain proficiency in Stealth and Intimidation. Additionally, when you move through grasslands, you can attempt to hide even when only lightly obscured by natural phenomena.

Yunamata Vinkan

If your character is Yunamata, replace Vinkus Resilience with Between Worlds: You gain proficiency in one skill from the Quadling racial traits and one from the Vinkan racial traits. You can also speak both Quadling and a Vinkan tribal language.

GM Notes

Vinkan characters bring themes of cultural identity, colonialism vs. independence, and the clash between tradition and change. Consider these hooks:

  • The party must navigate complex tribal politics to gain passage or alliance.
  • Kiamo Ko holds something the party needs—but at what cost?
  • A Vinkan character faces a choice between lowlander alliance and tribal loyalty.
  • The ghosts of the dragon wars resurface literally or metaphorically.
  • Inter-tribal conflict threatens to explode into war; the party can mediate or take advantage.
  • Elphaba's legacy in the Vinkus creates complications (sympathizers, enemies, cults).

Not all Vinkans are noble savages or backwards warriors. Show the sophistication of their culture, the wisdom in their traditions, and the complexity of their political structures. Also show how colonialism and war have damaged them.

Related Entries

  • The Vinkus (Region)
  • Kiamo Ko
  • Fiyero Tigelaar
  • Sarima
  • Liir
  • Arjiki Royal Connection (Background)
  • Vinkus Tribal Exile (Background)
  • Kiamo Ko Retainer (Background)

character/races/humans/emerald-city-nati.title: Emerald City Native
character/races/humans/emerald-city-nati.content:
Emerald City Native

"We wear the green spectacles because it's law. Some of us have worn them so long we've forgotten what we're not supposed to see."

Overview

To be born in the Emerald City is to be born at the center of power—and at the heart of corruption. The gleaming capital of Oz, where green dominates every surface (or appears to, through mandatory spectacles), is home to a complex urban society ranging from palace courtiers to slum-dwellers. Emerald City natives navigate a world of political intrigue, social stratification, and pervasive surveillance where every conversation might be reported and every friendship might be performative.

The City's magic is subtle but pervasive. The green illusion created by the spectacles affects perception in ways both obvious and hidden. Those born there often develop an instinct for reading between lines, detecting lies, and presenting carefully curated versions of themselves. They are cosmopolitan, educated, and deeply complicit in the machinery of empire—whether they acknowledge it or not.

Emerald City society is rigidly stratified. Palace-adjacent families enjoy wealth, influence, and access. Merchants occupy a prosperous but precarious middle ground. Slum-born citizens struggle in the outer rings, where the green gleam fades and the reality of poverty shows through the cracks.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Charisma score increases by 1, and one other ability score of your choice increases by 1.
Age Emerald City natives mature at the same rate as other humans and live into their 80s or 90s, with palace families sometimes living longer due to access to magical healthcare.
Size Medium. Emerald City natives range from 5 to 6 feet tall.
Speed 30 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and one of your choice (reflecting the cosmopolitan nature of the City)

City Wisdom

You've learned to navigate complex social and political situations. You gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Deception, Insight, Persuasion, or Investigation. Additionally, you can read, write, and speak one additional language of your choice.

Green-Blind (or Green-Sighted)

Choose one of the following traits:

Green-Blind: You've worn the spectacles your whole life and see the City as it's meant to be seen. You have advantage on saving throws against illusions but disadvantage on Investigation checks to see through the City's specific deceptions.

Green-Sighted: You've learned to see past the illusion. You have advantage on Investigation checks to detect the City's deceptions and can sometimes glimpse the truth, but you suffer from mild paranoia—disadvantage on saving throws against being frightened in urban environments.

Urban Navigator

You know the rhythms of city life. You always know the quickest route through urban terrain, can blend into crowds with ease (advantage on Stealth checks in cities), and can usually find a contact who can provide information or services (at the DM's discretion).

Culture

Palace-Adjacent: These families have wealth, titles, and power. They attend palace functions, influence policy, and marry strategically. They speak in coded language, dress in the latest fashions, and navigate intrigue like breathing. Many genuinely believe in the system; others are trapped by privilege they can't imagine abandoning.

Merchant Class: The City's economic engine, these families run shops, trade networks, and craft guilds. They're shrewd, pragmatic, and often more aware of the City's darker realities than the palace crowd. Some collaborate with underground movements, others profit from exploitation. They walk a careful line.

Slum-Born: In the outer rings, the green fades and harsh reality shows through. Poverty, crime, and desperation dominate. Many slum-dwellers are refugees from other provinces, former Animals, or descendants of those displaced by imperial projects. They survive through solidarity, street smarts, and sometimes crime. The resistance draws heavily from these communities.

The Green Illusion

Mandatory green-tinted spectacles create a collective hallucination—or do they? Some say the City is genuinely green. Others claim it's all grey stone and deception. The truth may lie somewhere in between. The spectacles definitely affect perception, creating a shared reality that reinforces conformity and makes questioning dangerous.

Removing the spectacles in public is illegal and socially transgressive. Those who do often see things others miss—but are branded as deviants, troublemakers, or worse.

Naming Conventions

Palace-Adjacent Names: Elegant, often with historical or literary references—Alabaster, Chrysophrase, Malachite, Verdancy

Merchant Names: Practical but aspirational—Sterling, Merit, Prosper, Grace

Slum Names: Often nicknames or references to circumstances—Lucky, Rat, Copper, Ash, Hope

Family Names: Palace families have long, prestigious names (Thropp, Chuffrey, Margreave). Merchant families have trade names (Goldsmith, Weaver). Slum families often lack formal surnames or adopt found names.

Roleplaying an Emerald City Native

Personality Traits:

  • I instinctively assess everyone I meet for their social status and connections.
  • I keep my real opinions hidden behind pleasantries and ambiguity.
  • I'm uncomfortable in natural settings; cities feel safe.
  • I collect information compulsively—you never know what might be useful.
  • I maintain multiple social personas depending on the situation.
  • I notice details others miss, especially inconsistencies and lies.

Ideals:

  • Order: The system works because everyone knows their place. (Lawful)
  • Truth: The lies must end, even if it costs everything. (Good)
  • Survival: I'll play whatever role keeps me alive and comfortable. (Neutral)
  • Ambition: I'll climb to the top no matter who I step on. (Evil)
  • Revolution: Burn the palace and build something new. (Chaotic)
  • Elegance: Beauty, wit, and style matter more than anything. (Any)

Bonds:

  • My family's reputation is everything; I'll protect it at any cost.
  • I know a secret that could topple the government—and it terrifies me.
  • Someone I love is in the resistance; I pretend not to know.
  • The slums raised me; I owe everything to that community.
  • I witnessed something in the palace I can never unsee or speak of.

Flaws:

  • I'm so used to lying that I sometimes forget what's true.
  • I'm addicted to luxury and can't bear discomfort.
  • I sell information to the highest bidder without considering consequences.
  • I'm paralyzed by fear of losing my social position.
  • I've internalized the City's prejudices and look down on "provincials."

Variants

Palace-Born

Replace Urban Navigator with Noble Bearing: You gain proficiency in Performance or Persuasion (choose one). Additionally, you can leverage your family name for advantage on Charisma checks when dealing with officials or nobility, but you also attract more scrutiny.

Southstairs Survivor

Some are born in the City's secret prison beneath the palace. Replace Green-Blind/Green-Sighted with Darkness Born: You have darkvision out to 60 feet, advantage on saving throws against fear, and proficiency in Stealth—but you have disadvantage on Charisma checks with anyone who learns about your origin.

GM Notes

Emerald City natives work well as faces, spies, or conflicted insiders. Plot hooks include:

  • A character must choose between family and conscience.
  • Information the character learned in the City becomes crucial.
  • The character is recognized by someone from their past (positive or negative).
  • The character's family is implicated in crimes against Animals or Quadlings.
  • The green spectacles malfunction, revealing uncomfortable truths.
  • A character must navigate palace politics or slum underworld contacts.

Related Entries

  • Political Navigation
  • Green Sight

  • Emerald City Urchin (Background)

character/races/humans/outlander.title: Outlander
character/races/humans/outlander.content:
Outlander

"They ask where I'm from as if Oz is the only world that matters. I've seen things beyond their Desert that would shatter their small certainties."

Overview

The Deadly Desert surrounds Oz on all sides, turning living flesh to sand and making passage nearly impossible. Yet some have crossed it—the Wizard in his balloon, Dorothy in her whirlwind-carried house, and others through means mysterious or magical. Those who come from beyond are Outlanders, and they bring with them perspectives, technologies, and ideas utterly foreign to Oz.

Outlanders are rare, strange, and often regarded with suspicion. They don't fit into Oz's rigid social categories. Their accents are different, their customs peculiar, their assumptions about how the world works fundamentally alien. Some adapt and assimilate; others remain forever apart. All carry the weight of displacement—they can never truly go home, and they can never fully belong.

The known lands beyond the Desert include Ev (with its Nome King and mechanical underground), Ix (a land of shamanic traditions and spirit worship), Quox (associated with dragons and fire), and the mysterious place called Kansas, from which both the Wizard and Dorothy originated. Each land has its own cultures, magic systems, and relationships to Oz.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase One ability score of your choice increases by 2, and another increases by 1, reflecting the diverse origins of Outlanders.
Age Varies by origin, but generally similar to other humans (maturity around 18, lifespan 70-90 years).
Size Medium. Outlanders vary greatly in height and build depending on origin.
Speed 30 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and one language from your homeland (Evian, Ixian, Quoxian, or other)

Outsider's Perspective

You see Oz with fresh eyes, noticing what natives overlook. You have advantage on Intelligence (Investigation) checks to spot contradictions, illusions, or cultural assumptions that don't make logical sense. Additionally, you're immune to being charmed by effects that rely on shared cultural context or patriotic sentiment specific to Oz.

Adaptable Survivor

Crossing the Deadly Desert or surviving displacement has made you resourceful. You gain proficiency in two of the following skills: Insight, Investigation, Perception, Survival. Additionally, when you finish a long rest, you can replace one of your skill proficiencies with another from this list, representing your ability to quickly adapt to new situations.

Foreign Knowledge

You possess knowledge from beyond Oz. Choose one:

  • Technological Understanding: You gain proficiency with tinker's tools and advantage on Intelligence checks to understand or repair mechanical devices (especially useful for Tiktoks).
  • Alternative Magic: You know one cantrip from any spell list, representing a different magical tradition. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for it (your choice).
  • Cultural Wealth: You start with twice the normal starting gold and have contacts in your homeland who can occasionally send resources (DM's discretion).
  • Spirit Sight: You can cast detect magic once per long rest without expending a spell slot, as you learned spirit-sensing techniques in your homeland.

Culture by Origin

Evian: From the underground kingdom ruled by the Nome King, Evians are familiar with subterranean life, mechanical constructs, and rigid hierarchies. They tend toward pragmatism and have complicated relationships with surface life. Many have darker skin tones and are shorter than average Ozians.

Ixian: From a land of shamans and spirit worship, Ixians bring mystical knowledge foreign to Oz's magic traditions. They often seem otherworldly to Ozians, with different concepts of time, souls, and reality. They tend toward tall, slender builds and often have intricate tattoos representing spiritual journeys.

Quoxian: From a volcanic land associated with dragons, Quoxians are comfortable with heat, fire, and danger. They're often seen as reckless or passionate by Ozian standards. Many have tanned or reddish-brown skin and dramatic features.

Kansan (or Unknown): From a place called Kansas or other unknown lands beyond, these Outlanders are perhaps the strangest. They come from places without magic, without talking Animals, without color-coded provinces. Everything about Oz astonishes them, and their questions reveal uncomfortable truths. They tend to be from rural, agricultural backgrounds and are often bewildered by Oz's political complexities.

The Question of Return

Most Outlanders cannot return home. The Wizard failed to go back in his balloon. Dorothy left but kept returning, suggesting the Deadly Desert doesn't block her specifically—or that she has access to magic (the Silver Shoes, the Ruby Slippers) that transcends normal rules. For most Outlanders, Oz is exile, permanent and absolute. This colors everything.

Naming Conventions

Names vary dramatically by origin:

Evian Names: Often earthy or gem-related—Granite, Copper, Jade, Obsidian, Ruggedo

Ixian Names: Flowing and mystical—Seraphina, Zephyr, Luminara, Cascade

Quoxian Names: Sharp and dramatic—Blaze, Scorch, Cinder, Pyra, Ignatius

Kansan Names: Simple and familiar (to our world)—Dorothy, Oscar (the Wizard), Henry, Em, regular American names

Roleplaying an Outlander

Personality Traits:

  • I ask "why" about everything, much to locals' annoyance.
  • I compare everything to "how we did it back home."
  • I'm fascinated by aspects of Oz that natives find mundane.
  • I feel like I'm always performing, never quite belonging.
  • I hoard reminders of home—objects, stories, recipes.
  • I unconsciously use phrases or gestures from my homeland that confuse Ozians.

Ideals:

  • Truth: Outsiders see clearly; I'll speak truths locals can't. (Good)
  • Innovation: I'll bring the best of both worlds together. (Good)
  • Superiority: My homeland's ways are obviously better. (Lawful)
  • Exploitation: I'll use my unique knowledge for personal gain. (Evil)
  • Belonging: I'll do whatever it takes to fit in here. (Neutral)
  • Return: I exist only to find a way home. (Any)

Bonds:

  • I left family/friends behind; I think of them constantly.
  • Someone in Oz helped me when I first arrived; I owe them everything.
  • I'm the last keeper of knowledge from my homeland; if I die, it dies.
  • I was sent here on purpose with a specific mission.
  • I found love in Oz; now I'm torn between two worlds.

Flaws:

  • I'm insufferably condescending about how "primitive" Oz is.
  • I'm paralyzed by homesickness and depression.
  • I trust no one because I've been othered and betrayed.
  • I appropriate Ozian culture clumsily, causing offense.
  • I'm so desperate to belong that I'll compromise any principle.

Variants

Wizard's Kin (Kansan)

If you're from Kansas or a similar non-magical world, replace Foreign Knowledge with Technological Prodigy: You gain proficiency in two types of artisan's tools and advantage on Intelligence checks related to mechanical devices, chemistry, or "mundane" sciences unknown in Oz.

Nome-Touched (Evian)

If you're from Ev or have connections to the underground kingdom, replace Adaptable Survivor with Subterranean Affinity: You have darkvision out to 60 feet, advantage on saving throws against being frightened while underground, and you can communicate simple ideas with constructs (like Tiktoks) even if they can't normally speak.

GM Notes

Outlander characters are fish-out-of-water protagonists who can ask questions the DM wants explored. They're great for:

  • Highlighting the strangeness of Ozian society to the audience.
  • Bringing outside knowledge that solves problems in unexpected ways.
  • Creating connections to lands beyond for expansion possibilities.
  • Exploring themes of immigration, displacement, and belonging.
  • Being the only one who questions "that's just how things are."

Be thoughtful about the "chosen one from outside" trope. Dorothy is special partly because she's an outsider, but that can become problematic if it implies Ozians can't solve their own problems.

Related Entries

  • The Deadly Desert
  • The Wizard of Oz
  • Dorothy Gale
  • Ev (Foreign Land)
  • Ix (Foreign Land)
  • Quox (Foreign Land)
  • Kansas (Foreign Land)

character/races/animals/overview.title: Animals (Sentient)
character/races/animals/overview.content:
Animals (Sentient)

"We are Animals, not animals. The difference is a soul, a voice, and the capacity to be murdered rather than merely slaughtered." — Dr. Dillamond

Overview

In Oz, some creatures are Animals (capital-A) — fully sentient, speaking beings with souls, cultures, and rights. Others are animals (lowercase-a) — non-sentient beasts. The line between them is one of the most contested and dangerous questions in Ozian society. Animals have been systematically persecuted, stripped of rights, and in many cases forcibly Silenced — their ability to speak magically removed, reducing them to the status of mere animals.

The persecution of Animals is central to the political horror of Oz. It began subtly under the Wizard's regime and intensified over time. Shiz University, once home to Animal professors like the goat Dr. Dillamond, banned Animal faculty. The Conference of the Birds was infiltrated and destroyed. Animals were required to register with the Gale Force, then stripped of citizenship, then hunted.

Playing an Animal character means playing someone whose personhood is constantly questioned, whose rights can be revoked at any moment, and who must navigate a society built on their oppression. It also means playing a character with rich cultural traditions, deep community bonds, and the strength that comes from surviving systematic dehumanization.

The Animal Question

What makes an Animal different from an animal? Ozians have debated this for generations:

  • The Soul Theory: Animals have souls granted by Lurline or awakened through unknown means. This is the Lurlinite view.
  • The Denial: Unionist orthodoxy claims Animals don't have souls and thus aren't truly people. This justifies persecution.
  • The Reform Position: Some Unionists argue Animals do have souls and deserve rights, creating internal church conflict.
  • The Scientific Mystery: Scholars like Dr. Dillamond sought biological explanations but were silenced before finding answers.
  • The Spontaneous Awakening: Some believe animals can spontaneously become Animals under certain conditions, though this is unproven.

Playing an Animal: General Considerations

All Animal characters share certain realities regardless of species:

Social Persecution

You face discrimination ranging from social slights to active violence. In some eras and regions, being an Animal is a death sentence. You must choose how your character responds: resistance, hiding, collaboration, or simple survival.

Registration and Documentation

In many periods, Animals must register with authorities, wear identifying markers, or carry papers. Failure to do so can result in arrest, Silencing, or worse. Some Animals refuse on principle; others comply to survive; still others use forged papers.

The Question of Eating Meat

If lions and bears are people, what do they eat? This creates moral complexity. Some Animals are vegetarian by choice or necessity. Others eat animals (lowercase) and live with the guilt or justify it as natural. Some radical Animals refuse to eat any creature, sentient or not. This often creates tension between predator and prey Animals.

Animal Culture vs. Animal Nature

Animal characters balance cultural identity (Lion society, Bear scholarship traditions, etc.) with their physical nature (carnivore instincts, flight capabilities, etc.). This tension between civilization and nature is ever-present.

Community and Solidarity

Animals often band together across species lines. The Conference of the Birds united different bird species. The Animal Resistance includes mammals, birds, and others. Shared oppression creates bonds that transcend natural divisions.

Mechanical Notes

Animal player characters use modified racial traits that account for both their animal nature and their sentient status:

  • Size Variation: Animals range from Small (many birds, young bears) to Large (elephants, adult bears). Large PCs should discuss with DM.
  • Natural Weapons: Many Animals have claws, beaks, or other natural weapons, but using them can be seen as "savage."
  • Movement Types: Flying Animals have special movement rules. Swimming Animals have aquatic advantages.
  • Speech and Silencing: The constant threat of being Silenced (forcibly stripped of speech) hangs over all Animals.
  • Tools and Equipment: Animals may struggle with equipment designed for human hands, requiring adaptive tools or magic.

Types of Animals

The following pages detail specific Animal types:

  • Mammals — Bears, Lions, Wolves, Tigers, Elephants, and more
  • Birds — Eagles, Crows, Owls, Songbirds, and the Conference tradition
  • Reptiles & Amphibians — The less common Animal types
  • The Question of Fish — Are fish Animals? The debate continues
  • Hybrid & Uncertain Status — Kalidahs, magical creations, and edge cases

Historical Context

The Golden Age (Pre-Wizard)

Before the Wizard, Animals lived relatively freely. They held positions of authority, taught at universities, and participated fully in society. This wasn't utopia — prejudice existed — but Animals had legal rights and social standing.

The Wizard's Suppression

The Wizard began subtle campaigns against Animals: propaganda suggesting they were dangerous, policies limiting their roles, encouragement of discrimination. By the end of his reign, Animals were being actively hunted. Dr. Dillamond's murder at Shiz marked a turning point.

The Conference of the Birds

A political organization of Animal birds that advocated for Animal rights and coordinated resistance. It was infiltrated by government agents and destroyed, with many members killed or Silenced. Its destruction scattered the Animal resistance and created lasting trauma.

Current Era (Variable by Campaign)

Depending on when your campaign is set, Animals may be in hiding, fighting active resistance, slowly regaining rights, or still facing genocide. The GM determines the current state of Animal persecution.

Passing as animal

Some Animals choose to "pass" as non-sentient animals to avoid persecution. They don't speak in public, pretend to be pets or working animals, and hide their intelligence. This is survival but comes at a terrible psychological cost. See the Animal Passing as animal (Background) for mechanics.

The Underground Railroad

The Animal Underground Railroad is a network dedicated to smuggling Animals to safety, usually to Quadling Country or the Vinkus where central authority is weaker. It's dangerous, secretive, and essential. Many Animal PCs have connections to it.

GM Guidance

Animal persecution is an allegory for real-world oppression. Handle it with care:

  • Session Zero: Discuss comfort levels with themes of genocide, dehumanization, and systematic oppression.
  • Lines and Veils: Establish what can be depicted on-screen vs. implied off-screen.
  • Agency: Animal PCs should have meaningful choices, not just suffer helplessly.
  • Complexity: Not all humans are oppressors; not all Animals are noble. Show the full range.
  • Hope: Even in darkness, resistance, community, and small victories matter.

Related Entries

  • Dr. Dillamond

character/races/animals/mammals.title: Mammals (Animal)
character/races/animals/mammals.content:
Mammals (Animal)

"I am not a thing to be caged. I am not a beast to be tamed. I am Brrr, and I have a soul." — The Cowardly Lion

Overview

Mammalian Animals are perhaps the most visible and most persecuted in Oz. Brrr the Lion, Princess Nastoya the Elephant, and countless unnamed Bears, Wolves, Tigers, and others have shaped Ozian history. They are scholars, warriors, leaders, and victims. Their size, strength, and predatory nature make them particularly threatening to human supremacists, leading to targeted violence and suppression.

Each mammalian species has developed distinct cultures and traditions. Bears are known for scholarship and record-keeping. Lions navigate complex social hierarchies and the weight of being symbols (the "cowardly lion" legend haunts Brrr throughout his life). Elephants maintain matriarchal societies and long memories. Wolves form tight pack structures that emphasize loyalty. Each species brings unique perspectives and challenges.

Racial Traits (Mammals - General)

All mammalian Animals share certain baseline traits, modified by specific species:

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Varies by species (see below)
Age Mammalian Animals live roughly as long as their animal counterparts would naturally—Bears and Elephants may reach 50-60 years, Lions and Wolves 20-30, smaller mammals less. However, sentience seems to extend natural lifespans somewhat.
Size Varies by species and age. Most are Medium, but some (like Elephants or adult Bears) are Large. Discuss Large PCs with your DM.
Speed Varies by species, typically 30-40 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and one species language (Leonine, Ursine, Lupine, etc.)

Animal Senses

You have proficiency in the Perception skill. Additionally, you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell or hearing. Your keen senses mark you as an Animal, making it harder to pass as human.

Natural Weapons

You have claws, fangs, or other natural weapons. You can make unarmed strikes dealing 1d6 + your Strength modifier slashing or piercing damage (your choice). However, using your natural weapons in "civilized" settings marks you as savage and may trigger hostile reactions. Many Animals refuse to use them except in dire circumstances.

Thick Hide or Fur

When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 12 + your Dexterity modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

Target of Persecution

You are subject to Gale Force registration laws, social discrimination, and potential violence. You have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks when dealing with openly anti-Animal NPCs. However, you have advantage on Charisma checks when interacting with the Animal Resistance or sympathetic communities.

Species Variants

Bear (Ursine)

Bears are known for their scholarly traditions. Shiz University once had multiple Bear professors before the purges. Bears value knowledge, record-keeping, and thoughtful analysis. They're often larger and slower than other Animals but possess great strength and wisdom.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (young) or Large (adult, DM's discretion)

Speed: 30 feet (your size and build make you less agile)

Scholar's Tradition: You gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Arcana, History, Nature, or Religion. Additionally, when you make an Intelligence check related to recalling lore or information you've read, you can add double your proficiency bonus.

Powerful Build: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

Hibernation Knowledge: You require only 4 hours of sleep during a long rest instead of 6 (though you still need 8 hours for a full rest). During winter months, you feel a strong urge to sleep more.

Roleplay Notes: Bear characters often struggle between their intellectual pursuits and society's view of them as dangerous beasts. Many were or knew professors who were purged from Shiz. The loss of scholarly community weighs heavily.

Lion (Leonine)

Brrr, the famous "Cowardly" Lion, has shaped how Ozians view all Lions—often unfairly. Lions navigate complex social hierarchies, both within their own prides and in broader Ozian society. They're seen as symbols: courage, nobility, ferocity, or (thanks to Brrr's legend) cowardice. This symbolic weight is a burden.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Charisma score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (females, young males) or Large (adult males, DM's discretion)

Speed: 35 feet

Regal Presence: Despite persecution, Lions carry themselves with dignity. You have proficiency in the Intimidation or Persuasion skill (your choice). Additionally, when you make a Charisma check to assert authority or demand respect, you can add your Strength modifier instead of Charisma (minimum +0).

Pride Tactics: When an ally within 30 feet of you is hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to move up to half your speed toward the attacker. If you end this movement within 5 feet of the attacker, you have advantage on your next attack roll against them before the end of your next turn.

Hunter's Instinct: You have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track creatures and on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to stalk prey.

Roleplay Notes: Lion characters often grapple with the Brrr legend and expectations of nobility or courage. Some embrace the reputation; others are crushed by it. See Brrr's story for the complexity of Lion identity in Oz.

Wolf (Lupine)

Wolves emphasize pack, loyalty, and collective survival. They work together instinctively, communicate through body language and subtle signals, and prioritize the group over the individual. In the Animal Resistance, Wolves often serve as coordinators and tacticians.

Ability Score Increase: Your Dexterity score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Medium

Speed: 40 feet

Pack Tactics: You have advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated. This represents your instinctive coordination with allies.

Keen Tracker: You have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track creatures and can track at a fast pace without penalty.

Howl of the Pack: As an action, you can howl to signal allies within 1 mile. Allies who hear it know your general direction and emotional state. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. (Note: Howling may attract unwanted attention in hostile territory.)

Roleplay Notes: Wolf characters struggle when separated from pack/community. They thrive in groups and suffer alone. Many feel torn between Animal pack bonds and the diverse alliances of the resistance.

Tiger (Feline)

Tigers are solitary, fierce, and rare. Ivory Tigers, mentioned in the novels, are particularly exotic and endangered. Tigers are often stereotyped as dangerous and unpredictable, making them prime targets for Silencing or elimination.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

Size: Medium or Large (DM's discretion)

Speed: 35 feet

Solitary Hunter: You have advantage on attack rolls when you're the only ally within 30 feet of the target. You're most effective when working alone.

Ambush Predator: You have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in natural terrain (forests, grasslands, jungles). Additionally, during the first round of combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that haven't taken a turn yet.

Pounce: If you move at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hit it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be knocked prone. If the target is prone, you can make one additional claw attack against it as a bonus action.

Roleplay Notes: Tiger characters are often loners by nature but may join groups out of necessity. They face intense prejudice and are frequently hunted. Ivory Tigers may be nearly extinct, making survivors precious and endangered.

Elephant (Proboscidean)

Princess Nastoya, matriarch of her people, led the Elephants through exile and trauma. Elephants maintain long memories, matriarchal traditions, and deep wisdom. They're among the largest Animals, making them impossible to ignore and easy to target.

Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Large (Elephants cannot be Medium; discuss with your DM about playing a Large PC)

Speed: 30 feet

Matriarch's Memory: Elephants never forget. You have advantage on Intelligence checks to recall information you've personally encountered. Additionally, you can perfectly recall any conversation or event you experienced within the past year.

Trunk Dexterity: Your trunk can manipulate objects, carry up to 30 pounds, and function as a natural "hand" for tasks. You can use your trunk to grapple creatures or manipulate objects while your feet remain planted.

Powerful Build: You count as Huge when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

Thick Hide: Your AC calculation from natural armor becomes 13 + your Dexterity modifier (instead of 12).

Charge: If you move at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hit it with a gore or slam attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 2d8 bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be knocked prone.

Roleplay Notes: Elephant characters carry the weight of Nastoya's legacy and their people's persecution. They remember every injustice, every lost family member, every broken promise. This can be both strength and burden.

Badger, Ape, and Other Mammals

Other mammalian species exist as Animals: Badgers (tenacious diggers), Apes (tool-users and climbers), Foxes (cunning survivors), and more. Work with your DM to create appropriate traits based on the species' natural abilities and cultural role in Oz.

General Guidelines:

  • +2 to one ability, +1 to another based on species strengths
  • One or two species-specific abilities (burrowing, climbing, etc.)
  • Natural weapons appropriate to the species
  • Cultural background related to their role in Animal society

The Burden of Being a Predator

Carnivorous Animals face an additional moral weight: if they eat meat, they may be eating animals (lowercase-a) that could potentially become Animals. Or worse, in dark times, the meat industry may be secretly processing Silenced Animals. Many predatory Animals become vegetarian, suffering malnutrition rather than risk cannibalism. Others eat and don't think too hard about it. Some justify it philosophically. This creates internal conflict and external judgment.

Animal Society and Culture

Before the persecution, Animals had rich cultural traditions:

  • Bears maintained vast libraries and taught at universities
  • Lions held courts and settled disputes through formal combat or debate
  • Wolves organized pack councils with democratic elements
  • Elephants passed down oral histories spanning generations
  • Tigers practiced solitary contemplation and hunting rituals

Much of this has been lost or driven underground. Animals fighting to preserve these traditions risk everything.

GM Notes

Mammalian Animal PCs bring physical power and cultural weight to the party. Consider:

  • Size Challenges: Large Animals may struggle with dungeon doors, city streets, or Witch's Brooms
  • Prejudice: Vary how NPCs react—some hostile, some sympathetic, most fearful
  • Practical Problems: How do Lions open doors? How do Elephants buy clothes? These details matter
  • Cultural Loss: NPCs who remember "the before times" can provide poignant moments
  • Hope and Resistance: Even in darkness, Animal communities support each other

Related Entries

  • Dr. Dillamond
  • The Animal Resistance
  • Animal Underground Railroad

character/races/animals/birds.title: Birds (Animal)
character/races/animals/birds.content:
Birds (Animal)

"We flew where we pleased once. Now even the sky isn't safe." — A surviving Conference member

Overview

Bird Animals occupy a unique position in Oz: they can fly, making them both valuable messengers and difficult to capture. Yet this mobility also made them prime targets when the Gale Force decided to eliminate organized Animal resistance. The Conference of the Birds was the most organized Animal political movement in history—and its destruction remains one of the great traumas of Animal society.

Birds range from tiny songbirds to massive eagles. Some, like Crows, have developed extensive intelligence networks. Others, like Owls, are associated with wisdom, death omens, or both. Eagles are warriors and leaders. Each species brings different capabilities and cultural traditions, but all share the gift and curse of flight.

Before the persecution, Birds served as messengers, scouts, scholars, and diplomats. Now, many hide their sentience, pretending to be mere birds. Others joined the resistance, using their aerial advantage for reconnaissance and communication. Still others were captured, caged, and Silenced—their wings clipped, their voices stolen.

Racial Traits (Birds - General)

All Bird Animals share certain baseline traits, modified by specific species:

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Varies by species (see below)
Age Bird Animals live roughly as long as their species naturally would, though sentience seems to extend lifespans. Crows and Ravens may reach 50+ years, songbirds 10-20, Eagles 30-40.
Size Small (most songbirds, small crows) or Medium (eagles, large owls, ravens). Tiny birds are generally not playable without heavy modification.
Speed 25-30 feet walking, 50-60 feet flying (varies by species)
Languages Common (Ozian), and Avian (with species-specific dialects)

Flight

You have a flying speed listed in your species traits. You can't use this flying speed if you're wearing medium or heavy armor, or if your wings are clipped or bound. If you're knocked prone, fall unconscious, or are otherwise incapacitated while flying, you fall unless you can hover. This ability makes you incredibly valuable—and incredibly targeted.

Wing Clipping: In some eras and regions, authorities clip the wings of captured Bird Animals, permanently removing their ability to fly. This is considered a form of torture and mutilation. A clipped bird can sometimes regain flight through powerful healing magic, but the psychological trauma persists.

Keen Vision

You have proficiency in the Perception skill. Additionally, you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight. You can see details at great distances that others miss.

Hollow Bones

Your bones are light but fragile. You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws to avoid being grappled or restrained, but you have disadvantage on saving throws against effects that would knock you prone or push you.

Talons or Beak

You have a natural weapon—talons or beak. You can make unarmed strikes dealing 1d4 + your Dexterity modifier piercing or slashing damage. Your hands (wing-claws) may be less dexterous than human hands, potentially affecting tool use (DM's discretion).

Conference Legacy

All Bird Animals carry the memory of the Conference, whether they personally remember it or not. You have advantage on Intelligence checks related to Animal history and political movements. Additionally, when you meet other Bird Animals, you can usually establish trust quickly through shared cultural references and grief.

Species Variants

Eagle (Aquiline)

Eagles are warriors, leaders, and symbols of freedom. They're large, powerful, and difficult to keep captive. Many Eagles fought openly during the Animal resistance and paid the price. Those who survive carry battle scars and deep conviction.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Medium

Speed: 30 feet walking, 60 feet flying

Raptor's Dive: If you fly at least 30 feet toward a target and then hit it with a talon attack on the same turn, the attack deals an extra 1d6 damage. If the target is a creature smaller than you, it must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be knocked prone.

Battlefield Commander: You have proficiency in Intimidation. Additionally, when you use the Help action to aid an ally in combat, that ally gains advantage on their next attack roll and adds your Wisdom modifier to the damage if they hit (minimum +1).

Superior Vision: You can see clearly up to 1 mile away as if it were only 100 feet. Additionally, you ignore lightly obscured conditions when relying on sight.

Roleplay Notes: Eagle characters are often military veterans, resistance fighters, or community leaders. They struggle with survivor's guilt and the weight of failed uprisings. Many knew members of the Conference personally.

Crow/Raven (Corvid)

Crows and Ravens are intelligence-gatherers, tricksters, and survivors. They're brilliant, adaptable, and deeply social within their own kind. Corvid intelligence networks survived the purges better than most, making them invaluable to the Animal Resistance.

Ability Score Increase: Your Intelligence score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

Size: Small (Crow) or Medium (Raven, DM's discretion)

Speed: 25 feet walking, 50 feet flying

Mimicry: You can mimic sounds you have heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they're imitations with a successful Wisdom (Insight) check opposed by your Charisma (Deception) check. This ability has saved countless Corvids from capture.

Intelligence Network: You can communicate with other Corvids (sentient or not) within sight. Non-sentient crows will perform simple tasks for you (delivering small objects, watching locations, making noise as distraction). Additionally, you have advantage on Intelligence (Investigation) checks to gather information in cities or settlements where crows are present.

Clever Mind: You gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Arcana, History, Investigation, or Sleight of Hand. Additionally, you can use Intelligence instead of Dexterity for Sleight of Hand checks.

Omen of Death: Whether true or superstition, Corvids are associated with death and ill omens. You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks against superstitious creatures, but disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks with those same creatures.

Roleplay Notes: Corvid characters are often spies, information brokers, or messengers. They know everyone's secrets—which makes them valuable and dangerous. Many operated in the Conference as intelligence coordinators.

Owl (Strigine)

Owls are associated with wisdom, night, and death. They're silent fliers, nocturnal hunters, and often scholars or mystics. Their connection to night and death gives them an air of the uncanny that makes other Ozians uncomfortable.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Intelligence score increases by 1.

Size: Small (most owls) or Medium (great horned owl, eagle owl)

Speed: 25 feet walking, 50 feet flying

Silent Flight: You have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks while flying. Your wings make no sound, allowing you to approach or escape undetected.

Darkvision: You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Nocturnal: You're most active at night. You have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) and Dexterity (Stealth) checks made in darkness or dim light. However, you have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight in bright sunlight.

Scholar's Wisdom: You gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Arcana, Insight, Medicine, or Religion. Additionally, when you make an Intelligence or Wisdom check to recall information or notice hidden details, you can reroll the die once and must use the new roll.

Roleplay Notes: Owl characters are often solitary scholars, mystics, or watchers. They see things others miss—literally and metaphorically. Many feel disconnected from the broader Animal community due to their nocturnal nature and unsettling reputation.

Songbird (Passerine)

Songbirds—thrushes, sparrows, finches, nightingales—are small, vulnerable, and numerous. They were often dismissed as unimportant, which ironically helped some survive. Songbird messengers can fly unnoticed where larger birds would be shot. Their voices carry warnings, songs, and coded messages.

Ability Score Increase: Your Dexterity score increases by 2, and your Charisma score increases by 1.

Size: Small

Speed: 20 feet walking, 50 feet flying

Melodic Voice: You have proficiency in Performance. Additionally, you can use your song to communicate emotions and simple concepts to any creature within hearing range, regardless of language barriers. This isn't magical, but it's remarkably effective.

Unassuming: Your small size and "harmless" appearance work to your advantage. You have advantage on Charisma (Deception) checks to appear innocent or non-threatening. Additionally, you're often underestimated—use it wisely.

Swift Flight: Your flying speed is not reduced when moving through tight spaces that would normally require squeezing (as long as they're large enough for your actual size).

Fragile Frame: Your hit point maximum is reduced by 1 per level (minimum 1 hit point per level). You're more vulnerable than larger Animals, but you compensate with speed and cunning.

Roleplay Notes: Songbird characters are survivors who've learned to use their perceived weakness as strength. They're messengers, spies, and the eyes of the resistance. Many carry messages for the Underground Railroad.

Other Bird Species

Other bird species exist as Animals: Hawks, Falcons, Herons, Woodpeckers, and more. Work with your DM to create appropriate traits based on natural abilities.

The Conference of the Birds

The Conference of the Birds was the pinnacle of Animal political organization. Founded in the early years of persecution, it united bird species in coordinated resistance and advocacy. The Conference held secret meetings, coordinated information networks, lobbied (unsuccessfully) for Animal rights, and planned collective action.

It was infiltrated by government agents, betrayed by collaborators, and violently destroyed. Many Conference members were killed, Silenced, or imprisoned in Southstairs. The destruction scattered bird Animals across Oz and created lasting trauma. Yet the memory persists, and some say the Conference never truly died—it merely went deeper underground.

Bird PCs often have personal or family connections to the Conference. Perhaps a grandparent was a member. Perhaps they survived the purge as a fledgling. The Conference is both inspiration and cautionary tale.

Flight and Freedom

Flight represents freedom—which is why authorities target it. In some regions, flying Animals are shot on sight. In others, they must register their flight patterns with the Gale Force. Some cities ban flying entirely within city limits. The sky should be freedom, but it's become another space of surveillance and danger.

Many bird Animals choose to walk rather than fly in public, hiding their greatest gift to survive. This self-imposed limitation weighs heavily. Imagine having wings and being afraid to use them.

Messenger Traditions

Despite persecution, bird Animals continue serving as messengers—it's both livelihood and calling. The Underground Railroad relies heavily on bird messengers. The Animal Resistance uses them to coordinate across distances. Even Gillikinese nobles employ bird messengers (often treating them as mere animals, which is both offensive and occasionally useful cover).

Messenger birds use coded messages, multiple routes, and careful timing. They know they're targets—one well-placed arrow ends everything. Yet they fly anyway because communication is resistance.

GM Notes

Bird Animal PCs add mobility and vulnerability to the party:

  • Flight is Powerful: Be prepared for creative aerial solutions to problems
  • Flight is Dangerous: Archers, weather, exhaustion, and wing damage are constant threats
  • Size Matters: Small birds face different challenges than Medium birds
  • Conference Survivors: NPCs who remember the Conference are either inspiring or broken
  • Messaging: Bird PCs may be asked to carry messages—some safe, some deadly
  • The Temptation to Hide: It's easier to pretend to be a non-sentient bird; address this temptation

  • The Animal Resistance
  • Animal Underground Railroad

  • Southstairs
