6I freeze when confronted openly.

GM Notes

Use Colwen ties to pull characters into Thropp-adjacent plots: inheritance disputes, old letters, and political fallout. Servant access is powerful in social infiltration adventures.

Related Pages

  • Munchkinland
  • Emperor Shell Reign
  • Free Munchkinland
  • The Agent

character/backgrounds/travelling-player.title: Travelling Player
character/backgrounds/travelling-player.content:
Travelling Player

"We make miracles out of cheap paint and good timing."

Overview

You traveled with a troupe: puppets, music, stories, and the hard work of moving joy from town to town. You learned to read crowds the way farmers read weather.

Traveling players see Oz in fragments: noble houses, dirty inns, hungry villages, and secret audiences. Sometimes the show is just a show. Sometimes it is a message.

Applicable Races

Performers come from everywhere. The road is a country of its own.

  • Outlander: Natural travelers who already live between borders
  • Munchkinlander: Local performers seeking bigger stages
  • Gillikinese: Runaways and romantics from polite society
  • Animals: Rare; those who could still travel openly

Skill Proficiencies

Performance, Acrobatics

Tool Proficiencies

Disguise kit, Musical instrument (choose one)

Languages

One of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A costume trunk piece (mask, hat, or cape)
  • A small instrument or prop
  • A set of greasepaint
  • A letter of recommendation from a troupe leader
  • A pouch containing 12 gp

Feature: Always a Stage

In most settlements, you can earn modest lodging or food by performing, and you can usually find other entertainers who trade rumors and safe travel advice.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I collect accents and steal them.
2I cannot resist an audience.
3I tell the truth as a joke.
4I flirt with danger like a bit.
5I keep my sadness offstage.
6I know how to calm a room.
7I pick up odd skills quickly.
8I leave before goodbyes get heavy.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Joy (Good). People deserve beauty
2Freedom (Chaotic). The road is my home
3Craft (Neutral). A good show is honest work
4Truth (Good). Stories can expose rot
5Reputation (Neutral). Fame is protection
6Manipulation (Evil). A crowd is a tool

Bonds

d6Bond
1My troupe is my family.
2I owe a town that hid us from soldiers.
3A rival troupe wants me ruined.
4I carry a prop that is secretly valuable.
5I promised to tell someone's story.
6I am searching for a lost performer.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I lie for applause.
2I chase novelty even when unsafe.
3I avoid commitment.
4I stir trouble for a better story.
5I take insults personally.
6I cannot turn off the performance.

GM Notes

Great for travel campaigns and social encounters. Use festivals, censorship, and secret messages hidden in shows. Traveling players can stumble into resistance work or Palace patronage.

Related Pages

  • The Performer
  • The Clocks Keepers
  • Emerald City
  • The Traveler

character/backgrounds/black-market-deale.title: Black Market Dealer
character/backgrounds/black-market-deale.content:
Black Market Dealer

"Scarcity is a policy. I just live in it."

Overview

You trade in what the law pretends does not exist: papers, medicine, weapons, banned books, contraband comforts. You learned which officials can be bribed and which only pretend to be.

You are not a hero by default. You might be a lifeline, a parasite, or both, depending on the night.

Applicable Races

Black markets flourish where the Palace tightens its fist; dealers come in many shapes.

  • Emerald City Native: City brokers with contacts everywhere
  • Munchkinlander: Rural smugglers moving goods past checkpoints
  • Outlander: Border traders and fixers
  • The Touched: Those shut out of lawful work

Skill Proficiencies

Deception, Persuasion

Tool Proficiencies

Thieves' tools

Languages

One of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A concealed purse with multiple compartments
  • A small set of scales
  • A list of contacts in code
  • A harmless-looking bundle that is not harmless
  • A pouch containing 15 gp

Feature: I Know a Person

In any sizable settlement, you can usually locate someone willing to sell restricted goods or information - for a price. You also know how to avoid the worst stings and set-ups.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I always know the market price.
2I hate being surprised.
3I never say 'no' without offering an alternative.
4I treat trust like currency.
5I keep receipts in my head.
6I smile when negotiating hard.
7I sleep with one eye open.
8I am oddly generous to the desperate.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Opportunity (Neutral). If it exists, it can be sold
2Aid (Good). Supply the people the state starves
3Freedom (Chaotic). Laws are suggestions
4Order (Lawful). Rules keep business stable
5Pragmatism (Neutral). Morals do not pay rent
6Exploitation (Evil). Desperation is leverage

Bonds

d6Bond
1A supplier is missing; my life depends on them.
2I protect a client who cannot be exposed.
3I owe the Criminal Networks a debt.
4I am being blackmailed by an official.
5I keep one item I refuse to sell.
6I promised to get someone out of Oz.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I cannot stop hustling.
2I take risks for bigger margins.
3I lie even to allies.
4I underestimate moral consequences.
5I hoard power and information.
6I burn bridges when cornered.

GM Notes

Dealers are plot engines: contraband quests, sting operations, rival smugglers, and double-crosses. Use shifting prices and scarce resources to create pressure.

Related Pages

  • Criminal Networks
  • Emerald City
  • The Palace
  • The Agent

character/backgrounds/forger-identity-ma.title: Forger/Identity Maker
character/backgrounds/forger-identity-ma.content:
Forger/Identity Maker

"In Oz, a name can be a life jacket or a noose."

Overview

You make people legible to the state - or invisible. Passes, seals, diplomas, travel documents, love letters with the wrong handwriting. Your craft is precision and nerve.

You know how governments think: what they expect to see on paper, and what makes them suspicious. You have probably saved lives. You have probably ruined a few, too.

Applicable Races

Forgers can be anyone with steady hands, sharp eyes, and low fear of prisons.

  • Emerald City Native: City artisans in ink and fraud
  • Gillikinese: Educated scribes who went rogue
  • Outlander: Border specialists and passport makers
  • Munchkinlander: Small-town document fakers for survival

Skill Proficiencies

Deception, Sleight of Hand

Tool Proficiencies

Calligrapher's supplies, Disguise kit

Languages

One of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A set of inks and fine pens
  • A roll of blank parchment and scraps
  • A few wax seals (real or stolen)
  • A small knife and sand for drying ink
  • A pouch containing 15 gp

Feature: Paper Masks

Given time and reference material, you can create a credible identity or document that fools casual inspection, and you know what questions officials will ask first.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I notice stamps and signatures immediately.
2I practice handwriting for fun.
3I keep my tools obsessively clean.
4I treat people as stories to edit.
5I avoid repeating my own lies.
6I get anxious around real authority.
7I cannot resist improving a document.
8I am proud, and it shows.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Protection (Good). Give the hunted a chance
2Artistry (Neutral). A perfect forgery is beauty
3Freedom (Chaotic). Paper should not define a person
4Order (Lawful). Rules exist; I just bend them
5Profit (Neutral). Everything has a price
6Control (Evil). I decide who becomes 'real'

Bonds

d6Bond
1I owe a client who paid with blood.
2A rival forger wants my method.
3I keep a ledger of fake identities.
4I protect a source inside the Palace.
5My family thinks I am a legitimate scribe.
6I have one identity I cannot abandon.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I take jobs I should refuse.
2I grow reckless when praised.
3I assume I can talk my way out.
4I leave clues because I cannot resist flourish.
5I panic when my work is questioned.
6I get attached to clients.

GM Notes

Forgers support stealth campaigns: fake passes, border crossings, infiltration, and blackmail. Use lost seals, counterfeit crackdowns, and clients with dangerous demands.

Related Pages

  • Criminal Networks
  • The Palace
  • Emerald City
  • The Agent

character/backgrounds/palace-servant.title: Palace Servant
character/backgrounds/palace-servant.content:
Palace Servant

"I carried trays while the fate of Oz changed courses."

Overview

You worked in the Palace: polishing, cooking, laundering, guiding guests, and pretending you were invisible. You learned that power is mostly boredom interrupted by panic.

You know which corridors echo, which doors are watched, and which officials whisper when they think servants are furniture.

Applicable Races

Palace staff are largely human, drawn from the Emerald City and surrounding regions.

  • Emerald City Native: The backbone of Palace labor
  • Munchkinlander: Hired hands and seasonal workers
  • Gillikinese: Specialists and trusted attendants
  • The Touched: Kept close as curiosities or labor

Skill Proficiencies

Insight, Stealth

Tool Proficiencies

Cook's utensils (or Disguise kit)

Languages

None

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A simple uniform piece
  • A ring of service keys (some false)
  • A folded floorplan sketch from memory
  • A small vial of polish or soap
  • A pouch containing 10 gp

Feature: Overheard in the Hall

While in a political or noble setting, you can often learn one useful rumor or schedule detail by watching staff traffic and listening for what slips out between orders.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I speak quietly by default.
2I notice who is tired and who is cruel.
3I keep my feelings hidden at work.
4I can move without making noise.
5I hate waste and showy wealth.
6I collect gossip, then regret it.
7I am loyal to other staff first.
8I freeze when addressed by title.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Discretion (Lawful). Survival is silence
2Justice (Good). Masters should answer for harm
3Security (Neutral). A steady roof matters
4Freedom (Chaotic). No one should be invisible
5Loyalty (Lawful). Protect the Palace; it protects us
6Resentment (Evil). I will sabotage their comfort

Bonds

d6Bond
1A fellow servant is my only family.
2I saw something that could topple an official.
3I keep a stolen trinket as proof I existed.
4I protect a guest I pity.
5I owe my job to a patron.
6I know a secret passage few remember.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I eavesdrop compulsively.
2I lie to avoid punishment.
3I resent authority so much I misjudge allies.
4I freeze under direct confrontation.
5I hoard small luxuries.
6I cannot stop imagining revenge.

GM Notes

Palace servants are ideal for intrigue and infiltration. Use staff politics, secret passageways, and sudden crackdowns. A servant can become the key witness everyone ignores until too late.

Related Pages

  • The Palace
  • Emerald City
  • Emperor Shell Reign
  • The Agent

character/backgrounds/kiamo-ko-retainer.title: Kiamo Ko Retainer
character/backgrounds/kiamo-ko-retainer.content:
Kiamo Ko Retainer

"The castle teaches you to love doors and fear them."

Overview

You served at Kiamo Ko in the Vinkus: a remote stronghold where rumors grew teeth. Your work was practical - repairs, cooking, guarding, negotiating with tribes - but the place was never just a place.

Kiamo Ko has been tied to Elphaba's legend and the west's grudges. You learned what it costs to shelter a symbol when the world wants the symbol dead.

Applicable Races

Most retainers are Vinkan humans, though Kiamo Ko has sheltered many strange guests.

  • Vinkan: The most common servants, guards, and locals
  • Outlander: Travelers who became staff to survive
  • Winged Monkeys: Those bound to the castle's history
  • The Touched: People who found refuge far from cities

Skill Proficiencies

Survival, Insight

Tool Proficiencies

Artisan's tools (choose one)

Languages

One of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A key or token from a Kiamo Ko door
  • A heavy cloak suited to western nights
  • A small toolkit or repair kit
  • A pouch containing 10 gp
  • A keepsake from someone who stayed (or died) there

Feature: Castle Hospitality

In the Vinkus, you can usually find someone who knows Kiamo Ko's reputation and will offer cautious help. You also know how to fortify a shelter quickly and how to live without city supply lines.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I prefer silence to small talk.
2I watch hills for movement.
3I am protective of my home, wherever it is.
4I distrust officials immediately.
5I keep tools close.
6I have a dry sense of humor.
7I am loyal to those who gave me refuge.
8I react strongly to witch-hunters.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Shelter (Good). A refuge is sacred
2Tradition (Lawful). The west remembers
3Freedom (Chaotic). No Palace rules my hills
4Pragmatism (Neutral). Survival first
5Loyalty (Lawful). Protect the symbol at any cost
6Ruthlessness (Evil). Threats must be ended

Bonds

d6Bond
1I owe my life to Kiamo Ko.
2Someone I served there is missing.
3I protect a hidden room in the castle.
4I am hunted for what I know.
5I keep a letter meant for a witch.
6I still hear the castle at night.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I distrust outsiders automatically.
2I turn every problem into a siege.
3I overreact to authority.
4I isolate when stressed.
5I cling to grudges.
6I take risks to prove loyalty.

GM Notes

Kiamo Ko ties are great for western travel, witch legends, and hidden refuges. Use pursuers, tribal politics, and the question of whether symbols help or harm the living.

Related Pages

  • Kiamo Ko
  • The Vinkus
  • Vinkan
  • Winged Monkeys

character/backgrounds/thropp-family-conn.title: Thropp Family Connection
character/backgrounds/thropp-family-conn.content:
Thropp Family Connection

"Some names are blessings. Ours is a storm."

Overview

You are tied to the Thropp family - by blood, marriage, service, or obligation. In Oz, that name drags history behind it: Nessarose, Elphaba, Shell, wars, myths, and guilt.

Connection means people project stories onto you. Some want favors. Some want vengeance. A few want you as proof that the past can be controlled.

Applicable Races

This is a human background rooted in Munchkinland politics and imperial fallout.

  • Munchkinlander: The most common origin point for Thropp ties
  • Emerald City Native: Imperial circles entangled with Shell's rule
  • Gillikinese: Academics and nobles fascinated by the legend
  • Outlander: Those pulled in through marriage or diplomacy

Skill Proficiencies

History, Persuasion

Tool Proficiencies

None

Languages

One of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A family token, letter, or seal
  • A piece of clothing that draws attention (or hides it)
  • A small notebook of names and dates
  • A pouch containing 12 gp
  • A keepsake tied to a Thropp story (true or false)

Feature: A Name That Opens Doors (and Closes Them)

When your connection is believed, you can usually secure a hearing from people obsessed with the Thropps: loyalists, rebels, scholars, and profiteers. The same recognition can also trigger hostility and danger.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I get tired of being a symbol.
2I correct rumors, then regret it.
3I speak carefully about family.
4I feel responsible for history.
5I flirt with danger out of spite.
6I crave anonymity.
7I carry pride and shame together.
8I notice who reacts to my name.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Redemption (Good). I will do better than the legend
2Legacy (Lawful). Bloodline demands loyalty
3Truth (Neutral). Stop rewriting the past
4Freedom (Chaotic). I refuse inherited roles
5Power (Neutral). A name is a tool
6Revenge (Evil). I will avenge my family's harm

Bonds

d6Bond
1I protect a relative who cannot be public.
2I carry a secret about the Thropps.
3An enemy hunts me for my connection.
4I owe a debt to someone the Thropps wronged.
5I keep a relic linked to Elphaba's story.
6I am searching for the truth of a family event.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I assume conflict is inevitable.
2I lash out at anyone who judges me.
3I chase validation through danger.
4I keep secrets until they poison relationships.
5I romanticize suffering as destiny.
6I use my name as leverage too easily.

GM Notes

This background makes the campaign personal: political factions want the character as symbol, scapegoat, or key. Use rumor storms, inherited enemies, and the temptation to exploit the name.

Related Pages

  • Munchkinland
  • Emperor Shell Reign
  • Free Munchkinland
  • The Palace

character/backgrounds/foreign-diplomat.title: Foreign Diplomat
character/backgrounds/foreign-diplomat.content:
Foreign Diplomat

"To negotiate with Oz, you must first learn which Oz you are speaking to."

Overview

You represent a foreign power - Ev, Ix, Quox, or another neighboring land. You arrived with letters of credence, a polished smile, and a quiet fear of becoming leverage in someone else's war.

Being a diplomat means translating not just language, but values. Oz is fractured: Palace, provinces, tribes, and underground. Your job is to keep the seams from turning into blades.

Applicable Races

Diplomats are typically Outlanders, though imperial courts sometimes train domestic envoys for foreign work.

  • Outlander: The typical origin for foreign representatives
  • Gillikinese: Educated envoys sent north-to-capital
  • Emerald City Native: Imperial staff trained for protocol
  • Vinkan: Western emissaries for tribal negotiations

Skill Proficiencies

Insight, Persuasion

Tool Proficiencies

Calligrapher's supplies

Languages

Two of your choice

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • Letters of credence with official seals
  • A fine outfit suitable for court
  • A travel cloak and compact luggage
  • A small gift for an Ozian official
  • A pouch containing 15 gp

Feature: Protocol Shield

In formal settings, you can usually secure an audience, delay immediate violence, or invoke etiquette to buy time. Even hostile officials often prefer to handle diplomats quietly rather than publicly.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I take notes after every conversation.
2I never show my full reaction.
3I ask careful questions that sound polite.
4I treat silence as information.
5I can compliment and threaten in one sentence.
6I prefer negotiation to force.
7I keep contingency plans everywhere.
8I get lonely in crowds.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Peace (Good). War is a failure of imagination
2Duty (Lawful). I serve my homeland first
3Pragmatism (Neutral). Stability beats purity
4Truth (Good). Lies make treaties rot
5Autonomy (Chaotic). No empire owns the provinces
6Influence (Evil). I will shape Oz for my benefit

Bonds

d6Bond
1My homeland expects results.
2I protect an interpreter or aide.
3I carry a secret clause in my treaty.
4An Ozian official owes me a favor.
5I am in love with someone I cannot claim.
6I fear being stranded in Oz forever.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I overtrust etiquette to save me.
2I hesitate when action is needed.
3I treat people as nations, not humans.
4I hide fear behind politeness.
5I keep secrets that endanger allies.
6I chase leverage too aggressively.

GM Notes

Diplomats open doors to court intrigue, foreign plots, and high-stakes negotiations. Use hostage diplomacy, secret clauses, and cultural misunderstandings to create tension.

Related Pages

  • The Palace
  • Emerald City
  • Outlander
  • Emperor Shell Reign

character/backgrounds/animal-passing-as-.title: Animal Passing as animal
character/backgrounds/animal-passing-as-.content:
Animal Passing as animal

"I learned to lower my eyes so they would stop looking for a mind."

Overview

You are a sentient Animal living as an ordinary animal to survive. You learned how to mimic dullness, how to hide language in your throat, how to let humans think you are property.

Passing keeps you alive. It also eats at you. Every day is a performance where being 'convincing' means being erased.

Applicable Races

This background is for sentient Animals forced into hiding by persecution.

  • Animals (Mammals): Passing as pets, livestock, or strays
  • Animals (Birds): Passing as barn birds, caged songbirds, or wild flocks
  • Winged Monkeys: Passing is complicated but possible under watch
  • The Touched: Rare: those 'passing' as harmless to avoid targeting

Skill Proficiencies

Stealth, Deception

Tool Proficiencies

Disguise kit (improvised)

Languages

Understands one language; chooses when (or if) to speak

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A hidden token of your former identity
  • A small pouch containing 5 gp (or stashed goods)
  • A scrap of cloth with a coded mark
  • A piece of food you saved for later
  • A scent marker or chalk for signs

Feature: In Plain Sight

When you behave like an ordinary animal, many people ignore you. You can often move through guarded spaces as 'just an animal,' overhear conversations, and access areas a person would be questioned for entering.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I keep my intelligence hidden automatically.
2I watch humans like they are weather.
3I hoard small luxuries in secret places.
4I panic when someone tries to 'train' me.
5I bond quickly with other Animals.
6I hate being touched without warning.
7I am patient to the point of coldness.
8I sometimes speak in my sleep.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Survival (Neutral). Live now; speak later
2Dignity (Good). I am not property
3Secrecy (Lawful). Exposure kills
4Freedom (Chaotic). No cage is acceptable
5Kinship (Good). Protect Animals first
6Retribution (Evil). I will punish every handler

Bonds

d6Bond
1A human child suspects the truth about me.
2I protect a hidden Animal cell.
3I keep a memory of my old name sacred.
4I owe a smuggler my life.
5I cannot abandon other passing Animals.
6I am waiting for a signal to run.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I freeze when discovered.
2I lash out when treated as property.
3I refuse help out of pride.
4I am slow to trust anyone.
5I risk myself to prove personhood.
6I carry rage that leaks out sideways.

GM Notes

This background enables stealth play and social commentary. Use 'cute animal' assumptions, a sudden threat of capture, and the moral question of whether to reveal yourself to save someone else.

Related Pages

  • Mammals
  • The Wizard Reign
  • Animal Resistance
  • Animal Underground Railroad

character/backgrounds/dragon-survivor.title: Dragon Survivor
character/backgrounds/dragon-survivor.content:
Dragon Survivor

"Fire rewrites the world in one breath."

Overview

Dragons are rare enough that most Ozians treat them like children's tales. You know better. You survived an encounter that left ash where certainty used to be.

Maybe you lost a caravan. Maybe a village burned. Maybe you saw a dragon once and have been running from that image ever since. You carry a sense for disaster, and a fear that feels like smoke.

Applicable Races

Dragon encounters are rare; survivors can be any race or origin.

  • Outlander: Travelers more likely to cross strange paths
  • Vinkan: Western routes and old ruins
  • Munchkinlander: Caravans and border roads
  • The Touched: Those already marked by the uncanny

Skill Proficiencies

Survival, Perception

Tool Proficiencies

None

Languages

None

Equipment

You start with the following equipment:

  • A scorched keepsake
  • A small flask of water you refill obsessively
  • A cloak patched against burns
  • A scrap of scale or charred bone (maybe)
  • A pouch containing 10 gp

Feature: Smoke Sense

You are quick to notice signs of impending danger: shifts in wind, unnatural heat, panicked animals, and the pattern of people about to stampede. You can often warn others or choose the safest route when panic hits.

Suggested Characteristics

People who lived this life often carry it in their habits, loyalties, and blind spots.

Personality Traits

d8Personality Trait
1I startle at sudden heat.
2I watch the sky compulsively.
3I keep emergency supplies without thinking.
4I distrust 'safe' routes.
5I talk about the event too much or not at all.
6I am brave in bursts, then shaken.
7I hate enclosed spaces that could trap smoke.
8I believe monsters are real - because they are.

Ideals

d6Ideal
1Protection (Good). Warn others before it is too late
2Caution (Lawful). Risk is usually stupidity
3Freedom (Chaotic). Keep moving; never settle
4Truth (Neutral). People should know what exists
5Revenge (Evil). I will hunt what hunted me
6Faith (Neutral). The world is larger than rulers

Bonds

d6Bond
1I lost someone in the fire.
2I protect a survivor who blames me.
3I keep a map of where it happened.
4I owe my life to a stranger.
5I am searching for proof it was real.
6I promised to return and recover something.

Flaws

d6Flaw
1I panic when plans change suddenly.
2I overreact to small threats.
3I refuse shelter even when needed.
4I take reckless revenge fantasies seriously.
5I push others away to keep them safe.
6I cannot stop reliving the moment.

GM Notes

Dragon survivors are a clean inciting incident: quests for proof, revenge, or rescue. Use rumors of dragons as misinformation or as the real thing, and let the survivor's trauma shape decisions.

Related Pages

  • The Traveler
  • The Vinkus
  • Munchkinland
  • Touched

exploration/locations/yackles-estate.title: Yackle's Estate
exploration/locations/yackles-estate.content:
Yackle's Estate

⚠️ GM CONTENT - Contains spoilers for The Witch's Wake

"The house sits like a sleeping predator in the hills—gray stone, narrow windows, the kind of silence that suggests it's listening."

Overview

Yackle's estate is a three-story manor house in the remote Pertha Hills, southeast of Shiz. Built in the Gillikinese architectural style of a century past, it appears abandoned but is, in fact, very much alive. The house is bound to Yackle through decades of ritual magic, making it an extension of her will—and potentially her final trap.

Key Features

  • The House is Watching: Yackle can perceive anything that happens in any room
  • Doors Lock and Unlock: Yackle controls movement through the house
  • Objects Animate: Furniture, portraits, and decorations can become threats
  • Time Feels Wrong: Clocks show different times, shadows move incorrectly
  • Memory is Stored Here: The house contains fragments of lives Yackle has absorbed

Exterior and Approach

First Impressions

Read-aloud:

The carriage climbs the final switchback into the Pertha Hills as twilight settles. Through bare trees, you glimpse your destination: a gray stone manor, three stories tall, with narrow windows like suspicious eyes. No smoke rises from the chimneys. No lights burn in the windows. The grounds are overgrown—roses gone wild, fountains dry and cracked. As your carriage stops before the front door, you notice the absolute silence. No birds. No wind. Just the house, waiting.

The Grounds

  • Overgrown Gardens: Once formal, now wild. Roses still bloom despite the season.
  • Dry Fountain: Central courtyard. Carved with scenes of harvests and hunts. Basin is cracked.
  • Carriage House: Empty except for one ancient coach with rotting wheels.
  • Servant Quarters: Small building, separate from main house. Abandoned decades ago.
  • The Well: Behind the house. Very deep. Echoes strangely. (Secret: connects to basement)

The Front Door

Heavy oak, iron-banded, with a brass knocker shaped like a sleeping face. The door is unlocked—but once all heirs are inside, it will not open again until Yackle permits it.

Ground Floor

1. Foyer

Read-aloud:

The front door opens to a two-story foyer lit by a single chandelier of dusty crystal. A grand staircase curves upward. The floor is black and white marble, laid in a spiral pattern that makes your eyes swim if you look too long. Doors lead left and right. Ahead, through an archway, you glimpse a dining room. The air smells of old paper and something floral—roses, maybe, or funeral lilies.

Features:

  • Chandelier: Can fall (Yackle's doing) - Dex save DC 15 or 4d6 bludgeoning damage
  • Spiral Floor: Staring at it: Wisdom save DC 13 or become briefly disoriented (disadvantage on next check)
  • Portrait: Above the stairs. Woman in old-fashioned dress. Eyes seem to follow movement. (This is Yackle as she appeared decades ago)
  • Side Tables: Vase with dried roses. Guest book (last entry: 47 years ago).

Secret: The spiral pattern on the floor matches the ritual circle in the hidden basement. Investigation DC 18 to notice this if you've seen both.

2. Parlor (West Wing, Ground Floor)

Read-aloud:

This parlor was once elegant—now it's a museum of decay. Velvet furniture faded to gray. A cold fireplace. Bookshelves with volumes whose spines have crumbled away. A grandfather clock stands in the corner, its hands frozen at seven minutes past midnight.

Features:

  • The Clock: Stopped at 12:07. If wound, it chimes—and time throughout the house begins moving strangely. (See Lair Actions)
  • Books: Philosophy, theology, forbidden histories. Investigation DC 14: find a volume on Kumbric Witch mythology.
  • Furniture: Can animate if Yackle wishes. Armchair (CR 1/2), loveseat (CR 1).
  • Hidden Compartment: Behind false book spine. Contains Yackle's diary from 40 years ago. Reveals she was searching for "a way to become what She was."

3. Dining Room (Central, Ground Floor)

Read-aloud:

The dining table is set for seven. Crystal goblets, silver cutlery, fine china—all covered in decades of dust. Seven high-backed chairs wait. At the head of the table sits an eighth chair, notably larger, carved with thorned roses. A bell sits beside that place setting.

Features:

  • The Bell: Silver, engraved with Yackle's name. If rung, Yackle's voice echoes through the house: "I'm so glad you've come."
  • Place Settings: Each has a name card. Six match the heirs. The seventh says "The Witness" (Mr. Trism). The eighth says "The Hostess."
  • The Meal: If the bell is rung, spectral servants (Memory Shades) appear and begin serving a phantom feast. The food looks real but tastes of ash and old flowers.
  • Chandelier Above: Heavy, ornate. Can be dropped as attack (Dex save DC 15, 6d6 damage).

Secret: Under "The Hostess" plate is a key. It opens the locked door to the Observatory (third floor).

4. Kitchen (East Wing, Ground Floor)

Read-aloud:

The kitchen is surprisingly clean—almost as if someone still uses it. A cast-iron stove, cold now. A prep table with knives hanging above. Copper pots gleaming faintly. A pantry door stands ajar, darkness beyond.

Features:

  • The Stove: If investigated closely, the ash in the firebox is still slightly warm. (Yackle was here recently.)
  • Knives: Can animate as flying weapons if Yackle chooses. Attack +5, 1d4+2 piercing, 30 ft range.
  • Pantry: Mostly empty. One shelf has fresh bread, clearly magical. (Eating it: Con save DC 14 or fall into a trance-like sleep for 1 hour.)
  • Servant's Stairs: Narrow staircase leads to second floor servants' quarters.

Clue: Perception DC 15: There's a very faint scent of green-tinged skin here. Not perfume. Something else. (Yackle's scent.)

5. Library (West Wing, Ground Floor)

Read-aloud:

Floor-to-ceiling bookshelves crowd this room. A rolling ladder, a reading desk, a leather chair by a window. Most books are moldering, but some appear well-maintained. The air here is thick with old paper and something acrid—ink, maybe, or old magic.

Features:

  • The Collection: Arcana DC 12 reveals many forbidden texts. Topics: pre-Lurline magic, soul transference, immortality, the Kumbric Witch.
  • Reading Desk: Open book: "The Hunger That Outlasts Death." Underlined passage: "To become eternal, one must consume that which makes others alive—their memories, their loves, their grief."
  • Ritual Circle: Hidden under the rug. Investigation DC 16. Chalk and dried blood, forming a 7-pointed star.
  • Trapped Book: One volume (spine reads "The Grimmerie's Origins") is trapped. Touching it: Wisdom save DC 15 or take 3d6 psychic damage and see a flash of Yackle's face, much younger, screaming.

Major Clue: Book titled "Vessels and Vicars: On Bodily Transference" describes how a dying witch can prepare a ritual to transfer her consciousness into a new body—specifically, into someone who has been marked with her power.

Second Floor

6. Master Bedroom (East Wing, Second Floor)

Read-aloud:

This was clearly the mistress's chamber. A four-poster bed with moth-eaten curtains. A vanity with a cracked mirror. A wardrobe standing open, revealing old dresses in styles from decades past. The window overlooks the wild gardens. Everything is perfectly preserved—too perfectly. No dust here.

Features:

  • The Mirror: Cracks form a pattern like a spider's web. Looking into it: Charisma save DC 14 or see your reflection smile when you don't.
  • The Wardrobe: Dresses in green, gray, black. One dress is newer—recently made. It's sized for one of the heirs. (Yackle's prepared it for her new body.)
  • Under the Bed: A lockbox. Lock DC 15. Contains letters between Yackle and someone signed only "K.W." (Kumbric Witch). The last letter: "You will inherit what I was, but the price is all that you are."
  • Secret Panel: Investigation DC 17. Behind the headboard. Contains Yackle's true will—the real one, not the fake Trism read. It names no heirs. It says: "I leave myself to the one who can endure me."

7. Guest Bedrooms (West Wing, Second Floor)

Six bedrooms, nearly identical. Each has:

  • A narrow bed
  • A small writing desk
  • A window (locked from outside)
  • A name card on the door matching each heir

The Trick: These rooms are designed to isolate heirs. If someone sleeps in one, they experience vivid nightmares drawn from Yackle's memories of previous "guests." Wisdom save DC 14 or wake with one level of exhaustion.

Personalization: Each room has been subtly customized for its designated heir:

  • The Scholar's room: Books on their exact research topic
  • The Heir's room: Family portraits they've never seen
  • The Animal's room: Subtle pro-Animal pamphlets (a test?)
  • The Debtor's room: Account books showing their exact debts
  • The Maunt's room: Religious texts from their former order
  • The Widow's room: Personal effects of their lost loved one

This proves Yackle has been watching them for a long time.

8. Portrait Gallery (Central Hall, Second Floor)

Read-aloud:

The upstairs hallway is lined with portraits. Dozens of faces stare out from ornate frames—men and women in styles spanning a century. Some you recognize from Oz history. Others are unknown. But they all share one thing: a certain emptiness in their eyes, as if something vital has been taken from them.

Features:

  • The Portraits: History DC 14 reveals some are of people who vanished mysteriously over the past 50 years. All were guests of Yackle.
  • The Newest Portrait: Still has wet paint. It shows one of the heirs—perfectly rendered, as if from life. (Yackle painted it. She's choosing.)
  • Animate Portraits: During combat, Yackle can make 1d4 portraits attack. They slide out of frames as Shadow Selves (use the stat block from House Horrors).

Secret: One portrait has a false back. Investigation DC 16. Behind it: a spy hole looking into the Master Bedroom.

9. Servants' Quarters (East Wing, Second Floor)

Small, cramped rooms. Long abandoned. Beds with rotted linens. Nothing of value—except one room where:

The Last Servant's Room:

  • A journal on the bedside table
  • Last entry: "She doesn't age. I've been here 30 years and she doesn't age. I'm leaving tonight."
  • The servant never left. Their skeleton is in the closet, locked from the outside.

Third Floor

10. The Observatory (Locked)

Key required: Under the plate in the dining room, or Thieves' Tools DC 18.

Read-aloud:

The top floor is a single round room beneath a glass dome. Telescopes point at the sky. Star charts cover the walls. At the center: a massive orrery of Oz's moons, slowly rotating despite no visible mechanism. The air here hums with magic.

Features:

  • The Orrery: Made of brass and crystal. Arcana DC 15: It's not showing the current sky—it's showing the sky 50 years ago, the night Yackle performed her first ritual.
  • Star Charts: Covered in Yackle's notes. "The alignment is near." "She promised I would not die." "The vessel must arrive willingly."
  • Ritual Components: Chalk, candles, dried herbs, a silver knife. Everything needed for a transference ritual.
  • The View: From here, you can see for miles—and you can see that the roads leading to the estate have vanished. You're cut off.

Major Clue: A prepared ritual circle is drawn on the floor. Seven points. Six for "contributors" (the other heirs). One for "the inheritor" (Yackle's new body). In the center: a space for "the willing heart" (the true sacrifice).

11. Yackle's Study (Hidden)

Access: Secret door from Observatory. Investigation DC 18, or Yackle reveals it during confrontation.

Read-aloud:

This room is small, windowless, and absolutely crammed with magical apparatus. Jars of pickled things. Bottles of luminous liquids. A desk covered in notes in a cramped, frantic hand. And on the wall: a mirror, but the reflection it shows is not this room. It shows a chamber deep underground, lit by green witchfire.

Features:

  • The Mirror: It's a window to the Heart Chamber (basement). Touching it: transported there instantly (no save, Yackle's trap).
  • The Notes: Yackle's research. "I have outlived three bodies. The fourth is prepared. The fifth will be eternal."
  • Preservation Jars: Each contains a piece of someone: a finger, an eye, a tongue. Labels name previous "heirs" who failed.
  • Yackle's Diary (Final Volume): Last entry: "Tonight. The alignment is perfect. One will provide the vessel. The rest will provide the fuel. And I will finally become what She promised—deathless, complete, a witch without limits."

Basement (The Heart Chamber)

Access

Three ways down:

  • The Well: Outside. Climb down 60 feet. Athletics DC 13.
  • Servant Stairs Secret: From kitchen, Investigation DC 17 reveals hidden staircase.
  • The Mirror: From Yackle's Study. Instant but one-way.

12. The Heart Chamber

Read-aloud:

You descend into the earth. The air grows cold. The walls are raw stone, carved with symbols in a language that predates Lurline. At the bottom: a circular chamber, lit by sickly green witchfire that burns without heat. In the center, a ritual circle identical to the one in the Observatory—but this one pulses with power. You can feel it in your teeth, your bones. This is the true heart of the house. And standing in the circle, waiting, is Yackle herself.

Features:

  • The Circle: Seven points, glowing. Each point has a name carved into the floor—the six heirs plus "The Inheritor."
  • The Walls: Covered in Kumbric script. Religion DC 18 or Arcana DC 16: These are binding spells, keeping the house anchored to this plane.
  • Yackle's Altar: A stone slab with manacles. Bloodstains. This is where she performs the final ritual.
  • The Fuel: Along the walls, alcoves contain the desiccated remains of previous victims—people whose memories and life force were consumed.

This is where the final confrontation happens.

The House as a Character

House Behavior by Stage

Stage 1 - The Reading (Welcoming):

  • Doors open easily
  • Lights flicker on in occupied rooms
  • Subtle creaks and settlings, but nothing overtly hostile
  • The house "herds" the heirs toward the dining room

Stage 2 - Exploration (Watching):

  • Doors sometimes lock behind the players
  • Portraits' eyes follow movement
  • Clocks chime at wrong times
  • Players hear whispers (echoes of previous victims)
  • The house separates players who split up

Stage 3 - Tests/Hunting (Aggressive):

  • Furniture animates and attacks
  • Doors seal shut, trapping players
  • Shadows move independently
  • Temperature drops; breath visible
  • The house actively hunts the players, using lair actions

Stage 4 - Confrontation (Desperate):

  • The house merges with Yackle—they are one entity
  • Walls bleed
  • Geometry becomes non-Euclidean
  • The house tries to collapse on the players if Yackle is near death

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing ties), the house takes one lair action:

  1. Sealing Doors: All doors in a 30-foot radius around a target lock. DC 18 Strength to force open, or they unlock at the end of the round.
  2. Animated Assault: 1d4 pieces of furniture animate and attack the nearest creature. Use Animated Armor stats but reskin as chairs, tables, suits of armor.
  3. Temporal Distortion: One creature must make a Wisdom save DC 16 or repeat their last action exactly (including movement and targets if possible). If impossible, they lose their action.
  4. Memory Flash: All creatures in one room must make a Wisdom save DC 15 or be stunned until the end of their next turn as they experience a fragment of a previous victim's final moments.
  5. Structural Shift: The house rearranges. A doorway that led to the parlor now leads to a bedroom. Players must make new mental maps. (This can only happen once per confrontation.)

GM Notes: Using the Estate

Pacing the Reveal

  • Early (Stage 1-2): The house seems merely old and creepy. Foreshadow with small details: warm ash, wrong reflections, portraits watching.
  • Middle (Stage 3): Escalate to overt threats. Animated furniture, locked doors, whispers. Make it clear the house itself is hostile.
  • Late (Stage 4): Full horror. The house is Yackle's body. Defeating her means destroying the house—and escaping before it collapses.

Player Agency

  • Let players explore freely in Stage 2. Don't force them into a railroad.
  • Reward investigation. Every clue brings them closer to understanding Yackle's plan.
  • If they try to leave early, the doors are sealed—but they can break windows, climb down, flee through the gardens. Yackle will hunt them, but escape is possible (though it ends the adventure prematurely).

The Witch Player's Advantage

The player secretly playing Yackle's vessel knows the house layout instinctively. Give them subtle hints:

  • "You feel drawn to the library."
  • "You know, somehow, that there's a hidden door here."
  • "The house wants you to find the observatory."

This makes them feel special without giving away the secret immediately.

Related Pages

  • Yackle - The mistress of the estate
  • The Witch's Wake - Full adventure
  • House Horrors - Creatures that inhabit the estate
  • Pertha Hills - Regional context

npcs/yackle.title: Yackle
npcs/yackle.content:
Yackle

⚠️ GM CONTENT - Contains major spoilers for The Witch's Wake

"I have been many things. I have been young and old, beautiful and forgotten, alive and... something else. What I will be next depends on you, dear heirs."

Overview

Yackle is not merely the villain of The Witch's Wake—she is a cosmic tragedy. An ancient being who existed before Lurline spoke the Eight Words that gave Oz structure, Yackle is trapped by the Binding of Witness: she exists because she is unseen, but cannot truly live or die. For over a thousand years, she has been suspended in this liminal state, desperately seeking either true existence or final dissolution.

The Truth About Yackle

  • Age: Over 1,000 years old. She remembers the Kumbric Void before creation.
  • Origin: A fragment of pre-Lurline chaos given consciousness by Lurline's first Word: REMEMBER. She was never meant to be.
  • Current State: Neither alive nor dead. The Binding of Witness keeps her in stasis—unseen, unwitnessed, unable to truly exist.
  • The House: Yackle's Estate is an extension of her being, sustaining her and trapping her simultaneously.
  • The Heirs: Not heirs—they are inversions of the Eight Bindings. By witnessing their truths, Yackle hopes to break the eighth Binding and achieve dissolution (or ascension, if she collects all eight secrets).

Personality & Roleplaying

As Madame Viridian (Disguise)

Yackle plays the role of "Madame Viridian," a widow and fellow heir. She is a consummate actor, having practiced deception for centuries.

Mannerisms:

  • Observes more than she speaks
  • Occasionally knows things she shouldn't (then covers with excuses)
  • Shows subtle contempt for the "greedy" heirs
  • Seems to know her way around the house
  • Touches objects with odd familiarity
  • Asks probing questions about each heir's past

Voice: Measured, calm, with occasional slips into archaic phrasing.

Tells (Foreshadowing):

  • Never eats or drinks (claims fasting, nerves, etc.)
  • Casts no reflection in certain mirrors
  • Animals (if any) react with fear to her presence
  • She doesn't bleed if cut—or bleeds something greenish
  • Knows the names of servants who died centuries ago
  • The house responds to her emotions

When Revealed

Once her cover is blown (or she chooses to reveal herself), Yackle drops all pretense.

Personality Revealed:

  • Lonely: A millennium of isolation has left her desperately craving connection, even as she prepares to consume the heirs
  • Philosophical: Views existence and non-existence as the only moral questions that matter
  • Tired: Exhausted by a thousand years of unchanging existence
  • Desperate: Will do anything to either truly exist or finally end
  • Conflicted: Genuinely likes some of the heirs, which makes what she must do harder

Sample Dialogue:

"Do you know what it's like to exist for a thousand years without ever truly being seen? To watch everyone you've ever known die, again and again, while you remain? I don't want your lives. I want what you have that I never did—the chance to be real."
"The Bindings made me. Memory, the first Word, gave me consciousness. But Witness, the eighth Word—that one trapped me. I exist only because I am unseen. To be witnessed is to break. I've been waiting a millennium for someone brave enough to truly see me."

Goals & Motivations

  1. Collect Inversions: Each heir represents an inversion of one of the Eight Bindings. By collecting their secrets (witnessing their truths), Yackle weakens the Bindings.
  2. Break the Eighth Binding: When the heirs witness her true form in the Heart Chamber, the Binding of Witness cracks. This is what she's been engineering for centuries.
  3. Achieve Dissolution (or Ascension):
    • If fewer than 8 secrets: She hopes to finally die, to dissolve into peaceful non-existence.
    • If all 8 secrets: She transforms into something beyond Binding—truly immortal, truly powerful (Phase 4).

What She Wants From Each Heir

Each heir embodies an inversion of a Binding. When they reveal their secret in Yackle's presence, she collects that inversion's power:

  • Averic (Memory): Rewrote the past - False memories weaken truth
  • Liir (Blood): Claims false lineage - Severed connection weakens heritage
  • Frederick (Nature): Denies true self - Hidden identity weakens essence
  • Shell (Service): Punished for service - Betrayed loyalty weakens devotion
  • Sarima (Sacrifice): Traded instead of gave - Bargained exchange weakens gift
  • Mareth (Deed): Unchanged by actions - Unpunished atrocity weakens transformation
  • Seven (Hunger): Hungers but shouldn't - Mechanical longing weakens natural desire
  • The Eighth (Witness): Never truly seen - When the heirs witness Yackle's true form, the final Binding breaks

Combat Statistics

Phase 1: The Revealed Witch (CR 11)

When This Phase Occurs: Yackle's disguise is broken, or she chooses to reveal herself. She fights as a powerful arcane caster, using the house as her lair.

Yackle (Phase 1)

Medium humanoid (primordial), neutral evil

Armor Class 15 (mage armor)
Hit Points 200 (20d8 + 100)
Speed 30 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)14 (+2)20 (+5)20 (+5)18 (+4)16 (+3)

Saving Throws Int +9, Wis +8
Skills Arcana +13, Deception +11, History +13, Insight +8, Perception +8
Damage Resistances necrotic; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
Condition Immunities charmed, frightened
Senses darkvision 120 ft., passive Perception 18
Languages Common, Kumbric (ancient dialect), Ozian dialects, telepathy 60 ft.
Challenge 11 (7,200 XP)

Legendary Resistance (3/Day). If Yackle fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

Magic Resistance. Yackle has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Collected Secrets. For each secret Yackle has collected (see Secret Collection below), she gains specific combat benefits. Mark which secrets have been revealed in her presence.

Spellcasting. Yackle is an 18th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 17, +9 to hit with spell attacks). She has the following spells prepared:

  • Cantrips (at will): mage hand, minor illusion, ray of frost, shocking grasp
  • 1st level (4 slots): detect magic, mage armor, magic missile, shield
  • 2nd level (3 slots): hold person, misty step, suggestion
  • 3rd level (3 slots): counterspell, dispel magic, fear, fireball
  • 4th level (3 slots): dimension door, greater invisibility, polymorph
  • 5th level (3 slots): dominate person, hold monster, telekinesis
  • 6th level (1 slot): chain lightning, true seeing
  • 7th level (1 slot): finger of death
  • 8th level (1 slot): feeblemind
  • 9th level (1 slot): time stop

Actions

Multiattack. Yackle makes two attacks with Void Touch or casts a cantrip and makes one Void Touch attack.

Void Touch. Melee Spell Attack: +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (3d8 + 4) necrotic damage, and the target must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or have its hit point maximum reduced by the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

Kumbric Extraction (Recharge 5-6). Yackle targets one creature within 60 feet that has not yet revealed their secret. The target must make a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 22 (4d10) psychic damage and is compelled to speak their deepest secret aloud. Yackle immediately collects that secret's power. On a success, the target takes half damage and resists the extraction. Characters who have already revealed their secrets voluntarily are immune to this ability.

Legendary Actions

Yackle can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Yackle regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

Cantrip. Yackle casts a cantrip.

Move. Yackle moves up to her speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Cast Spell (Costs 2 Actions). Yackle casts a spell of 3rd level or lower.

Memory Drain (Costs 3 Actions). Yackle targets one creature she can see within 30 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or take 22 (4d10) psychic damage and become stunned until the end of its next turn as Yackle tears a memory from its mind. Yackle regains hit points equal to half the psychic damage dealt.

Secret Collection Benefits

When Yackle collects a secret (either through Kumbric Extraction or by being present when it's revealed), she gains the following benefits during Phase 1:

Character Secret Collected Benefit
Averic Averic has disadvantage on Intelligence saves. Once per battle, Yackle can counter one of his spells without using a reaction or spell slot.
Liir Yackle has advantage on attacks against Liir. Liir's damage against Yackle is reduced by 1d6.
Frederick Yackle can cast dominate person on Frederick once without concentration or using a spell slot.
Shell Yackle gains resistance to radiant damage. Whenever Shell heals an ally, Yackle regains hit points equal to 25% of the healing done.
Sarima Once per battle, Yackle can use one of Sarima's spell slots to cast a spell. Sarima has disadvantage on concentration checks.
Mareth Mareth has disadvantage on attack rolls against Yackle. Critical hits against Yackle become normal hits.
Seven Once per battle, Yackle can skip Seven's turn entirely. Seven has disadvantage on Wisdom saves.

Phase 2: Merged with the House (CR 12)

When This Phase Occurs: Yackle is reduced to 100 hit points or lower in Phase 1, OR the players destroy her physical form. Yackle merges fully with the house, becoming a distributed consciousness.

Change in Tactics: Yackle is now everywhere and nowhere. She can speak from any surface, attack from any direction, and the house itself becomes her weapon. She uses lair actions more frequently and cannot be "cornered."

Yackle-House Entity (Phase 2)

Large monstrosity (living structure), neutral evil

Armor Class 17 (architectural hardness)
Hit Points 180 (19d10 + 76)
Speed 0 ft. (the house does not move, but Yackle's manifestations can appear anywhere within it)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
18 (+4)10 (+0)18 (+4)20 (+5)18 (+4)16 (+3)

Saving Throws Con +9, Int +10, Wis +9
Damage Resistances necrotic, psychic; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing
Damage Immunities poison
Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
Senses truesight 120 ft. (entire house), passive Perception 19
Languages all languages Yackle knew, telepathy (entire house)
Challenge 12 (8,400 XP)

Legendary Resistance (3/Day). If the house fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

Omnipresent. Yackle can perceive everything within the house simultaneously. She cannot be surprised. Stealth and invisibility are ineffective against her.

Bound to the House. Yackle cannot leave the house. If forced outside (via banishment, etc.), she can manifest a spectral form but has disadvantage on all rolls until she returns.

Distributed Existence. Yackle does not have a single body. Damage must be dealt to the house itself (attacking structural elements, destroying ritual anchors, etc.). Destroying a manifestation does not harm her directly.

Regeneration. The house regains 20 hit points at the start of Yackle's turn if she has at least 1 hit point.

Actions

Multiattack. The house makes three attacks: any combination of Manifested Strike, Structural Assault, or casts a spell.

Manifested Strike. Melee Weapon Attack: +9 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage plus 9 (2d8) necrotic damage. (Yackle manifests a spectral limb from a wall, floor, or ceiling to strike.)

Structural Assault. Yackle causes part of the house to attack. Choose one:

  • Falling Debris: Targets in a 10-foot radius must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw or take 27 (6d8) bludgeoning damage (half on success).
  • Animated Furniture: 1d4 objects (chairs, tables, suits of armor) animate and attack as if using the animate objects spell (Yackle's spell save DC).
  • Sealing Room: All doors and windows in one room seal shut. DC 20 Strength check to force open, or they remain closed until the end of the round.

Spellcasting. Yackle retains her spellcasting ability from Phase 1. However, she now casts spells from any point in the house (walls, floors, ceilings, mirrors, etc.).

Legendary Actions

The house can take 3 legendary actions (same options as Phase 1, plus):

Shift Geometry (Costs 2 Actions). The house rearranges itself. Doorways lead to different rooms. Staircases reverse direction. Players must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check or become lost (disadvantage on navigation checks for 1 minute).

Invoke Terror (Costs 3 Actions). All creatures in one room must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or become frightened for 1 minute. Frightened creatures must use their movement to flee toward the nearest exit. They can repeat the save at the end of each of their turns.

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing ties), the house takes a lair action. Roll 1d6:

  1. Sealing Doors: All doors within 60 feet of a chosen point lock. DC 18 Strength to force.
  2. Animated Assault: 2d4 objects animate and attack.
  3. Temporal Distortion: One creature repeats its last action (Wisdom save DC 17 negates).
  4. Memory Flash: All creatures in one room are stunned until the end of their next turn (Wisdom save DC 17 negates).
  5. Structural Collapse: Ceiling collapses in a 20-foot cube. Dexterity save DC 17 or take 4d10 bludgeoning damage.
  6. Whispers of the Dead: All creatures in the house hear the voices of Yackle's previous victims. Wisdom save DC 17 or take 3d8 psychic damage and become frightened of Yackle for 1 minute.

How to Defeat Phase 2

Yackle cannot be killed through normal damage in this phase. Players must:

  • Find the Heart Chamber: Located in the cellar, accessed through the false wall (map found in puzzle box).
  • Reach Yackle's True Body: Suspended in the Heart Chamber by shadow threads connected to three anchor points.
  • Proceed to Phase 3: Once players reach the Heart Chamber and witness Yackle's true form, the Binding of Witness cracks and Phase 3 begins.

Phase 3: The Heart Chamber (CR 9)

When This Phase Occurs: The players reach the Heart Chamber and witness Yackle's true body. The eighth Binding—Witness—cracks. She manifests in her original form—ancient, withered, real for the first time in a millennium.

Visual Description: Yackle's original body, suspended by shadow threads in the center of the circular room. Ancient. Withered. Eyes closed. Green-gray skin stretched over bones like parchment. As the players enter, her eyes open—genuinely seeing and being seen for the first time in a thousand years.

Yackle's True Form (Phase 3)

Medium aberration (primordial entity), neutral evil

Armor Class 14 (natural armor)
Hit Points 150 (20d8 + 60)
Speed 30 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)14 (+2)16 (+3)20 (+5)18 (+4)16 (+3)

Saving Throws Int +9, Wis +8, Cha +7
Skills Arcana +13, History +13, Insight +8
Damage Vulnerabilities radiant
Damage Resistances necrotic, psychic
Condition Immunities frightened
Senses truesight 60 ft., passive Perception 14
Languages Common, Kumbric, telepathy 60 ft.
Challenge 9 (5,000 XP)

Witnessed. For the first time in a millennium, Yackle is truly seen. She is vulnerable to radiant damage and cannot hide or become invisible by any means. However, being witnessed also makes her fully real—she can now experience pain, joy, connection, and ultimately, death.

Binding Fragments. Yackle retains fragments of the Eight Bindings' power based on collected secrets (see Secret Benefits table, but at reduced effectiveness).

Spellcasting (Reduced). Yackle retains access to her spells but has fewer slots:

  • Cantrips: At will
  • 1st-3rd level: 3 slots each
  • 4th-5th level: 2 slots each
  • 6th-7th level: 1 slot each
  • 8th+ level: None

Actions

Multiattack. Yackle makes two Void Touch attacks or casts a spell and makes one Void Touch attack.

Void Touch. Melee Spell Attack: +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 22 (4d8 + 4) necrotic damage. If the target is a humanoid with 50 hit points or fewer, Yackle can attempt to possess it (DC 17 Charisma save to resist). On a failed save, Yackle's consciousness enters the target's body (see Possession below).

Unmaking Scream (Recharge 5-6). Yackle releases a psychic scream that embodies a thousand years of loneliness. All creatures within 30 feet must make a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw, taking 33 (6d10) psychic damage on a failure or half on a success. Creatures who fail are also stunned until the end of their next turn.

Legendary Actions

Yackle has 3 legendary actions in this phase:

Cantrip. Yackle casts a cantrip.

Move. Yackle moves up to her speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Cast Spell (Costs 2 Actions). Yackle casts a spell of 3rd level or lower.

Binding Lash (Costs 2 Actions). One shadow thread from an anchor lashes out. Melee weapon attack: +9 to hit, reach 15 ft., 18 (4d6+4) necrotic damage and target is grappled (escape DC 17).

The Anchor Points

Three glowing nodes where shadow threads connect Yackle's body to the walls. These represent her connection to PAST, PRESENT, and FUTURE.

  • AC: 12
  • HP: 30 each
  • Immune to: Necrotic, psychic damage

When an anchor is destroyed:

  • Yackle takes 20 damage
  • Yackle loses 1 legendary action permanently
  • Yackle can use her reaction to make a Void Touch attack against whoever destroyed it

When all three anchors are destroyed, Yackle's connection to time itself is severed. She becomes untethered, which triggers either her Final Moment (if she has fewer than 8 secrets) or Phase 4 (if she has collected all 8 secrets).

Possession Mechanic

If Yackle successfully possesses a character:

  • The character's consciousness is suppressed but aware
  • Yackle controls the body for 1 minute or until forced out
  • Allies can attempt to expel her: dispel magic (DC 17), protection from evil and good, or dealing 30+ psychic/radiant damage to the possessed character
  • If expelled, Yackle takes 4d10 psychic damage and cannot attempt possession again for 1 minute
  • This is Yackle's desperate attempt to survive—by taking a new vessel

Phase 4: Ascendant (CR 15) - ONLY IF ALL 8 SECRETS COLLECTED

When This Phase Occurs: Yackle has collected all eight secrets (all eight inversions), and all three anchors are destroyed. Instead of dissolution, she transcends—becoming something beyond the Bindings, a truly immortal entity.

WARNING: This is a near-TPK scenario. It should only occur if the party revealed all their secrets to Yackle. This represents the worst-case outcome.

Yackle Ascendant (Phase 4)

Medium aberration (primordial god), chaotic evil

Armor Class 18 (reality warping)
Hit Points 250 (20d8 + 150)
Speed 40 ft., fly 40 ft. (hover)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
14 (+2)18 (+4)20 (+5)22 (+6)20 (+5)20 (+5)

Saving Throws Dex +9, Int +11, Wis +10, Cha +10
Skills Arcana +16, History +16, Insight +10, Perception +10
Damage Resistances cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, psychic
Damage Immunities poison; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
Condition Immunities all conditions
Senses truesight 120 ft., passive Perception 20
Languages all languages, telepathy 120 ft.
Challenge 15 (13,000 XP)

Legendary Resistance (5/Day). If Yackle fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

Transcendent Being. Yackle is immune to all conditions. She cannot be charmed, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, stunned, or put to sleep by any means.

Reality Unbound. Yackle has broken free of the Eight Bindings. She can rewrite local reality within the house. Once per round as a free action, she can alter one aspect of the environment (change terrain, create walls, eliminate cover, etc.).

Eight Inversions Manifest. Yackle can use the powers of all eight collected secrets simultaneously (see Eight Inversion Attacks below).

Regeneration. Yackle regains 20 hit points at the start of her turn if she has at least 1 hit point and hasn't taken radiant damage since her last turn.

Actions

Multiattack. Yackle makes three attacks using any combination of Void Touch, Inversion Strike, or spells.

Void Touch. Melee Spell Attack: +11 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 28 (4d10 + 6) necrotic damage, and the target's hit point maximum is reduced by the damage taken.

Inversion Strike. Yackle channels one of the eight inversions as an attack (see Eight Inversion Attacks table below). Each can be used once per round.

Unmaking Wave (Recharge 5-6). Yackle releases a wave of unmaking energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw, taking 55 (10d10) psychic damage on a failure or half on a success. Creatures who fail are also stunned until the end of their next turn and forget their most recent action.

Legendary Actions

Yackle can take 5 legendary actions, choosing from the options below:

Cantrip. Yackle casts a cantrip.

Move. Yackle moves or teleports up to her speed.

Inversion Strike (Costs 1 Action). Yackle uses one Inversion Strike.

Cast Spell (Costs 2 Actions). Yackle casts a spell of 5th level or lower.

Reality Warp (Costs 3 Actions). Yackle fundamentally alters reality in a 30-foot radius. All creatures in the area must succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence saving throw or be teleported to a random location within the house, take 4d10 force damage, and be disoriented (disadvantage on attacks and saves until end of next turn).

Eight Inversion Attacks

Yackle can use each of these once per round as part of Inversion Strike:

Inversion Attack
False Memory (Averic) Target makes DC 18 Int save or forgets who their allies are for 1 minute (treats them as strangers). Repeat save each turn when damaged by Yackle.
Severed Blood (Liir) Target makes DC 18 Cha save or is cut off from their heritage. They lose all racial traits and class features tied to lineage for 1 minute.
Forced Truth (Frederick) Target makes DC 18 Wis save or their true form is revealed. All disguises, illusions, and polymorph effects on them end. They cannot hide or become invisible for 1 hour.
Betrayed Service (Shell) Target makes DC 18 Wis save or their healing becomes harmful for 1 minute. Any healing they attempt deals necrotic damage instead.
Hollow Sacrifice (Sarima) Target makes DC 18 Cha save or their magic becomes a bargain. Each spell they cast costs them 10 HP in addition to the spell slot for 1 minute.
Eternal Guilt (Mareth) Target makes DC 18 Wis save or is paralyzed by visions of those they've wronged. Paralyzed for 1 minute. Repeat save each turn, but disadvantage if they've killed innocents.
Mechanical Despair (Seven) Target makes DC 18 Con save or their body becomes mechanical. They gain vulnerability to lightning, lose ability to heal naturally, and feel no emotions for 1 minute.
Complete Witness (Eighth) Target makes DC 18 Cha save or is Witnessed completely. Yackle knows everything about them—all secrets, all fears, all weaknesses. She has advantage on all attacks and they have disadvantage on all saves vs. her for 1 minute.

Lair Actions (Phase 4)

On initiative count 20, Yackle can take a lair action. The entire house warps to her will:

  1. Walls of Oblivion: Walls of solidified void appear. 20-foot walls, AC 15, 50 HP. Block line of sight and movement.
  2. Gravity Reversal: Gravity reverses in one room. All creatures take 3d6 fall damage and are prone.
  3. Temporal Loop: One creature must repeat their last turn exactly (same actions, same targets if possible).
  4. Memory Harvest: All creatures in the house lose one prepared spell or regain one fewer hit die on their next rest.
  5. The House Hungers: The house itself attacks. 3d10 force damage to all creatures, Dex save DC 18 for half.

Defeating Phase 4

Phase 4 Yackle is extraordinarily dangerous. To defeat her:

  • Radiant Damage: She has no resistance to radiant damage. Focus holy magic, sunlight, divine power.
  • Lurline's Word: If found in the puzzle box, this deals 4d10 radiant damage automatically, no save.
  • Unmaking Phrase: If pieced together from Binding lore, stuns Yackle for 1 round (only works once).
  • Destroy Her Will: Reduce her to 0 HP. At 0 HP, she makes one final attack, then dissolves into nothingness with a scream that shatters all glass in the house.
  • The House Collapses: When Phase 4 Yackle is defeated, the house immediately begins collapsing. Players have 3 rounds to escape or be buried (10d10 bludgeoning damage per round after round 3).

Defeat Conditions (All Phases)

Yackle can be defeated through:

  1. Combat Victory: Reduce her to 0 HP in Phase 3 (or Phase 4 if it occurs). She dissolves into dust.
  2. Mercy/Peaceful Dissolution: In Phase 3, if offered genuine understanding and compassion, Yackle can choose to let go. This requires extraordinary roleplaying and a DC 20 Persuasion or Insight check. She fades peacefully, the house becomes mundane, and the players escape unharmed.
  3. Re-Binding: A character can volunteer to stay as the house's warden, binding Yackle but keeping her alive. The house remains sentient, Yackle remains trapped, and the volunteer becomes the new keeper. This is a bittersweet ending—one player sacrifices freedom to prevent Yackle's destruction.
  4. Exorcism: In Phase 2 or 3, powerful divine magic (dispel evil and good, banishment, etc.) combined with a DC 20 Religion check can forcibly banish Yackle. She screams and dissolves, but her last words curse the caster with haunting dreams.

Tactics by Phase

Phase 1 Tactics

  • Opens with greater invisibility or time stop to position advantageously
  • Focuses on extracting remaining secrets via Kumbric Extraction
  • Targets spellcasters first, using counterspell liberally
  • Uses dominate person on fighters to turn them against the party
  • Retreats via dimension door when bloodied
  • Uses Memory Drain to sustain herself while dealing psychic damage
  • Exploits collected secrets ruthlessly (see Secret Benefits table)

Phase 2 Tactics

  • Attacks from unexpected angles—walls, ceilings, mirrors
  • Separates the party by sealing rooms
  • Overwhelms with animated objects and lair actions
  • Uses Shift Geometry to disorient and confuse
  • Focuses attacks on anyone trying to reach the cellar
  • Creates choke points with debris and sealed doors
  • Uses Whispers of the Dead to demoralize

Phase 3 Tactics

  • Fights desperately—she knows this is her last chance
  • Attempts possession on low-HP targets
  • Uses anchors as cover, forcing players to divide attention
  • Casts high-damage spells even when it hurts her
  • If near death (below 50 HP), begs, bargains, lies, and offers deals
  • Makes philosophical arguments: "I only wanted to exist. Is that so wrong?"
  • If all anchors destroyed and she has <8 secrets, accepts defeat with relief
  • If all anchors destroyed and she has 8 secrets, transforms into Phase 4 with triumphant rage

Phase 4 Tactics (If Applicable)

  • Unleashes everything simultaneously—no holding back
  • Uses all eight Inversion Strikes each round to cripple different party members
  • Focuses Void Touch on anyone dealing radiant damage
  • Uses Reality Warp to separate and isolate targets
  • Employs Unmaking Wave when the party clusters
  • Regenerates 20 HP per turn unless hit with radiant damage
  • Lair actions create impossible battlefield conditions
  • Fights with the certainty of a god—she believes she's already won

Roleplaying Yackle's Death

If Defeated Through Violence (Phase 3)

She crumbles, her ancient body turning to ash. For a moment, you see her as she once was—before the Bindings, before the loneliness, when she was just a fragment of chaos given form. Young. Curious. Terrified of oblivion. Then that vision fades. Her last words echo: "I only wanted... to see tomorrow. To be seen today. Thank you... for witnessing me." The house groans. The walls crack. You have minutes to escape before it collapses entirely.

If Shown Mercy (Peaceful Dissolution)

She stares at you, disbelieving. Tears stream down her ancient face—the first tears in a millennium. "You would... spare me? Give me... peace?" For a long moment, she simply stands there, being seen, being witnessed, being real. Then she smiles—genuinely smiles. "I don't remember how to say thank you. But I remember this: you are kind. Kinder than I deserved." She fades, not into death, but into something gentler—dissolution without pain, release without violence. The house sighs, released from bondage. The walls settle. You are free to leave.

If Defeated in Phase 4

She screams—not in pain, but in fury and denial. "NO! I WAS BEYOND! I WAS FREE!" Her form fractures, reality warping around her. For a terrible moment, you see all her faces—every life she consumed, every mask she wore, a thousand years of stolen existence—and then she shatters like broken glass. The house shudders violently. Walls crack. The ceiling collapses. You hear her voice one final time, distant and fading: "I will return... I will always return... I am what refuses to end..." Then silence. Then the sound of the house tearing itself apart. RUN.

Yackle's Backstory (For GM Reference)

Yackle was never born. She was created—an accidental consequence of Lurline's first Word, REMEMBER. When Lurline imposed order on the Kumbric Void, fragments of pre-creation chaos were given structure. Most dissolved. Yackle... remembered. And in remembering, she became.

For her first century, she was simply a wandering consciousness, trying to understand what it meant to exist. She studied at Shiz. She loved. She learned. But the eighth Binding—Witness—trapped her: she existed only because she remained unseen. True witnessing would shatter her.

She spent centuries trying to break free:

  • First ritual (Year 347): Tried to become truly alive by consuming memories
  • Second ritual (Year 523): Tried to become truly dead through sacrifice
  • Third through seventh rituals: Failed attempts at transcendence
  • Eighth ritual (Year 954): The Witch's Wake—her final attempt

She is not evil by nature. She is what happens when an unintended existence desperately tries to become real—or to finally end.
