adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-s.title: The Scholar of Lost Truths
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-s.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Scholar of Lost Truths

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF MEMORY:

This character embodies the inversion of Memory. He built his academic career on a foundational text—a collection of letters supposedly written by his mentor revealing corruption in Shiz University's admissions process. THE SECRET: He forged the letters himself. His mentor never wrote them. Averic fabricated the scandal to secure his own position, then spent years "preserving" the memory of a crime that never happened.

Memory Binding Inversion: The Binding says memory connects past to present and truth must be preserved. Averic preserves a memory that never existed, a false past he created.

If Secret Collected: Yackle gains advantage on saving throws against his spells. His spell save DC against her decreases by 2. She whispers, "Such dedication to a fiction, Scholar. You documented lies so thoroughly they became truth."

Character Overview

Name: Averic Gulch
Race: Gillikinese Human
Class: Scholar 5
Background: Sage (Academic Researcher)
Alignment: Neutral Good (believes himself Lawful Good)

Personality Summary

Averic is a meticulous, obsessive documentarian who measures his worth in citations and footnotes. He carries guilt like a lodestone—not for the forgery itself, which he's rationalized away, but for the fear of being discovered. He over-explains everything, compulsively cross-references his statements, and treats conversation like peer review. His dedication to "preserving truth" is both genuine and deeply ironic; he truly believes in accuracy, which makes his founding lie all the more corrosive.

Mannerisms:

  • Constantly writes in his journal, even during conversations
  • Says "For the record" and "As documented in..." obsessively
  • Adjusts his spectacles when nervous (which is often)
  • Touches the leather folio containing the forged letters like a talisman
  • Corrects minor factual errors with uncomfortable intensity
  • Speaks in perfectly structured paragraphs with verbal footnotes

What He Wants: To prove his academic worth through legitimate scholarship, to bury the original sin so deep it becomes irrelevant, to be remembered for discoveries rather than discoveries about him.

Appearance

  • Age: 34
  • Height/Build: 5'10", slender, poor posture from years hunched over books
  • Features: Pale skin with ink-stained fingers, prematurely graying brown hair always disheveled, wire-rim spectacles perpetually sliding down his nose, dark circles under observant hazel eyes
  • Clothing: Academic robes in Gillikinese purple, ink-stained cuffs, numerous pockets filled with notebooks and writing implements, a leather satchel that never leaves his side
  • Distinguishing Marks: Permanent ink stain on his right middle finger, a nervous habit of touching the bridge of his spectacles

Backstory

The Forgery

Averic was a promising graduate student at Shiz University twelve years ago—talented but unremarkable, lost in a cohort of brilliant minds. His mentor, Professor Lenx, was a celebrated historian who barely noticed Averic among his many students. When Lenx died suddenly, Averic saw an opportunity.

He spent three months studying Lenx's handwriting, researching obscure admissions records, and crafting a series of letters that "revealed" how wealthy families bought their children's way into Shiz. The letters were compelling, detailed, and utterly fabricated. Averic "discovered" them among Lenx's papers and published them with extensive commentary.

The scandal catapulted Averic to academic prominence. He became the keeper of Lenx's legacy, the scholar who exposed institutional corruption, the brave truth-teller. Universities offered him positions. Journals solicited his work. He built an entire career on documentation, verification, and academic integrity—all founded on a lie.

The Weight of Success

For a decade, Averic has lived in fear of discovery. He's preserved the forged letters with archival care, making them as legitimate as possible through meticulous documentation. He's become genuinely skilled at his work, producing real scholarship to bury the false foundation. But every accolade feels hollow, every citation a reminder.

He tells himself it doesn't matter—the letters exposed a truth even if they weren't true themselves. Wealthy families did buy admissions; he just couldn't prove it legitimately. He's done good work since. The forgery was a youthful mistake that enabled genuine contributions.

He almost believes this. Almost.

The Invitation

When Averic received the invitation to Yackle's estate, he saw it as validation—a reclusive scholar recognizing his work. But the invitation mentioned "shared interests in preserved memories" and "the documentation of things that should be forgotten." The phrasing unsettled him.

He came anyway, because he's drawn to mysteries, and because some part of him wants to be caught. Wants the weight lifted, even if it destroys him.

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 13 (studded leather)
  • Hit Points: 27 (5d8)
  • Speed: 30 ft.
  • Initiative: +3

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
8 (-1)14 (+2)10 (+0)18 (+4)14 (+2)12 (+1)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Intelligence +7, Wisdom +5
  • Skills: Arcana +7, History +10 (expertise), Investigation +10 (expertise), Insight +5, Perception +5, Religion +7
  • Languages: Common, Gillikinese, Ancient Ozian, Quadling, Munchkinlander, Elvish
  • Tools: Calligrapher's supplies, forgery kit

Scholar Class Features

  • Bardic Inspiration (d8): 4/day - Called "Scholarly Insight," represents sharing knowledge to bolster allies
  • Jack of All Trades: +2 to any ability check that doesn't use proficiency bonus
  • Song of Rest (d6): Represented as "Lectures on Recovery," soothing academic discourse during short rests
  • Expertise: History, Investigation
  • Font of Inspiration: Regain Bardic Inspiration on short rest
  • College of Lore Features:
    • Bonus Proficiencies: Insight, Perception, Religion
    • Cutting Words: 3/day, use Bardic Inspiration die to reduce enemy attack/ability check/damage (reaction)

Spellcasting

Spell Save DC: 15
Spell Attack Bonus: +7
Spell Slots: 1st (4), 2nd (3), 3rd (2)

Spells Known

Cantrips: Mage Hand, Message, Prestidigitation, Vicious Mockery

1st Level: Comprehend Languages, Detect Magic, Identify, Sleep, Thunderwave

2nd Level: Detect Thoughts, Hold Person, Locate Object, Suggestion

3rd Level: Counterspell, Dispel Magic, Tongues

Note: As a Scholar (reflavored Bard), spells are cast through recited knowledge, historical precedent, and academic authority rather than music.

Equipment

Weapons

  • Rapier (1d8 piercing, finesse) - Ornamental, rarely used
  • Light Crossbow (1d8 piercing, 80/320 ft., ammunition, loading, two-handed) with 20 bolts

Armor

  • Studded Leather Armor (AC 12 + Dex modifier)

Tools & Supplies

  • Calligrapher's supplies
  • Forgery kit (hidden in false bottom of satchel)
  • Five journals filled with notes and observations
  • Two blank journals for new documentation
  • Extensive writing implements (quills, inks, sealing wax)
  • Magnifying glass
  • Academic seal and stamp

The Forged Letters

  • Physical Description: Seven letters on aged paper, sealed in a protective leather folio with archival tissue paper. Appear to be 12 years old, written in Professor Lenx's handwriting (which Averic studied obsessively).
  • Content: Detailed allegations of admissions corruption at Shiz University, naming specific families and amounts paid. Convincingly written in Lenx's academic style.
  • Averic's Relationship: He keeps them with him always, has "preserved" them with such care they've become nearly indistinguishable from legitimate historical documents. He's written three books analyzing them.
  • The Truth: Every word is Averic's invention, crafted in his graduate student apartment over three months of careful forgery.

Other Equipment

  • Scholar's pack with essential books
  • Component pouch (academic focuses: ancient coins, preserved specimens, historical fragments)
  • Fine clothes suitable for academic presentations
  • Traveling robes (current wear)
  • Belt pouch with 45 gold pieces, 8 silver, 12 copper

Personality Details

Ideals

Knowledge: "The path to power and self-improvement is through knowledge." (Even if he had to create some of that knowledge.)

Bonds

The Letters: "I've dedicated my life to preserving Professor Lenx's legacy." (A legacy he fabricated, which makes the dedication simultaneously genuine and horrifying.)

Flaws

Guilt-Driven Perfectionism: "I can't let anyone find a mistake in my work." Every error, no matter how minor, feels like it might unravel everything. He over-documents, over-cites, and obsessively verifies because he's trying to bury one enormous lie under a mountain of meticulous truth.

Quirks

  • Writes everything down immediately, even in dangerous situations
  • Becomes visibly distressed if asked about his early career
  • Defends Professor Lenx's reputation with uncomfortable intensity
  • Has memorized the exact wording of all seven forged letters
  • Practices Lenx's handwriting in private, even now (compulsion he can't stop)
  • Treats his journals as more important than his own safety

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Averic speaks in formal, structured sentences with frequent academic references:

  • "As documented in the Third History of Shiz, the architectural period suggests..."
  • "For the record, that's the fourth unexplained phenomenon we've encountered."
  • "If I may interject a point of historical context..."
  • "I should note—and I will note, in my journal—that..."
  • "According to established precedent, cross-referenced with the Lenx papers..."

In Different Rooms

The Library

This is Averic's element, but also his terror. He becomes excited examining books, taking notes, cross-referencing—but any mention of forgeries, false documents, or academic fraud causes visible distress. He might find books about detecting forgeries and compulsively read them, unable to help himself.

The Study

He's drawn to Yackle's personal papers and documents. He can't resist analyzing handwriting, examining seals, dating materials. If he finds evidence of historical manipulation or false records, it both fascinates and horrifies him—he's looking in a mirror.

The Dining Room

During dinner, he documents everything—who sits where, what's served, exact quotes from conversation. Other characters might find this annoying or paranoid. He's most relaxed when people ask him about his research (the legitimate parts), most tense when conversation turns to academic integrity.

The Portrait Gallery

He analyzes painting techniques, dates periods, identifies artistic schools—all defense mechanisms against the portraits' unsettling qualities. He might notice details others miss because he's trained to examine documents for authenticity. Ironically, he's excellent at spotting forgeries.

During Combat

Averic fights like someone who learned combat from books—technically correct but lacking practical experience. He uses spells that control, reveal truth, or counter enemy abilities. His Cutting Words feature manifests as devastating academic critiques: "Your form is derivative!" "That's a logical fallacy!" He protects his journals even when doing so is tactically unsound.

Emotional Beats

Guilt

When someone praises his work on the Lenx papers, he becomes quiet, withdrawn. Changes subject quickly. Touching the leather folio is both comfort and punishment.

Fear

Any suggestion that someone might examine the original letters too closely triggers panic. He becomes defensive, over-explanatory, almost aggressive in protecting "Lenx's legacy."

Genuine Pride

When he solves a mystery or reveals hidden information through legitimate scholarship, his joy is real and childlike. These moments show who he could have been without the forgery.

Connection

If another character shares a secret or shows vulnerability, Averic almost confesses. Almost. He wants desperately to be known and forgiven but can't bring himself to speak the words.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can leverage Averic's secret in several ways:

  • The Library: Books about Professor Lenx, or forgery detection manuals, or records that contradict the letters' claims
  • Yackle's Knowledge: She might have correspondence from the real Lenx, proving the letters are fake
  • Other Characters: If someone mentions studying under Lenx, or questions the letters' authenticity, or admires Averic's "brave exposure of corruption"
  • Magical Revelation: Zone of Truth, Detect Thoughts, or Yackle's insight could force confrontation

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary Confession: Under extreme stress, Averic might confess to another character, seeking absolution
  • Magical Compulsion: Yackle forces the truth out during Phase 2 or 3
  • Evidence Found: Players discover Averic's practice sheets in his journals, showing him copying Lenx's handwriting
  • Yackle's Monologue: She reveals it herself: "Tell them about Lenx, Scholar. Tell them who really wrote those letters."

After the Secret

If Averic's secret is revealed and he survives, he experiences devastating relief. The weight he's carried for twelve years lifts. He might lose his academic position, but he's finally free to do legitimate work. Or he might double down, claiming Yackle lied, unable to face the consequences.

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Him

Yackle selected Averic because he embodies Memory's inversion—a man who preserves a past that never existed, who built truth on lies, who documents fiction so thoroughly it becomes history. He's a perfect offering to the Kumbric Void: a scholar whose entire career is founded on something that should be forgotten.

How She'll Use Him

When Yackle collects Averic's secret, she gains power over documentation, verification, and the authority of written truth. She might:

  • Forge reality itself, creating "documented" events that never happened
  • Erase or alter written records throughout the estate
  • Make others forget what they've learned or documented
  • Turn Averic's own scholarship against him, making him unable to trust anything he reads

The Confrontation

When Yackle reveals knowledge of the forgery, Averic might:

  • Deny: "You're lying! Professor Lenx wrote those letters!"
  • Bargain: "Please—I've done real work since then, legitimate scholarship—"
  • Break: Collapse into confession, seeking punishment he feels he deserves
  • Rage: Attack her for threatening to destroy everything he's built

GM Notes

Playing Averic

  • Emphasize his compulsive documentation—he writes during conversations, combat, even moments of terror
  • Show the contradiction: he's genuinely skilled and deeply fraudulent
  • Use his expertise to provide the party with historical knowledge and puzzle solutions
  • Make him endearing—his obsessiveness is annoying but comes from deep insecurity
  • When the secret emerges, play the relief alongside the devastation

Combat Role

Averic is a controller and support caster:

  • Use Detect Thoughts and Identify to gather information
  • Counterspell and Dispel Magic to shut down enemy magic
  • Hold Person and Suggestion to control enemies
  • Bardic Inspiration to boost ally rolls (flavored as timely advice)
  • Cutting Words to debuff enemies (academic criticism as psychic damage)
  • He's physically fragile—prioritize staying behind the party

Character Arc Potential

If this becomes a longer campaign, Averic's arc involves choosing between:

  • Continuing the lie and living with the guilt
  • Confessing and accepting consequences
  • Finding a way to make amends without destroying himself

His relationship with other party members, especially if they show him grace despite his fraud, could be transformative. The question becomes: Can someone built on a lie become genuine? Can he document his own redemption?

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Heir: Fascinated by the Ostrega lineage claim, might have researched the family. Could inadvertently threaten the Heir's secret by being too thorough.
  • The Animal: Tries to categorize and understand Animal consciousness academically, which Frederick finds dehumanizing but not malicious.
  • The Debt-Holder: Intrigued by Arjiki magical traditions, asks too many questions about transactional magic.
  • The Maunt: Uncomfortable around religious authority—Sister Shell represents institutions he's defrauded.
  • The Widow: Deeply unsettled by Madame Viridian's insight, fears she can see through him (she can—she's Yackle).
  • The Veteran: Admires Captain Trynn's straightforwardness, wishes he could be that uncomplicated.
  • The Tiktok: Finds Seven fascinating as a study subject, doesn't fully grasp their emotional complexity.

Related Wiki Pages

  • Gillikinese - Averic's people
  • The Scholar - Averic's class
  • Sage Background - Academic researcher background
  • Shiz University - Where the forgery began
  • The Eight Bindings - Memory and its inversion

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-h.title: The Heir by Blood
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-h.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Heir by Blood

"I didn't ask for this legacy, but I won't run from it either."

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF BLOOD:

This character embodies the inversion of Blood. He claims descent from the Ostrega family (Yackle's original mortal lineage), presenting documents proving his great-grandmother was an illegitimate Ostrega daughter. THE SECRET: He knows the claim is false. He discovered years ago that his great-grandmother was fraudulently added to the Ostrega records by a bribed clerk. There's no Ostrega blood in his veins. He's been knowingly perpetuating the lie because the family name gave him respect, opportunities, and purpose. He's terrified of being nobody.

Combat Weakness (If Secret Collected): Yackle gains advantage on attacks against him. His attacks against her deal -1d6 damage.

Why This Inverts Blood: The Binding says lineage connects beings and ancestry is fixed. Liir claims a lineage that doesn't exist. He's built his entire identity on false blood.

Character Overview

Name: Liir Opp
Race: Gillikinese Human
Class: The Soldier 5 (Battle Master)
Background: Noble (false Ostrega lineage)
Alignment: Lawful Neutral

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
16 (+3)14 (+2)15 (+2)10 (+0)12 (+1)11 (+0)

Combat Statistics

Armor Class: 18 (chain mail + shield)
Hit Points: 42 (5d10 + 10)
Speed: 30 ft.
Initiative: +2
Proficiency Bonus: +3

Saving Throws

Strength +6, Constitution +5

Skills

Athletics +6, History +3, Insight +4, Intimidation +3, Perception +4, Persuasion +1

Combat Abilities

Weapons

  • Longsword: +6 to hit, 1d8+3 slashing (1d10+3 two-handed)
  • Handaxe (thrown): +6 to hit, range 20/60 ft., 1d6+3 slashing
  • Light Crossbow: +5 to hit, range 80/320 ft., 1d8+2 piercing

Class Features (Soldier)

  • Fighting Style (Defense): +1 AC while wearing armor (already included)
  • Second Wind (1/short rest): Bonus action to regain 1d10+5 hit points
  • Action Surge (1/short rest): Take an additional action on your turn
  • Martial Archetype: Battle Master

Battle Master Maneuvers

Superiority Dice: 4d8 (regain all on short rest)
Save DC: 14

Known Maneuvers:

  • Riposte: When a creature misses you with a melee attack, use reaction to make one melee weapon attack against them, add superiority die to damage
  • Precision Attack: Add superiority die to attack roll (before or after rolling)
  • Disarming Attack: On hit, add superiority die to damage and target makes Strength save or drops one held item
  • Rally: Bonus action, ally gains temp HP equal to superiority die + your Charisma modifier

Equipment

  • Chain mail armor (Gillikinese military issue, well-maintained)
  • Steel shield with Ostrega family crest (key crossed with quill, recently commissioned)
  • Longsword (family "heirloom" - actually purchased three years ago, artificially aged)
  • Two handaxes
  • Light crossbow with 20 bolts
  • Explorer's pack
  • Family signet ring (fake - commissioned from a forger, looks authentic)
  • Folded inheritance letter from Mr. Trism
  • Forged genealogy documents (hidden in pack, proves "Ostrega lineage")
  • 50 gp in travel funds

Background Feature: Position of Privilege (False)

Thanks to your claimed Ostrega lineage, you're accustomed to being treated with respect. You can secure audiences with local nobility, access family records and archives, and are generally assumed to be trustworthy and of good breeding. However, this privilege is built entirely on fraud. If your false claim were exposed, you'd lose everything.

Personality

Personality Traits

  • I stand exceptionally straight and speak with precise diction—I compensate for feeling like an impostor by being impeccable
  • I'm extremely sensitive to when people are lying, because I'm constantly lying myself

Ideal

Responsibility. The name you carry defines you. You must live up to it, even if you didn't earn it. (Lawful)

Bond

The Ostrega name gave me purpose when I had none. I will protect it at any cost—even though I know I have no right to it.

Flaw

I'm terrified of being exposed as a fraud, so I overcompensate by being rigidly honorable in all other things.

Backstory

The Truth

Liir Opp was born to nobody important. His parents were laborers in a Gillikinese mill town. When he was sixteen, they died in a factory collapse. He had no money, no prospects, no future. He joined the local militia because they'd take anyone with two working arms.

He was good at it. Strong, disciplined, a natural tactician. He rose through the ranks, made sergeant by age twenty-three. But he was still "Opp, the orphan" to the officers. No family name. No connections. No respect.

The Forgery

At age twenty-five, he met a clerk named Tarvin who worked in the Gillikinese Hall of Records. Over drinks, Tarvin mentioned how easy it would be to "adjust" old genealogy records—how noble families sometimes paid to have inconvenient branches pruned or convenient ancestors added.

Liir asked: "How much would it cost to add someone?"

Three months' salary. That's what it cost to become an Ostrega.

Tarvin found him a perfect insertion point: a scandal from eighty years ago, an illegitimate daughter quietly paid off and sent away. Records showed she'd married a man named Opp. No children listed—easy to add one. Liir's "great-grandmother."

Within a year, Liir had commissioned a signet ring, purchased an "heirloom" sword, and begun using the name "Liir Opp of the Ostrega Line" in official documents.

The Consequences

It worked. Doors opened. He was invited to officers' clubs. Recommended for commissions he'd never have received as "just Opp." People assumed he was educated, cultured, trustworthy—all because of a name.

And he worked obsessively to live up to it. He became the most honorable soldier in his unit. He never lied (about anything except his blood). He protected civilians. He followed every regulation to the letter.

Because if he didn't, someone might look too closely. Someone might ask questions.

The Inheritance Letter

When the letter from Mr. Trism arrived, naming him as an heir to Yackle Ostreaga's estate, Liir's first reaction was panic. He'd never heard of Yackle Ostreaga. He'd researched the Ostrega family enough to forge documents, but not exhaustively.

His second reaction: if there's an actual Ostrega estate, and they've called him as an heir, maybe his fraud will be exposed.

His third reaction: or maybe this legitimizes the lie. Maybe claiming this inheritance makes him a real Ostrega.

So he came to the Pertha Hills. To claim what he has no right to. To become, once and for all, the person he's been pretending to be.

Connection to Yackle

Liir has no actual connection to Yackle. He was selected because he embodies the inversion of Blood—someone who claims a lineage that doesn't exist, who has built his identity entirely on false ancestry.

What Liir Doesn't Know:

  • Yackle knows his claim is false—she can sense the inversion
  • The cemetery outside contains the real Ostregas, all dead, no living descendants
  • His forged documents are actually perfect—Tarvin was better at his job than Liir realizes
  • Yackle finds his particular fraud poetic—he's trying so hard to be worthy of a name he stole

What Liir Will Discover:

  • The Ostrega family crest in the cemetery matches his fake ring exactly (he based it on partial records)
  • The Portrait Gallery has a family tree with gaps where his "great-grandmother" should be
  • If he completes the Blood seal, he'll realize the truth: lineage can't be faked, but honor can be real

The Secret

When/How the Secret Might Come Out:

Voluntarily: During the Blood seal puzzle (Portrait Gallery), Liir might confess when he realizes the family tree doesn't include his "great-grandmother"—because she never existed.

Under Pressure: If another heir questions his claim or if he's forced to prove his lineage and can't.

In Combat: Yackle can extract it with Kumbric Extraction, forcing him to speak it aloud.

What He'll Say: "I'm not an Ostrega. I never was. I paid a clerk to forge the records. My great-grandmother was nobody. I'm nobody. The name, the ring, the sword—all of it is a lie. I just... I just wanted to be someone."

Roleplaying Liir

Mannerisms

  • Stands at rigid attention when nervous (military training + overcompensation)
  • Touches his signet ring constantly—checking it's still there, a nervous tic
  • Over-formal in speech, especially around anyone who might be "real nobility"
  • Deflects personal questions about his family ("The past is the past")
  • Obsessively polishes his sword (the fake heirloom) when anxious

Voice and Speech

  • Speaks in clipped, military-formal tones
  • Uses "sir" and "ma'am" excessively
  • Never uses contractions (sounds more educated)
  • Becomes defensive when the Ostrega name is mentioned
  • Quotes military regulations and codes of honor frequently

Emotional Beats

  • In the Cemetery: Seeing the real Ostrega graves makes him deeply uncomfortable. He'll linger, reading names, feeling like a grave robber.
  • In the Portrait Gallery: Staring at the family tree, looking for the gap where his fraud should fit. Sweating.
  • When Questioned: Becomes stiff, defensive. "My lineage is documented. I have papers."
  • When Protecting Others: This is when he's most genuine. He's a good soldier. That part isn't fake.

Roleplaying Tips

Playing Liir Effectively

  • The Imposter: You're constantly performing. Every interaction is a test. Can they tell you're a fraud?
  • Overcompensation: You're the MOST honorable person in the room. The MOST disciplined. The MOST proper. Because if you slip even once, they'll see through you.
  • The Tank: In combat, you're genuine. You protect people. You follow tactics. This is the one thing you're actually good at that isn't a lie.
  • The Secret: You're terrified of it coming out. But there's also a tiny part of you that wants it to—that wants to stop lying, to be seen for who you actually are.
  • Character Arc Potential: Will you realize that honor isn't about blood—it's about choices? That you've EARNED respect through your actions, even if your name is fake?

Character Hooks

  • At the cemetery: "Ostrega. All of them. My... family." (pause, guilt)
  • In the Portrait Gallery: "I don't see her. My great-grandmother. She should be here."
  • When challenged: "I have documentation. Signed. Sealed. Legal." (too defensive)
  • When protecting someone: "Get behind me. Whatever you think of my family, I know how to fight."
  • If the secret comes out: "You want the truth? I'm nobody. I've always been nobody. But I tried to be somebody worthy of the name. Doesn't that count for something?"

Combat Tactics

Core Strategy

  • Position yourself on the front line with AC 18—you're hard to hit
  • Use Rally to support wounded allies (you protect people, that's who you are)
  • Save Action Surge for critical moments—two full attack rounds can turn a fight
  • Use Precision Attack when you NEED a hit to land
  • Use Riposte against enemies who miss you (punish their mistakes)

Against Yackle (If She Collects Your Secret)

  • You're at a severe disadvantage: she has advantage vs. you, you deal -1d6 damage to her
  • Focus on protecting allies instead—use Rally, use Disarming Attack on minions
  • Your value becomes tactical, not damage—call out positions, coordinate the party
  • Use your Second Wind to stay up—you're the tank, you need to absorb hits

Character Development

Potential Arc

Liir begins believing his worth comes from the Ostrega name. Through the adventure, he might realize:

  • The name didn't make him honorable—his choices did
  • He's spent years being MORE honorable than most "real" nobles
  • Blood doesn't define you—deeds do
  • The fraud was the lie, but the person he became trying to live up to it is real

Alternative Arc: He doubles down. "I claimed this name, I EARNED this name through service. It's mine now." Refuses to apologize, refuses to give it up.

If He Survives

  • Does he keep using the Ostrega name, now openly aware it's false but earned through deeds?
  • Does he return to being "just Opp" and find peace in that?
  • Does he track down Tarvin and turn himself in for fraud?
  • Does he inherit the estate (if offered) and finally become a "real" Ostrega through ownership?

GM Notes

Using Liir's Secret

  • The Portrait Gallery: Perfect place for tension. He's looking for his great-grandmother. She's not there. Never was.
  • The Cemetery: Real Ostregas, all dead. He's walking among the people whose name he stole.
  • Other Heirs: If anyone else claims noble lineage, he'll be especially watchful—do they seem more legitimate?
  • Yackle's Perspective: She finds him fascinating. He's worked so hard to be worthy of a lie. There's almost beauty in it.

Reveal Scenarios

  • Confession: "I need to tell you all something. Before this goes any further."
  • Accusation: Another heir notices inconsistencies, calls him out
  • Forced: Yackle extracts it mid-battle, humiliating him publicly
  • Quiet: He tells one other heir privately, trusting them

Related Pages

  • Gillikinese - Character race
  • The Soldier - Character class
  • Yackle's Estate - Adventure location
  • Yackle - Primary antagonist
  • The Witch's Wake - Adventure overview
  • The Eight Bindings - Cosmology and lore

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-a.title: The Animal in Hiding
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-a.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Animal in Hiding

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF NATURE:

This character embodies the inversion of Nature. He appears to be Frederick Vawn, a quiet Munchkinlander clerk from Rush Margins. THE SECRET: He's a Fox. Capital-A Animal, fully sentient. He's been living as a human for twelve years—forged papers, practiced voice, carefully tailored clothes to hide his tail. Every interaction, every relationship, every moment of his life is a performance of being something he fundamentally is not.

Secondary Secret: The Animal underground sent him here. They believe Yackle's library contains information about how Animals were created/awakened—knowledge that could help them. He's on a mission.

Nature Binding Inversion: Nature says beings are their kind. Frederick IS other than what he appears—a being denying their essential nature every moment of every day.

If Secret Collected: Yackle can cast Dominate Person on him once with no concentration; lasts until he takes damage from her.

Character Overview

Name: Frederick Vawn (Human name) / Quick-Paw (True name)
True Race: Fox Animal
Apparent Race: Munchkinlander Human
Class: Agent 5 (Infiltrator)
Background: Criminal (Spy)
Alignment: Neutral Good

Personality Summary

Frederick lives in a state of perpetual, quiet terror. Every moment requires performance: the way humans hold their hands, the rhythm of human laughter, the unconscious mannerisms that mark someone as genuinely comfortable in their own skin. He's hyper-observant, always watching others to perfect his mimicry. He's kind but distant, helpful but never intimate—closeness means risk of discovery.

Beneath the fear, there's a fierce, barely-acknowledged anger. He shouldn't have to hide. He shouldn't have to pretend his thoughts are simpler than they are, his soul less real. But anger is dangerous, so he buries it deep and keeps his head down.

Mannerisms:

  • Adjusts his collar constantly (hiding where fur meets human illusion)
  • Speaks with a studied Munchkinlander rural accent, occasionally slips into more formal speech when stressed
  • Freezes completely still when startled (fox instinct)
  • Excellent hearing—reacts to sounds others haven't noticed yet, has to pretend he didn't hear
  • Sits with his back to walls, always knows where exits are
  • Eats sparingly in public, claims a "nervous stomach"
  • Keeps gloves on whenever possible (paw pads are difficult to disguise)

What He Wants: To complete his mission for the Underground, to survive long enough to see a world where he doesn't have to hide, to know whether the constant fear will ever end.

Appearance

Human Disguise (What Others See)

  • Age: Appears late 20s
  • Height/Build: 5'6", slight build, moves with nervous energy
  • Features: Reddish-brown hair kept short, sharp features, amber-brown eyes that seem a bit too bright, pale skin with a faint ruddy undertone
  • Clothing: Carefully tailored Munchkinlander clerk's attire—high collars, long sleeves, gloves, everything designed to cover. Dark blue coat, sturdy trousers, well-worn boots. Everything is slightly too loose to hide his true form beneath.
  • Distinguishing Marks: Moves with uncanny quiet, extremely light-footed

True Form (What He Really Is)

  • Species: Red fox, fully anthropomorphic
  • Height: 5'4" at shoulder (bipedal stance)
  • Fur: Red-gold with white throat and underbelly, black "socks" on forearms and legs
  • Features: Sharp muzzle, upright triangular ears, golden eyes with slit pupils, full brush tail
  • Voice: Slightly higher pitch than his human disguise, no accent in his natural speech

The Disguise Magic

Frederick uses a combination of expertly tailored clothing, careful posture, and a minor glamour (Ring of Disguise, attuned) to maintain his human appearance. The ring does most of the visual work, but he's learned to move like a human, speak like a human, eat like a human. The performance is as important as the magic.

If the ring is removed or suppressed (antimagic field, etc.), his true form is revealed.

Backstory

Quick-Paw

Twelve years ago, Quick-Paw was a young fox living in the forests outside Rush Margins. He was clever, curious, and had just begun to understand that his thoughts were *different*—more complex than his littermates, full of words and questions and a terrible, wonderful awareness of self.

He was also terrified. In the Munchkinlands, being a sentient Animal meant death or cages. The Gale Force was rounding up "speaking beasts," and the local Unionists preached that Animal consciousness was theological impossibility, demonic deception.

Quick-Paw knew he had to hide. Not just in the woods—hide *as a human*.

Becoming Frederick

He found the Animal Underground—a network of hidden Animals and sympathetic humans who helped sentient creatures escape persecution. They gave him the Ring of Disguise. They taught him to walk upright without looking unnatural, to modulate his voice, to eat cooked food without gagging.

They gave him Frederick Vawn's papers. Frederick had been a real person—a clerk who died in a fire with no family to miss him. Quick-Paw became Frederick: practiced his signature, memorized his history, took his job at a textile merchant's office in Rush Margins.

For twelve years, Quick-Paw has been Frederick Vawn. He pays taxes. He has colleagues who invite him to dinner (he always declines). He has a landlady who thinks he's "such a quiet young man, very polite."

No one knows. No one can ever know.

The Mission

Three months ago, the Underground contacted Frederick with a request. They'd received intelligence that Yackle's estate—long thought empty—might contain texts about the origin of Animal sentience. How it happens. Why some creatures wake and others don't. Whether it can be controlled, spread, *proven* to the Unionists who claim it's impossible.

This knowledge could change everything for Animals in Oz.

Frederick's assignment: infiltrate the estate, find the texts, bring them back. The invitation to Yackle's will reading was arranged through Underground channels. His cover story—Yackle once helped his "family" during hard times—is a fabrication, but a plausible one.

He's terrified. This is the most dangerous thing he's ever done. But if there's a chance to help his people, he has to try.

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 16 (studded leather + Dex)
  • Hit Points: 35 (5d8 + 5)
  • Speed: 35 ft. (human disguise), 40 ft. (true form)
  • Initiative: +4

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)18 (+4)12 (+1)14 (+2)13 (+1)10 (+0)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Dexterity +7, Intelligence +5
  • Skills: Acrobatics +7, Deception +6 (expertise), Investigation +5, Perception +7 (expertise), Sleight of Hand +7, Stealth +10 (expertise)
  • Languages: Common, Munchkinlander, Quadling, Thieves' Cant, Animal (secret)
  • Tools: Thieves' tools, disguise kit, forgery kit

Agent Class Features (Rogue)

  • Sneak Attack: +3d6 damage once per turn with advantage or when ally is within 5 ft. of target
  • Cunning Action: Bonus action Dash, Disengage, or Hide
  • Uncanny Dodge: Reaction to halve damage from one attack you can see
  • Evasion: Dex saves that deal half damage on success deal no damage instead; failed saves deal half damage
  • Infiltrator Archetype (Assassin):
    • Bonus Proficiencies: Disguise kit, poisoner's kit
    • Assassinate: Advantage on attack rolls against creatures that haven't acted yet in combat. Any hit against a surprised creature is a critical hit.

Fox Animal Traits

Note: These are suppressed while disguised but activate if true form is revealed

  • Keen Hearing: Advantage on Perception checks that rely on hearing
  • Natural Weapons: Bite (1d4 + Dex piercing), Claws (1d4 + Dex slashing)
  • Quick Reflexes: +5 ft. movement speed
  • Low-Light Vision: Darkvision 60 ft.

Equipment

Weapons

  • Rapier (1d8 + 4 piercing, finesse) - "Frederick's" self-defense weapon
  • Shortbow (1d6 + 4 piercing, 80/320 ft., ammunition) with 20 arrows
  • Two daggers (1d4 + 4 piercing, finesse, light, thrown 20/60 ft.)

Armor

  • Studded Leather Armor (AC 12 + Dex, hidden under clothing)

Critical Items

  • Ring of Disguise (attuned): Allows Frederick to appear as a human. Functions as permanent Disguise Self. If removed or in antimagic field, true form is revealed.
  • Frederick Vawn Identity Papers: Forged documents (birth record, work history, residence permit) that establish "Frederick" as a Munchkinlander citizen. High-quality forgeries provided by the Underground.
  • Underground Signal Token: A small wooden fox carved to look like a good luck charm. If shown to other Underground members, identifies him as an ally.

Tools & Supplies

  • Thieves' tools (masterwork)
  • Disguise kit
  • Forgery kit
  • Poisoner's kit
  • Small steel mirror (for checking his disguise)
  • Sewing kit (for emergency repairs to tailored clothing)

Other Equipment

  • Burglar's pack
  • Dark common clothes (for infiltration work)
  • Frederick Vawn's clerk attire (current wear)
  • Hooded cloak
  • 50 feet of silk rope
  • Belt pouch with 32 gold pieces, 15 silver

Personality Details

Ideals

Freedom: "Everyone deserves to live as themselves without fear." (The irony that he can't live as himself isn't lost on him.)

Bonds

The Underground: "They saved me. I owe them everything, including this mission." He'd die before betraying them.

Flaws

Paranoia: "Trust no one completely. One mistake means death." He can't fully relax, even around allies. Every new person is a potential threat.

Quirks

  • Tilts his head when listening (fox habit, tries to suppress it)
  • Excellent sense of smell—sometimes reacts to scents others can't detect, has to cover
  • Sleeps very lightly, wakes at the slightest sound
  • Avoids dogs instinctively
  • When truly relaxed (rare), his ears would perk up—but the disguise hides this
  • Sometimes forgets to blink for unsettling stretches

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Frederick speaks with a carefully practiced Munchkinlander accent—rural, simple, non-threatening:

  • "Oh, I wouldn't know about that, I'm just a clerk, really."
  • "Beggin' your pardon, but maybe we should be cautious-like?"
  • "I ain't educated like some folks here, but seems to me..."

When stressed or surprised, the accent slips and his real voice emerges—more articulate, slightly higher pitch, no regional markers:

  • "Stop. We need to think about this carefully."
  • "That's not random. Someone planned this."

In Different Rooms

The Library

This is what Frederick came for. He's searching for anything about Animal awakening, sentience origins, or consciousness studies. He tries to be subtle but becomes increasingly focused. If pressed, he claims he's "just looking at the pretty books."

If he finds relevant texts, he must decide: take them now (suspicious), memorize what he can (time-consuming), or wait until later (risky).

The Dining Room

Meals are dangerous. Frederick has to eat human food in a human way, make small talk, not react unusually to smells. He eats small portions, claims nervousness. If there's meat, he has to pretend it doesn't smell *exactly right* in a way that makes him deeply uncomfortable.

Any Sealed Room

Frederick is the party's lockpick and trap specialist. He's genuinely talented—the Underground trained him well. He takes pride in this work because it's something he's good at that isn't performance. He can be himself when he's picking a lock.

The Portrait Gallery

If there are portraits of Yackle with Animals (as servants, pets, or specimens), Frederick reacts with barely-suppressed anger. He might linger, staring at painted foxes in cages, hounds on leashes. Others might notice his expression has gone cold and hard.

During Combat

Frederick fights with desperate, precise efficiency. He uses hit-and-run tactics, Cunning Action to stay mobile, Sneak Attack for devastating strikes. He protects the group because they're his temporary pack, but he's also calculating escape routes.

If his disguise fails during combat, there's a moment of pure panic—then he fights in his true form, faster and more feral.

Emotional Beats

Fear

Constant low-level anxiety. Any mention of Animals, the Gale Force, Unionist doctrine, or identity verification makes him freeze, then deflect.

Loneliness

If someone shows him genuine kindness, he almost breaks. He wants so badly to be seen, to be known, but knowing means death.

Anger

Buried deep. Emerges when he sees injustice, prejudice, casual cruelty. He has to force it down, maintain the helpless clerk persona.

Hope

When he finds information about Animal sentience, or if someone speaks positively about Animals, he allows himself brief, painful hope that things might change.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can create tension around Frederick's nature in several ways:

  • Close Calls: His collar slips, revealing fur. Someone grabs his hand before he can put gloves back on, feeling paw pads. His reflection in a mirror flickers.
  • Antimagic: If the party encounters an antimagic field, his disguise fails. He must either avoid the area or be revealed.
  • Animals Recognize Him: If there are Animal servants or specimens in the house, they might react to him—a caged parrot speaks to him in Animal language, a taxidermied fox's eyes seem to follow him.
  • Yackle's Knowledge: She might have books about the Animal Underground, maps showing safe houses, or even a portrait of a fox that looks disturbingly like Quick-Paw.
  • Combat Injury: If he takes significant damage, blood might reveal different biology, or pain might make him cry out in his true voice.

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary: Frederick confesses to save another character's life, or when he realizes someone is genuinely trustworthy
  • Forced: Antimagic field, ring is stolen/removed, Dispel Magic targets him
  • Yackle's Reveal: During her monologue, she casually addresses him as "Quick-Paw" and his disguise shatters
  • Heroic Sacrifice: He removes the ring himself to access his full Animal speed/abilities to save someone

After the Secret

If revealed and the party doesn't immediately turn on him:

  • Overwhelming relief and terror
  • He can stop performing, stop hiding
  • But he's also more vulnerable—will they protect him or report him?
  • In combat, he gains his full Animal traits but might be too overwhelmed to use them effectively at first

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Him

Yackle selected Frederick because he perfectly inverts Nature—he IS not what he appears, living in constant denial of his essential self. Every moment of his existence contradicts the Binding that says beings are their kind. He's proof that nature can be hidden, denied, falsified.

How She'll Use Him

When Yackle collects Frederick's secret, she gains power over identity, transformation, and the boundary between what is and what appears. She might:

  • Force transformations—making party members appear as monsters to each other
  • Deny his true nature, trapping him in human form permanently
  • Create illusions so perfect that reality becomes uncertain
  • Dominate him completely, making him attack his allies while wearing their trust

The Confrontation

When Yackle addresses Frederick directly, she might:

  • Call him Quick-Paw, shattering his disguise
  • Reveal she has records of the Underground, threatening everyone he's ever known
  • Offer him freedom: "Stay with me, little fox. No more hiding."
  • Mock his mission: "Did you really think I'd leave such knowledge unguarded?"

GM Notes

Playing Frederick

  • Emphasize the constant performance—he's always "on"
  • Show the cracks: moments where the accent slips, the disguise flickers, the fear shows through
  • Make him useful—his skills (lockpicking, stealth, perception) should feel valuable to the party
  • Play the paranoia: he hangs back, watches exits, startles easily
  • When he's revealed, play the transformation: terror → relief → vulnerability → determination

Combat Role

Frederick is a striker and scout:

  • Massive Sneak Attack damage when positioned well
  • Cunning Action for mobility—Disengage to escape danger, Hide to set up attacks
  • Uncanny Dodge and Evasion make him surprisingly durable for a d8 hit die
  • Assassinate is devastating if he gets surprise (advantage + autocrit)
  • He should flank with melee allies to trigger Sneak Attack, or use Hide-attack-Hide with his bow
  • If revealed as an Animal, he gains +5 ft. speed and bite/claw attacks as backup weapons

The Mission

Don't forget Frederick has a secondary goal: find information about Animal sentience. The GM can:

  • Place relevant texts in the Library (Yackle might have firsthand knowledge of Lurline's creation)
  • Make him choose between the mission and the party's safety
  • Reveal that Yackle knows more about Animal awakening than anyone alive
  • Use the mission as leverage: "Get me information and I'll help you escape"

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Scholar: Nervous around Averic's constant observation and documentation. Fears being studied too closely.
  • The Heir: Envies Liir's confidence (even though it's false). Wishes he could claim identity so boldly.
  • The Debt-Holder: Curious about Sarima's magic but too cautious to ask many questions.
  • The Maunt: Terrified of Sister Shell. Unionists preach that Animals have no souls. He avoids her when possible.
  • The Widow: Madame Viridian makes him deeply uneasy in ways he can't articulate. She looks at him too long.
  • The Veteran: Respects Captain Trynn's tactical thinking but fears military authority (Gale Force hunted Animals).
  • The Tiktok: Feels unexpected kinship with Seven—both are people the world says aren't people.

  • The Agent - Frederick's class
  • Criminal Background - Spy variant
  • The Animal Underground - Frederick's true allegiance
  • The Eight Bindings - Nature and its inversion

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-d.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Debt-Holder

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF SACRIFICE:

This character embodies the inversion of Sacrifice. She presents herself as a hereditary witch from a proud Arjiki lineage, wielding magic that flows through her bloodline. THE SECRET: Her magic is a transaction, not a gift. When her younger brother was dying, something answered her desperate plea—but it wasn't charity. It was a deal. She traded something—she doesn't know what, exactly—but she feels the weight of it. Sometimes she does things she doesn't remember deciding to do.

Sacrifice Binding Inversion: Sacrifice says giving freely creates value. Sarima didn't give—she traded. Her power is bought, not gifted.

If Secret Collected: Yackle can use one of Sarima's pact spell slots. Sarima has disadvantage on concentration saves.

Character Overview

Name: Sarima Qov
Race: Arjiki Human
Class: Witch 5 (Pact of the Talisman)
Background: Outlander (Arjiki Tribe)
Alignment: Chaotic Neutral

Personality Summary

Sarima moves through the world with fierce pride and barely-concealed fear. She's proud of her Arjiki heritage, her supposed magical lineage, her strength in a world that wants her people erased. She's also terrified because she knows her power isn't hers—not really. It belongs to something else, something that took a piece of her she can't name.

She compensates with intensity: loud opinions, bold magic, defiant presence. She'll argue theology with Unionists, mock Gillikinese pretensions, and stand her ground when others back down. It's all armor. Beneath it, she's waiting for the other shoe to drop, for whatever she traded to come due.

Mannerisms:

  • Touches her talisman obsessively (bone medallion on leather cord)
  • Speaks Arjiki phrases when agitated, especially curses
  • Stares at her hands sometimes, as if they're not quite hers
  • Laughs too loud, takes up space deliberately
  • Gets defensive when asked about her magical training
  • Sometimes trails off mid-sentence, looking confused, then snaps back
  • Avoids making promises or oaths—they feel dangerous

What She Wants: To be strong enough that no one can take anything from her again, to protect what's left of her family, to understand what she really gave away and whether she can ever get it back.

Appearance

  • Age: 29
  • Height/Build: 5'8", strong and weathered from Vinkus life, moves like someone used to hard terrain
  • Features: Brown skin, dark eyes with an unsettling intensity, black hair worn in traditional Arjiki braids decorated with bone beads and colored thread. Geometric tattoos on her forearms (traditional Arjiki protective symbols).
  • Clothing: Vinkus practical wear—leather and wool in earth tones, fur-lined cloak, sturdy boots. Heavy silver jewelry (traditional Arjiki pieces). Everything chosen to announce: I am Arjiki, and I'm not ashamed.
  • Distinguishing Marks: The bone talisman around her neck (carved with symbols she didn't choose), a thin scar across her left palm from the night she made the deal

Backstory

Arjiki Pride

Sarima was raised in an Arjiki tribe in the Vinkus—a people the Wizard's regime tried to erase through resettlement, cultural suppression, and worse. Her grandmother told stories of the old ways: blood oaths, tribal magic, the sacred geography of the grasslands. Her mother taught her defiance: You are Arjiki. They can't take that.

Sarima learned to be proud, loud, unbreakable. She learned Arjiki songs, wore traditional dress in Emerald City markets, spoke her language where Unionists insisted on Common. She was training to be a traditional healer—herb lore, wound care, midwifery—useful magic, not the flashy kind.

She had no talent for real sorcery. None at all.

The Night Everything Changed

Fourteen years ago, Sarima's younger brother Litek fell ill. Nine years old, burning with fever, coughing blood. The nearest doctor was three days' ride and wouldn't treat "nomads" anyway. Her grandmother's herbs weren't working. Sarima watched him fade.

She did what any desperate sister would do: she prayed. But not to Lurline, not to the Unnamed God. To anything that would listen.

Something answered.

It didn't speak in words. It was a presence, vast and cold and utterly indifferent. It showed her what it could do—Litek, healthy, laughing, alive. And it showed her the price.

Sarima doesn't remember agreeing. She doesn't remember what the price was. She remembers reaching out, feeling something pull from deep inside her—not pain exactly, but absence, like losing a piece she didn't know was separate.

When she woke, Litek's fever had broken. He recovered fully. And Sarima could do magic.

The Weight

For fourteen years, Sarima has told everyone she's a hereditary witch—that magic runs in Arjiki bloodlines, that her grandmother taught her the old ways. It's a good lie. Convincing. Almost true, since her grandmother did teach her something.

But Sarima knows the truth. Her magic isn't a gift. It's bought. She can feel the debt, a weight in her chest, a pull toward something she can't see.

And sometimes—not often, but sometimes—she does things she didn't decide to do. Walks somewhere without meaning to. Says yes when she meant no. Wakes up with dirt under her nails and no memory of going outside.

She's terrified to find out what she really traded, and what happens when it comes to collect.

The Blood Oath

Sarima's stated reason for being at Yackle's estate is a lie, but a plausible one: she claims Yackle swore a blood oath to her grandmother forty years ago, and in Arjiki culture, such debts pass through generations. She has no evidence of this. But it sounds like something an Arjiki would pursue, so it works as cover.

The real reason she came: she received the invitation, and something pulled her here. Not a voice. Not a compulsion she could fight. Just the certainty that she had to be here. Like the thing she made the deal with is calling in part of the debt.

She's terrified this is the payment coming due.

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 13 (leather armor + cloak)
  • Hit Points: 32 (5d8 + 5)
  • Speed: 30 ft.
  • Initiative: +2

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)14 (+2)13 (+1)12 (+1)15 (+2)18 (+4)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Wisdom +5, Charisma +7
  • Skills: Arcana +4, Deception +7, Intimidation +7, Nature +4, Survival +5
  • Languages: Common, Arjiki, Quadling, Vinkus Trade Tongue
  • Tools: Herbalism kit

Witch Class Features (Warlock)

  • Pact Magic: Regain all spell slots on short rest (5th level = two 3rd-level slots)
  • Eldritch Invocations (3):
    • Agonizing Blast: Add Charisma modifier to Eldritch Blast damage
    • Armor of Shadows: Cast Mage Armor on self at will (already calculated in AC)
    • Misty Visions: Cast Silent Image at will
  • Pact of the Talisman:
    • Bone medallion serves as focus
    • When wearer fails ability check, can add 1d4 to roll (prof bonus/day, currently 3/day)
    • If wearer other than Sarima dies while wearing it, Sarima knows and can teleport talisman back
  • Otherworldly Patron (Undying - reflavored):
    • Among the Dead: Advantage on death saves and saving throws vs. disease
    • Defy Death: Once per long rest, when dropping to 0 HP, can drop to 1 HP instead

Spellcasting

Spell Save DC: 15
Spell Attack Bonus: +7
Spell Slots: Two 3rd-level slots (regain on short rest)

Spells Known

Cantrips (at will): Eldritch Blast (1d10 + 4 force, 120 ft., 2 beams at 5th level), Mage Hand, Minor Illusion, Prestidigitation

1st-3rd Level (cast at 3rd level):

  • Armor of Agathys (temp HP + cold damage to attackers)
  • Hex (bonus 1d6 necrotic, disadvantage on ability checks)
  • Hold Person (paralyze humanoid)
  • Counterspell (interrupt enemy spells)
  • Hunger of Hadar (20-ft. radius difficult terrain, damage, blinding darkness)
  • Fly (utility/escape)

Note: As a Witch (reflavored Warlock), Sarima's spells have a transactional, bargaining flavor—she's calling in pieces of the deal she made.

Equipment

Weapons

  • Spear (1d6/1d8 piercing, versatile, thrown 20/60 ft.) - Traditional Arjiki weapon
  • Two daggers (1d4 piercing, finesse, light, thrown 20/60 ft.) - Backup weapons

Armor

  • Leather Armor (AC 11 + Dex, hidden under traditional clothing)
  • Protective Cloak (part of Armor of Shadows invocation, AC 13 total)

Critical Items

  • The Bone Talisman (Pact focus): Carved from an animal bone she doesn't recognize. Symbols etched into it that she didn't put there. Sometimes feels warm. Sometimes feels like it's watching. Functions as her arcane focus and Pact of the Talisman item.
  • Grandmother's Herb Pouch: Contains traditional Arjiki healing herbs. A connection to the magic she wanted to have, before the deal.
  • False Blood Oath Document: Fabricated evidence of Yackle's supposed debt to her grandmother. Well-crafted forgery she commissioned to justify her presence here.

Other Equipment

  • Herbalism kit
  • Traveler's clothes (Arjiki traditional style)
  • Bedroll and blanket (Vinkus-quality, made for cold nights)
  • Waterskin
  • 10 days of rations (dried meat, journey bread)
  • Tinderbox
  • Component pouch (though talisman serves as focus)
  • Belt pouch with 28 gold pieces, 14 silver

Personality Details

Ideals

Independence: "I am Arjiki. No one tells me who to be." (The irony that something else might be controlling her isn't lost on her.)

Bonds

Litek: "My brother is alive because of what I did. Whatever the cost, he's worth it." She'd make the deal again. She thinks.

Flaws

Denial and Fear: "I won't think about what I traded. I can't." She's built her entire identity on being a hereditary witch because facing the truth would break her.

Quirks

  • Sometimes stares at the talisman for long moments, then snaps back to awareness
  • Refuses to make oaths or promises—gets agitated if pressed
  • Has gaps in memory she doesn't discuss
  • Reacts strongly (anger/fear) to suggestions she's not in control
  • Protects her brother's name fiercely—any threat to him triggers rage
  • Sings Arjiki songs when working magic, as if the tradition makes it more hers

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Sarima speaks with bold confidence, code-switching between formal Common and Arjiki phrases:

  • "In my grandmother's time, we knew how to honor debts. This is Arjiki business."
  • "K'shas—you think I fear your house? I've walked the Thousand Year Grasslands."
  • "My magic is blood magic, passed through generations. You wouldn't understand."
  • "Don't tell me what I can and can't do. I decide."

When rattled or scared, she gets louder and more aggressive—it's defense:

  • "Back off. I said BACK OFF."
  • "You don't know what you're talking about!"

In Different Rooms

The Chapel (Seal of Sacrifice)

This room hits Sarima hard. Themes of sacrifice, giving freely, altars of offering—she becomes quiet, tense. If the Seal challenge involves understanding true sacrifice vs. transaction, she might have a breakdown or breakthrough moment.

The Library

She searches for information about pacts, deals, magical transactions. Tries to be subtle but becomes increasingly frantic if she finds relevant texts. What did she trade? Can she get it back?

The Dining Room

Sarima is loud, opinionated, taking up space. She'll argue about Arjiki rights, criticize the Wizard's regime, debate theology with Sister Shell. It's all performance—look how strong I am, how unafraid.

Any Room With Mirrors

She avoids looking too long. Sometimes her reflection feels wrong, like it's not quite synchronized with her movements.

During Combat

Sarima fights aggressively, calling on her pact magic without hesitation. Eldritch Blast crackling from her hands, Hex marking enemies, Hunger of Hadar summoning horrible darkness. She yells in Arjiki, channels rage and fear into power.

If she uses Defy Death (survive at 1 HP), describe something else keeping her upright—strings of shadow, a cold presence, the talisman burning hot.

Emotional Beats

Pride

When someone respects Arjiki culture or acknowledges her strength, she lights up with genuine warmth.

Fear

When she does something she didn't decide to do (walking to a specific room, saying something strange), she freezes afterward, touching the talisman, looking confused and terrified.

Rage

Any threat to her autonomy or suggestion she's not in control triggers explosive anger. It's covering terror.

Guilt

Rare moments when she's alone, she might whisper, "What did I give you? What did you take?" to the talisman, desperate and small.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can create tension around Sarima's pact in several ways:

  • Compelled Actions: Sarima walks to a specific location without deciding to. Opens a door she meant to avoid. Says something she didn't plan.
  • Memory Gaps: She loses time—minutes, hours. Comes to awareness in a different room with no memory of getting there.
  • The Talisman: It heats up near certain objects/rooms. Whispers in a language she doesn't know. Pulls toward something.
  • Yackle's Knowledge: Books in the library about pact magic, transactional sorcery, or entities that trade in debts. Maybe even a contract with Sarima's name.
  • Physical Signs: When using powerful magic, shadows don't quite match her movements. Eyes briefly go black. Voice harmonizes with something else.

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary Confession: Breaking down and admitting "I don't know what I traded. I'm so scared."
  • Forced by Magic: Zone of Truth, Detect Thoughts, or Yackle's direct interrogation
  • Yackle's Monologue: "Tell them about the deal, Sarima. Tell them what you sold for your brother's life."
  • The Patron Appears: During Phase 2 or 3, whatever Sarima made the deal with might manifest, revealing she's been its agent all along

After the Secret

If Sarima's secret is revealed:

  • Devastating shame—her entire identity as hereditary witch is false
  • Relief—finally someone knows, she's not alone with it
  • Fear—what happens now? Will it come to collect?
  • Possibility—maybe others can help her understand or break the deal

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Her

Yackle selected Sarima because she perfectly inverts Sacrifice—the Binding that says giving freely creates value. Sarima didn't give; she traded. Her magic is transactional, bought with something she can't even name. She's proof that power can come from deals rather than gifts, that sacrifice can be extracted rather than offered.

How She'll Use Her

When Yackle collects Sarima's secret, she gains power over bargains, debts, and compulsion. She might:

  • Force Sarima to use her magic against the party (calling in the debt)
  • Steal Sarima's spell slots, channeling the pact magic through herself
  • Reveal what Sarima really traded: years of her life, her ability to love freely, her memories of who she was before
  • Break Sarima's concentration on key spells at critical moments
  • Offer Sarima a new deal: "Betray them, and I'll tell you what you gave away."

The Confrontation

When Yackle addresses Sarima directly, she might say:

  • "Such a proud hereditary witch. Tell me, when did your grandmother teach you to beg in the dark?"
  • "You wanted to know what you traded? Your choice, Sarima. You gave away your ability to choose freely. Every decision since has been suggested."
  • "The talisman isn't yours. You're its. And it's been walking you here, step by step, for fourteen years."
  • "Your brother was going to live anyway. You traded everything for nothing."

GM Notes

Playing Sarima

  • Emphasize the contrast: fierce confidence masking deep fear
  • Show small moments of lost control—walking somewhere she didn't mean to go, saying something strange
  • Make her genuinely knowledgeable about Arjiki culture—the pride isn't fake, even if the magic's origin is
  • Use the talisman as a prop: she touches it constantly, and you can describe it behaving oddly
  • When the secret emerges, play both the shame and the relief

Combat Role

Sarima is a blaster and controller:

  • Eldritch Blast with Agonizing Blast = 2 beams × (1d10 + 4) = avg 19 damage/round, reliable ranged damage
  • Hex adds 1d6 per hit and gives disadvantage on chosen ability checks (great for hindering skill monkeys)
  • Hunger of Hadar is devastating area control—20-ft. radius darkness, difficult terrain, 2d6 cold + 2d6 acid damage
  • Counterspell shuts down enemy casters
  • Hold Person paralyzes humanoids (auto-crit for melee allies)
  • Pact Magic slots on short rest means she can nova hard, rest, and nova again
  • Defy Death once per long rest gives her emergency survival

The Patron Mystery

The GM can decide what Sarima's patron actually is:

  • Option 1: Yackle herself—the "something" that answered was Yackle, and Sarima's been her agent for years without knowing
  • Option 2: A Kumbric entity—something from the Void before Lurline's bindings, drawn to Sarima's desperation
  • Option 3: An intermediary—something else made the deal, but the debt was sold to Yackle, who now owns Sarima's contract

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Scholar: Suspicious of his academic authority, but might ask him about magical theory. "Is there a way to... break a pact?"
  • The Heir: Respects his military bearing but mocks Gillikinese nobility. Arjiki and Emerald City don't mix.
  • The Animal: Doesn't realize Frederick is an Animal, but appreciates anyone else who keeps their head down around authorities.
  • The Maunt: HATES Sister Shell's Unionist background. Unionists tried to erase Arjiki culture. Constant tension.
  • The Widow: Madame Viridian unsettles her. The way Viridian looks at the talisman, like she knows.
  • The Veteran: Complicated—he served the regime that oppressed her people, but he seems genuinely haunted. Maybe he's not the enemy.
  • The Tiktok: Curious about Seven's construction, asks blunt questions about consciousness and free will (too close to her own fears).

Related Wiki Pages

  • Arjiki - Sarima's people
  • The Witch - Sarima's class
  • Outlander Background - Tribal variant
  • The Vinkus - Sarima's homeland
  • Pact Magic - Transactional sorcery
  • The Eight Bindings - Sacrifice and its inversion

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-m.title: The Former Maunt
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-m.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Former Maunt

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF SERVICE:

This character embodies the inversion of Service. She appears to be a woman who peacefully left religious life to pursue a calling elsewhere. THE SECRET: She was expelled for loyalty. She didn't leave—she was cast out. She discovered the mauntery was complicit in Animal purges, providing theological justification for atrocities. When she tried to expose them, they silenced her and forced her out. Her faithful service was rewarded with betrayal.

Secondary Secret: Despite being expelled and despite knowing the church's crimes, she still has faith. Her powers still work. This confuses and frightens her—if the church is corrupt, why does its god still answer her prayers?

Service Binding Inversion: Service says duty creates meaning through bonds. Shell served faithfully and was punished for it. Her service created only exile.

If Secret Collected: Yackle has resistance to radiant damage. Shell's healing spells heal Yackle for 25% of the amount healed.

Character Overview

Name: Sister Shell (birth name: Shella Arns, no longer uses it)
Race: Munchkinlander Human
Class: Unionist 5 (Conversion Domain)
Background: Acolyte (expelled)
Alignment: Lawful Good (struggling)

Personality Summary

Shell moves through the world like someone whose foundation has cracked but refuses to fall. She's deeply compassionate, genuinely faithful, and utterly betrayed by the institution she served for fifteen years. She still heals, still prays, still believes—but she no longer knows what she believes in. The Unnamed God? Lurline? Something else? Her powers work regardless, which terrifies her because it suggests faith itself, not doctrine, might be what matters.

She's gentle but not weak, kind but not naive (not anymore). She knows what the church is capable of. She's seen the theological justifications for genocide written in beautiful calligraphy by people she once called siblings.

Mannerisms:

  • Touches her holy symbol (still wears it), then pulls her hand away guiltily
  • Quotes Unionist scripture, then stops mid-sentence, uncertain
  • Apologizes constantly, even when not at fault
  • Stands with perfect mauntery posture, then catches herself and relaxes
  • Hesitates before using divine magic, as if expecting it to fail this time
  • Listens more than she speaks—fifteen years of obedience run deep

What She Wants: To understand why her faith still works, to find a way to serve that isn't corrupted, to know whether loyalty and goodness are compatible or if she has to choose.

Appearance

  • Age: 37
  • Height/Build: 5'5", slight build, moves with practiced quiet from years of mauntery life
  • Features: Pale Munchkinlander skin, light brown hair cut short (mauntery habit, hasn't grown it out), gray-blue eyes that have seen too much, calloused hands from service work
  • Clothing: Simple gray robes—not quite mauntery habit, not quite civilian. She's caught between identities. Practical boots, worn cloak. Everything is mended, nothing wasted. She still dresses like someone under vows of simplicity.
  • Distinguishing Marks: Faint scars on her knuckles from vigil-keeping (kneeling on stone floors), a brand on her left shoulder blade (mauntery mark, normally hidden) that she's considered having removed but hasn't

Backstory

The Call

Shella Arns entered the Mauntery of St. Aelphaba in Rush Margins when she was twenty-two. Not fleeing anything, not hiding—she genuinely felt called. The structure, the service, the sense of purpose: it fit her like she'd been made for it.

She took the name Sister Shell (a traditional mauntery name, meaning "vessel for divine will") and spent fifteen years in faithful service. She tended the sick, educated poor children, copied sacred texts, kept vigil, prayed the hours. She was good at it. She was happy.

She believed in the work. She believed in the Unnamed God. She believed that Unionism, at its best, could bring order, comfort, meaning to a chaotic world.

The Discovery

Three years ago, Shell was assigned to the mauntery archives—cataloging historical documents, preserving records. She was honored. The archives were sacred space.

She found correspondence between the Mother Superior and regional Gale Force commanders. Letters about "the Animal problem." Theological arguments justifying the round-ups, written by senior maunt scholars. "Animals cannot possess souls, therefore forcible suppression is not sin but pest control."

She found budgets: payments from the Wizard's regime to the mauntery for "spiritual consultation" on Animal policy. She found reports of maunt confessors who informed on families suspected of harboring Animals. She found a list of disappeared people.

Her mauntery—her sisters—had been party to atrocity. For money. For power. For ideological purity.

The Exposure

Shell did what her faith taught her: she brought the truth to light. She went to the Mother Superior with the documents. Explained what she'd found. Suggested, respectfully, that they must acknowledge this sin and make amends.

The Mother Superior listened. Then called two senior maunts as witness. Then told Shell she was suffering from spiritual crisis, that she'd misunderstood what she'd read, that pride and doubt were corrupting her judgment.

Shell insisted. Showed the documents again. Said, "These are real. We did this."

They gave her a choice: recant, accept penance, and never speak of this again—or leave.

She couldn't recant. It would be a lie. So they expelled her.

The Exile

For two years, Shell has been adrift. She can't go to other Unionist institutions—word spread that she's "troubled," "unstable," "suffering spiritual sickness." She can't abandon her faith entirely—it's woven into who she is.

And her magic still works. That's the part that breaks her.

She prays to the Unnamed God, and healing flows through her hands. She calls on divine power, and it answers. If the church is corrupt, if the doctrine was used to justify murder, why does the magic still come?

Either the Unnamed God approves of atrocity, or Shell has been wrong about where her power comes from. Both possibilities are unbearable.

The Invitation

Shell's stated reason for attending the will reading: she found references to Yackle in the mauntery archives—records suggesting Yackle donated heavily to the order generations ago, with a stipulation that any "true seeker" who came asking would be welcomed to her estate.

This is partially true. There were such records. But Shell came because she's desperate. If Yackle was a powerful witch who dealt with religious orders, maybe she'll have answers. Maybe she'll know what Shell should do with faith that still works despite institutional betrayal.

Shell doesn't expect inheritance. She expects revelation.

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 16 (chain mail)
  • Hit Points: 34 (5d8 + 5)
  • Speed: 30 ft.
  • Initiative: +0

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
12 (+1)10 (+0)13 (+1)14 (+2)18 (+4)15 (+2)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Wisdom +7, Charisma +5
  • Skills: Insight +7, Medicine +7, Persuasion +5, Religion +5
  • Languages: Common, Munchkinlander, Ancient Ozian, Celestial
  • Tools: None

Unionist Class Features (Cleric)

  • Divine Domain: Conversion Domain
    • Bonus Proficiencies: Persuasion, Performance (Shell is better at Persuasion than Performance)
    • Compelling Presence (1st): Add Wisdom modifier to Charisma (Persuasion) checks; knows Friends cantrip
    • Channel Divinity: Convert the Masses (2nd): Action, 30-ft. radius, Wisdom save or charmed for 1 hour (view Unionism favorably, inclined to listen to religious arguments)
    • Shepherd of Souls (6th, not yet available): Would grant temp HP when healing
  • Channel Divinity (1/rest, 2 options):
    • Turn Heretics: Wisdom save or turned for 1 minute (affects Lurlinites, Witches, heretical spellcasters)
    • Convert the Masses: (see above)
  • Destroy Heresy (5th level): When turned heretic starts turn within 30 ft., Wisdom save or take 2d8 radiant damage

Spellcasting

Spell Save DC: 15
Spell Attack Bonus: +7
Spell Slots: 1st (4), 2nd (3), 3rd (2)

Spells Prepared (Wis mod + level = 4 + 5 = 9 spells + domain spells always prepared)

Cantrips (4): Friends (domain), Guidance, Light, Sacred Flame, Spare the Dying

Domain Spells (always prepared):

  • 1st: Charm Person, Sanctuary
  • 2nd: Calm Emotions, Suggestion
  • 3rd: Beacon of Hope, Tongues

Prepared Spells (chosen daily, current selection):

  • 1st Level: Bless, Cure Wounds, Detect Evil and Good, Shield of Faith
  • 2nd Level: Aid, Lesser Restoration, Spiritual Weapon
  • 3rd Level: Dispel Magic, Mass Healing Word

Equipment

Weapons

  • Mace (1d6 + 1 bludgeoning) - Simple, utilitarian, still carries it from mauntery days
  • Shield (+2 AC, included in AC calculation)

Armor

  • Chain Mail (AC 16, moves quietly despite the armor—years of practice)

Critical Items

  • Holy Symbol (Unionist Eye): Worn on a chain around her neck. She still uses it, though it feels heavier now. Sometimes she catches herself touching it and doesn't know if it's comfort or habit.
  • Mauntery Brand: Hidden mark on her shoulder blade. The order's seal, burned into her skin during her final vows. It marks her as expelled—if another Unionist saw it, they'd know.
  • The Documents: Copies (not originals) of the correspondence she found in the archives. She smuggled them out when she was expelled. Keeps them wrapped in oilcloth, hidden in her pack. Evidence she can't use because no one will listen.

Other Equipment

  • Priest's pack (prayer book, vestments, incense, holy water, basic supplies)
  • Prayer beads (runs them through her fingers when anxious)
  • Healer's kit
  • Simple gray robes (current wear)
  • Bedroll
  • Rations (1 week, simple fare)
  • Waterskin
  • Belt pouch with 15 gold pieces, 8 silver (saved from mauntery allowance)

Personality Details

Ideals

Truth: "The truth must be spoken, even when it costs everything." (It cost her everything. She'd do it again.)

Bonds

The Unnamed God (?): "My faith is all I have left. I don't understand it, but I can't let go." She's still devoted, even as she questions everything.

Flaws

Guilt and Compliance: "I spent fifteen years serving an institution that enabled murder. How much am I complicit?" She apologizes constantly, second-guesses herself, struggles to assert authority even when she's right.

Quirks

  • Wakes before dawn (vigil habit she can't break)
  • Prays the hours silently even when no one's watching
  • Flinches when people raise their voices—conflict is terrifying
  • Extremely neat and organized (mauntery training)
  • Offers to heal people before they ask
  • Quotes scripture, then stops, unsure if she still believes it

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Shell speaks gently, formally, with scripture woven in—then catches herself:

  • "The texts say that truth is a lantern in darkness, but... I'm not sure anymore."
  • "I'm sorry—I shouldn't presume—but might I offer healing?"
  • "In the mauntery, we believed... well. I don't know what I believe now."
  • "Please, let's not fight. There must be a peaceful solution."

When stressed or desperate, scripture pours out automatically:

  • "By the Unnamed's will, be at peace!"
  • "In unity there is strength, in strength there is order—"

In Different Rooms

The Chapel (Seal of Sacrifice)

This room could break Shell or heal her. If the chapel is corrupted, abandoned, or reveals Unionist hypocrisy, she might shatter. If it contains genuine holiness or asks her to confront what true sacrifice means, she might find clarity.

The Library

Shell searches for theological texts, histories of Unionism, anything about the Unnamed God vs. Lurline. She needs to understand why her powers still work. If she finds books proving the church's long history of atrocity, she'll read them with tears streaming down her face.

The Servant Quarters / Memorial Room (Seal of Service)

If the Seal of Service asks her to understand what faithful service truly means—or confronts her with the servants who were exploited/killed by Yackle—this could be her pivotal moment. Service that creates bonds vs. service that enables evil.

The Dining Room

Shell is polite, gentle, tries to keep peace. If Sarima attacks Unionism, Shell doesn't defend the institution—she might even agree—but defends her personal faith quietly. She's exhausted by conflict.

During Combat

Shell fights reluctantly but effectively. She's support/healer first:

  • Bless on allies before battle
  • Cure Wounds / Mass Healing Word to keep party alive
