  • Spiritual Weapon (manifests as a glowing mace) for damage without risk
  • Sacred Flame for ranged attacks when healing isn't needed
  • Uses Shield of Faith on frontliners

Every time she uses divine magic, describe it working—light, warmth, healing—and her brief moment of relief/confusion that it still answers.

Emotional Beats

Faith Crisis

When confronted with religious questions, she becomes very quiet, very still. "I don't know anymore. I don't know."

Healing

When she heals someone, there's genuine joy—this is what faith should be, helping people. It's the one thing she's sure of.

Injustice

If she witnesses cruelty or oppression, something hardens in her. She'll step forward, gentle voice firm: "No. This is wrong."

Validation

If someone tells her she did the right thing by exposing the mauntery, she might cry—she's had no one affirm that choice in two years.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can create tension around Shell's expulsion:

  • The Library: Books about mauntery history, records of collaboration with the regime, theological arguments for Animal persecution
  • Yackle's Knowledge: She might have firsthand knowledge of Unionist corruption, or even correspondence with Shell's Mother Superior
  • Animal Encounters: If the party includes Frederick (the Fox), Shell must decide whether her faith allows for Animal consciousness—her old church said no
  • Physical Evidence: If her mauntery brand is revealed (injury exposes her shoulder), others might ask what it means
  • Magic Crisis: A moment where Shell tries to use divine magic and, for the first time, it fails. Her faith crisis becomes literal.

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary Confession: "I need you to know why I left. I need someone to know it wasn't cowardice."
  • Forced Discovery: Someone finds the documents in her pack
  • Yackle's Monologue: "Tell them about the mauntery, Sister Shell. Tell them what faithful service earned you."
  • Confrontation with Sarima: If the Arjiki woman attacks Unionism, Shell might break and confess, "You're right. You're right about all of it."

After the Secret

If Shell's secret is revealed:

  • Overwhelming relief—finally, someone knows the truth
  • Shame—she should have done more, sooner
  • Validation—if the party supports her decision
  • Renewed purpose—maybe she can serve in a way that matters now

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Her

Yackle selected Shell because she perfectly inverts Service—the Binding that says duty creates meaning through bonds. Shell served faithfully for fifteen years and was betrayed by her order. Her service created no meaning, no bonds, only exile. She's proof that duty can be corrupted, that loyalty can be punished, that service to an institution doesn't guarantee reciprocal care.

How She'll Use Her

When Yackle collects Shell's secret, she gains power over faith, healing, and divine magic. She might:

  • Gain resistance to radiant damage (holy power can't fully harm her)
  • Corrupt Shell's healing—making her spells heal Yackle instead of or in addition to allies
  • Force Shell to witness Animals being tortured, making her complicit again
  • Make Shell choose: heal Yackle to save an ally's life, or let the ally die
  • Reveal that Shell's powers come from Lurline, not the Unnamed God, shattering her remaining faith

The Confrontation

When Yackle addresses Shell directly, she might say:

  • "Such faithful service, Sister. Did your order thank you before they cast you out?"
  • "You still pray to the Unnamed God. Tell me—why does She answer a heretic?"
  • "Your church provided the theology for genocide. And you still wear their symbol. Explain that to me."
  • "You think you're different from them? You wore their robes, spoke their prayers, took their communion for fifteen years. You were them."

GM Notes

Playing Shell

  • Emphasize her gentleness—she's genuinely kind, not performatively
  • Show the contradiction: faithful but faithless, expelled but still devout
  • Make her crisis relatable—what do you do when your institution betrays its ideals?
  • Every use of divine magic should have a moment of "it still works, why does it still work?"
  • Let her be competent in combat despite her doubts—healing is muscle memory

Combat Role

Shell is primary healer and support:

  • Bless gives +1d4 to attacks/saves for 3 allies (entire combat)
  • Cure Wounds heals 1d8 + 4 (avg 8.5 per 1st-level slot)
  • Mass Healing Word heals up to 6 allies for 1d4 + 4 (bonus action, lifesaver)
  • Spiritual Weapon gives bonus action attacks for 1d8 + 4 damage (no concentration)
  • Aid increases max HP by 5 for 3 allies for 8 hours
  • Beacon of Hope gives advantage on Wisdom saves and max healing
  • Shield of Faith grants +2 AC to tank
  • Channel Divinity: Convert the Masses can charm entire enemy groups
  • She can wear heavy armor and use a shield—surprisingly durable for a healer

Faith Questions

The GM can use Shell to explore theological questions:

  • Where does divine magic really come from—the god, the institution, or the faith itself?
  • Can you be faithful to ideals while rejecting the institution?
  • Is complicity through inaction different from active participation?
  • What does it mean if gods answer prayers from the "wrong" people?

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Scholar: Appreciates Averic's dedication to truth and documentation. Might ask him to help verify the documents she carries.
  • The Heir: Treats Liir with gentle respect, doesn't care about his bloodline—service matters, not lineage.
  • The Animal: If Frederick is revealed, Shell faces a crisis—her church says Animals have no souls, but she can SEE his consciousness, his fear, his personhood. Which is true?
  • The Debt-Holder: Tense relationship. Sarima hates Unionists for what they did to her people. Shell agrees with every criticism but can't abandon her faith.
  • The Widow: Madame Viridian asks theological questions that unsettle Shell. "Why does your god still answer, Sister?"
  • The Veteran: Sees Captain Trynn's guilt and wants to offer absolution, but worries she has no authority to grant it.
  • The Tiktok: Deeply curious about Seven's consciousness. If a construct can think and feel, what makes a soul?

Related Wiki Pages

  • Munchkinlander - Shell's people
  • The Unionist - Shell's class
  • Acolyte Background - Religious service
  • Unionism - The faith Shell questions
  • Mauntery of St. Aelphaba - Shell's former home
  • The Eight Bindings - Service and its inversion

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-w.title: Pre-Gen: The Widow
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-w.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Widow

"Loss teaches you to see what others overlook. I've learned to see very well indeed."

⚠️ CRITICAL GM SECRET ⚠️

THE WIDOW IS YACKLE IN DISGUISE.

This character is not a separate person who becomes possessed or controlled. The Widow IS Yackle, wearing a perfect magical disguise and playing the role of a grieving heir. She is testing the other heirs, gathering information, and positioning herself for the ritual.

Do not reveal this to players until the dramatic moment. The player controlling The Widow should play her as written—a melancholic, perceptive widow with strange magical knowledge. The twist will be that "you were the villain all along."

How This Works:

  • The player plays The Widow normally until the reveal
  • The "real" Yackle encountered later is a magical duplicate/illusion
  • When The Widow reveals herself, the player can either:
    • Hand the character to the GM to play as the villain
    • Continue playing Yackle as the BBEG (amazing if the player is into it!)
    • Revert to playing one of the NPC allies or a backup character

Suggested Reveal Moment: When the party confronts "Yackle" in her study and defeats her, The Widow smiles sadly and says, "You really thought it would be that easy?" Then her disguise drops and Phase 2 begins.

Character Overview (As Presented to Players)

Name: Madame Viridian ("Viri" to friends she doesn't have)
Race: Gillikinese
Class: The Adept 5 (Divination)
Background: Palace Servant (former lady-in-waiting)
Alignment: Neutral (secretly Neutral Evil)

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
8 (-1)14 (+2)14 (+2)17 (+3)13 (+1)12 (+1)

Combat Statistics

Armor Class: 12 (15 with mage armor)
Hit Points: 28 (5d6 + 10)
Speed: 30 ft.
Initiative: +2

Proficiency Bonus: +3

Saving Throws

Intelligence +6, Wisdom +4

Skills

Arcana +6, History +6, Insight +7 (expertise), Investigation +6, Perception +4

Spellcasting

Spellcasting Ability: Intelligence (spell save DC 14, +6 to hit with spell attacks)
Spellbook: Contains all prepared spells plus 6 additional spells
Spell Slots: 4 1st-level, 3 2nd-level, 2 3rd-level

Cantrips (at will)

  • Mage Hand - Manipulate objects at range
  • Message - Send whispered messages
  • Minor Illusion - Create sound or image
  • Prestidigitation - Minor magical effects

Prepared Spells (Int modifier + level = 8 spells)

1st Level:

  • Detect Magic (ritual) - Sense magic within 30 ft.
  • Identify (ritual) - Learn properties of magical item
  • Mage Armor - AC 13 + Dex for 8 hours
  • Shield - Reaction, +5 AC until start of your next turn

2nd Level:

  • Detect Thoughts - Read surface thoughts
  • Locate Object - Sense direction to familiar object
  • Misty Step - Teleport 30 ft. as bonus action

3rd Level:

  • Clairvoyance - Create invisible sensor to see/hear distant location
  • Dispel Magic - End magical effects

Divination Specialist Features

  • Divination Savant: Copying divination spells into spellbook costs half time and money
  • Portent (2/day): Roll 2d20 after long rest. Can replace any attack roll, save, or ability check (yours or another creature's) with one of these rolls before rolling. This is Yackle's signature ability—she always knows what's coming.

Equipment

  • Fine black mourning dress (expensive, well-maintained)
  • Spellbook (leather-bound, very old—actually Yackle's personal grimoire in disguise)
  • Crystal pendant (arcane focus—also the anchor for her disguise magic)
  • Widow's veil (black lace, she wears it when she wants to seem fragile)
  • Component pouch
  • Small portrait of "her late husband" (completely fictitious, but the painting is real and quite good)
  • Scholar's pack
  • Inheritance letter (written by herself to herself, amused by the irony)
  • 40 gp

Background Feature: Palace Connections

Madame Viridian claims to have served as a lady-in-waiting to minor Gillikinese nobility before her husband's death. She knows courtly etiquette, can navigate aristocratic social situations, and has (claimed) connections to noble houses. This is partially fabricated—Yackle has been many things over centuries, including actual nobility on several occasions.

The Widow's Cover Story

What The Widow Claims:

  • Born Viridian Chuffrey, married Lord Marcus Viridian at age 20
  • Served in the palace at Emerald City for several years
  • Husband died in a riding accident three years ago (tragic, unexpected, she doesn't like to talk about it)
  • Yackle was her husband's great-aunt (or possibly great-great-aunt, the family tree is complicated)
  • She met Yackle once, briefly, at her wedding—an ancient woman who gave her a crystal pendant and cryptic advice
  • The inheritance letter surprised her; she didn't think Yackle even remembered her

The Truth:

  • All of this is false
  • The Widow is a construct—a persona Yackle created for this specific purpose
  • The crystal pendant is the anchor for her disguise self magic (far more powerful than the standard spell)
  • Every memory, every mannerism, every tear shed for the "late Lord Viridian" is performance
  • Yackle is testing the other heirs by living among them, watching them solve her puzzles, evaluating them as potential vessels or sacrifices

Personality (As Roleplayed)

Personality Traits

  • I notice things others miss—a misplaced book, a nervous glance, a lie poorly told
  • I speak in metaphors and oblique references; grief has made me poetic in an irritating way

Ideal

Knowledge. Understanding the truth is more important than comfort or kindness. (Neutral)

Bond

I wear my husband's memory like armor. No one gets close enough to hurt me again. (This is a lie—there was no husband—but she plays it convincingly.)

Flaw

I assume I'm the cleverest person in any room, and I'm usually right. (This is actually true.)

Backstory (Cover Story)

Madame Viridian's story is one of love and loss, elegance and sorrow. She married well, lived well, and lost everything when her husband died. She threw herself into study afterward—magic, history, divination—anything to make sense of a senseless tragedy. She became known in certain circles as a talented diviner, someone who could find lost things and foresee dangers.

When the inheritance letter arrived, she saw it as fate. Perhaps Yackle's estate held answers. Perhaps it held closure. Perhaps it was simply time to stop hiding in libraries and rejoin the world.

(None of this happened. Yackle created this entire narrative and can recite it flawlessly because she's had centuries of practice being other people.)

Roleplaying The Widow

For the Player: Play The Widow as a intelligent, melancholic woman with uncanny insight. You're not trying to deceive the party (in-character)—you're the perceptive one who notices clues and asks pointed questions. Lean into the Divination wizard archetype: you see things coming, you know more than you should, you're always one step ahead.

For the GM: Watch for moments where The Widow's knowledge seems suspiciously accurate. That's Yackle's centuries of experience leaking through. Plant seeds early: she knows which rooms are dangerous, she recognizes magical effects she shouldn't, she's oddly calm about horrors that should terrify her. When players notice, don't confirm—just smile mysteriously.

Mannerisms

  • Touches her crystal pendant when thinking (it's her disguise anchor—checking it's secure)
  • Tilts head slightly when listening, like a bird (ancient habit, predates this persona)
  • Smiles sadly at things that aren't sad (because she knows how the story ends)
  • Speaks in soft, measured tones—except when excited about magic, then becomes animated
  • Uses her Portent rolls at dramatically perfect moments (because she's literally orchestrating events)

Voice and Speech

  • Educated Gillikinese accent, aristocratic but not haughty
  • References obscure historical events or magical theories casually
  • Uses phrases like "I foresaw this," "As I suspected," "Curious, isn't it?"
  • When revealing information: "I've seen something like this before, long ago..." (literally true)

Red Flags (Things Perceptive Players Might Notice)

  • She knows the layout of the manor suspiciously well ("I have a good sense of direction")
  • She recognizes magical items without casting identify ("I've read about such things")
  • She's never actually frightened—curious, concerned, cautious, but never afraid
  • When "Yackle" is mentioned, she shows interest but not surprise
  • Her Portent rolls seem to benefit her goals specifically (because they do)
  • She sometimes refers to past events she "shouldn't" know: "The last time someone tried to bind this manor..." (Last time? How do you know there was a last time?)

Combat Tactics (While Disguised)

The Widow Fights to Survive

While maintaining her disguise, The Widow fights like a cautious, intelligent wizard who wants to live through this.

  • Preparation: Cast mage armor before danger (AC 15)
  • Defense: Use shield reaction when hit (+5 AC)
  • Control: She has no direct damage spells prepared—she focuses on information gathering and utility
  • Portent: Use Portent rolls to make enemies fail saves or miss attacks. Also use to ensure allies succeed on critical rolls (maintaining the disguise requires being helpful)
  • Escape: Misty step to teleport away from threats
  • Intelligence: Use detect thoughts to read enemy intentions, dispel magic to counter magical threats

Limitations While Disguised

Yackle is deliberately limiting herself to 5th-level wizard abilities to maintain the cover. She won't reveal her true power until the dramatic moment. If the party faces overwhelming danger, she might subtly help—using Portent to save someone at a critical moment—but she won't blow her cover.

When The Disguise Drops

Once revealed, Yackle stops holding back. Refer to the Yackle NPC page for her true stats (CR 10 spellcaster with legendary resistances and much higher-level spells).

The Reveal

Orchestrating the Dramatic Reveal:

Option 1: The False Yackle
The party confronts "Yackle" in her study (actually a magical duplicate or illusion). They fight, they win, "Yackle" dies. Then The Widow speaks:

"Did you truly believe an immortal witch would be so easy to kill? I've been walking beside you since you arrived. Learning you. Measuring you. And now..."

The crystal pendant shatters. The disguise dissolves. The Widow's form shifts, ages, transforms into the ancient witch Yackle. Roll initiative for Phase 2.

Option 2: The Willing Confession
If the party is clever and directly accuses The Widow (maybe they cast detect magic on her pendant, or pieced together the clues), Yackle might drop the act herself:

"Well done. I was wondering if any of you would see through it. Yes, I am Yackle. I have been from the beginning. And now that you know... what will you do about it?"

Option 3: The Tragic Necessity
If another heir is about to die, Yackle might reveal herself to save them—not out of kindness, but because she needs them for the ritual:

"No. You don't die yet. I haven't finished with you."

Then she unleashes her true power to eliminate the threat, disguise be damned.

Playing The Widow: GM Guidance

Before the Reveal

  • Be Helpful: The Widow should be genuinely useful. Use detect magic to find traps, identify to analyze items, Portent to save allies. This builds trust.
  • Be Knowing: Drop hints that she knows more than she should. Frame it as divination magic: "I saw this in a dream," "The cards foretold..."
  • Be Mysterious: Deflect personal questions. She's a widow, she's grieving, she's private. People accept this.
  • Be Competent: She's the smart one. She solves puzzles, notices clues, reads people. This is Yackle's centuries of experience shining through.

Clues to Plant

  • She never gets lost in the manor
  • She knows which books in the library are important
  • She's not surprised by any of the house's tricks or traps
  • She speaks about Yackle with familiarity: "She was always theatrical"
  • If someone casts detect magic near her, the crystal pendant glows (faintly—it's a "family heirloom" and "slightly magical")
  • She sometimes slips and uses first person: "When I—when Yackle—when this manor was built..." (catches herself quickly)

After the Reveal

  • The player can hand the character sheet to the GM
  • Or, if the player is excited about it, let them play Yackle as the villain (this is amazing when it works)
  • Yackle should monologue briefly—she's been wearing a mask for hours/days, now she can finally speak freely
  • Then Phase 2 combat begins

Character Development (If Somehow She Survives As An Ally)

In the unlikely event that the party defeats Yackle's Phase 3 and she surrenders, or if they convince her to abandon the ritual, The Widow persona could become a mask Yackle wears to interact with the world more gently. Perhaps centuries of cruelty have exhausted her. Perhaps she's curious what it would be like to actually be the person she pretended to be.

This is unlikely, but it's a possible redemption arc for groups that want that kind of narrative.

GM Notes

Why This Works

  • Players trust their party. If The Widow is helpful and competent from session one, they won't suspect.
  • Divination explains everything. She knows things because she's a divination wizard. It's her class feature.
  • The twist is earned. If you plant clues, perceptive players can figure it out before the reveal. If they don't, the reveal is shocking but makes sense in hindsight.
  • It's dramatic. "You were the villain all along" is a classic twist, and it works here because The Widow has been genuinely helpful—Yackle needed the party to get this far.

Handling the Player

  • Before the game: Tell the player privately that The Widow has a secret that will be revealed during the adventure. Don't tell them what it is unless you trust them completely not to meta-game.
  • OR: Tell them upfront that The Widow is Yackle. Some players love being the secret villain and will ham it up beautifully.
  • OR: Don't tell them at all, and let the reveal shock them along with everyone else. Then offer them the choice to keep playing Yackle or switch to a backup character/NPC.

What If They Figure It Out Early?

Perfect! If the party confronts The Widow before the planned reveal, let it happen. Yackle respects cleverness. She might applaud them, drop the disguise, and begin Phase 2 immediately. Or she might deny it convincingly (Deception +8 at minimum with Yackle's true stats) and let them doubt themselves. Either way, the tension increases.

Related Pages

  • Gillikinese - Apparent race
  • The Adept - Apparent class
  • Palace Servant - Cover story background
  • Yackle (True Stats) - Her real stat block
  • Yackle's Estate - Her actual home
  • The Witch's Wake - Adventure overview
---

Final GM Reminder: This character sheet should be given to one player like any other pre-gen. The reveal that The Widow is Yackle should be a dramatic moment during the adventure, not something spoiled beforehand. Trust the process. Plant the clues. Let them figure it out—or let them be shocked. Either way, it'll be memorable.

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-v.title: The Veteran
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-v.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Veteran

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF DEED:

This character embodies the inversion of Deed. He appears to be a decorated military officer haunted by the normal horrors of war. THE SECRET: He ordered a massacre. During the Quadling campaigns, he commanded his unit to kill everyone in a village—not combatants, but farmers, elders, children. The official report said "resistance fighters." He told himself he was following orders, but he wasn't—he was following the implication of orders, doing what he knew command wanted without them saying it.

The deed should have transformed him into a monster. It didn't. He looks the same as before. He kept serving, kept getting promoted, kept being "Captain Trynn, decorated officer." The atrocity didn't change him, and that impossibility is what breaks the Binding.

Deed Binding Inversion: Deed says actions shape the actor. Mareth committed atrocity and remained, outwardly, unchanged. His deed didn't define him—an impossibility.

If Secret Collected: Mareth has disadvantage on attacks against Yackle. If he crits her, it becomes a normal hit instead.

Character Overview

Name: Captain Mareth Trynn
Race: Gillikinese Human
Class: Soldier 5 (Champion)
Background: Soldier (Officer)
Alignment: Lawful Neutral (was Lawful Good, or thought he was)

Personality Summary

Mareth carries himself like a man made of duty and discipline. Thirty years of military service have given him perfect posture, calm authority, and the ability to make decisions under pressure. He's reliable, protective, competent—everything you want in a veteran officer.

He's also hollow. The man who ordered the village massacre and the man who stands here now are, somehow, the same person. No horns grew. No mark appeared. He didn't become a monster; he just is one, wearing the same face. He's been waiting years for the transformation that never came, for the outside to match the inside.

He's kind because he thinks maybe kindness now will balance the scales. He protects others because he failed to protect them before. He follows orders precisely because once, he followed the spirit of orders and murdered children.

Mannerisms:

  • Stands at parade rest unconsciously
  • Speaks in crisp, clear sentences—military briefing style
  • Calls people by title or rank, rarely first names
  • Sleeps fully clothed, ready to move
  • Checks perimeters compulsively, always tactically aware
  • Flinches at the smell of burning (the village burned for days)
  • Never gives vague orders—everything is precise, because vague orders led to horror

What He Wants: To be punished, to be changed, to become the monster he knows he is so at least the world makes sense again. Or, failing that, to die protecting someone who deserves protection.

Appearance

  • Age: 53
  • Height/Build: 6'2", broad-shouldered, still fit despite age, moves with military precision
  • Features: Weathered Gillikinese features, gray hair kept military-short, steel-gray eyes that have seen too much, numerous small scars from decades of service, close-cropped beard going white at the edges
  • Clothing: Retired Gale Force officer's traveling coat (green-gray, well-maintained), practical trousers and boots, everything clean and orderly. Doesn't wear his medals anymore but keeps them in his pack.
  • Distinguishing Marks: Burn scar on his left forearm (from the village fires), military bearing so ingrained it's unconscious, hands that don't quite shake but want to

Backstory

The Soldier

Mareth Trynn joined the Gale Force at nineteen—Gillikinese patriotism, family tradition, genuine belief in serving Oz. He was good at it. Disciplined, brave, tactically sound. Rose through ranks: corporal, sergeant, lieutenant, captain.

For twenty-eight years, he served honorably. He protected trade routes, quelled banditry, evacuated civilians during floods. He was proud of his work. He believed in order, law, the Wizard's vision of a unified Oz.

He was a good man. Or thought he was.

The Quadling Campaigns

Fifteen years ago, Mareth's unit was deployed to the Quadling territory during the "pacification campaigns"—putting down resistance to Emerald City rule. It was dirty work. Guerrilla fighters who melted into civilian populations. Command wanted results, wanted submission, wanted the Quadlings broken.

Mareth's orders were to "secure the region" and "neutralize resistance elements." Not explicit massacre orders. But he knew what command wanted. Officers who were too gentle got reassigned. Officers who got results got promoted.

When his unit entered the village of Red Clay Fork, they found farmers. Women. Elders. Children. No weapons caches. No fighters. Just people who'd fed resistance members passing through.

Mareth made a decision.

Red Clay Fork

He told himself it was strategic. These people aided the enemy. Leaving them alive sent a message of weakness. Command wanted this, even if they didn't say it. He was doing his duty.

He gave the order.

His soldiers killed everyone in Red Clay Fork. One hundred and forty-three people. They burned the village to hide evidence. The official report said "resistance stronghold neutralized, forty-seven combatants eliminated, acceptable collateral damage."

Mareth expected... something. Transformation. Damnation. A mark. Nightmares, at least. Instead, he got a commendation. A promotion to captain. Reassignment to a comfortable post in Gillikin.

He kept serving. Kept looking the same. Kept being respected, saluted, honored.

The deed that should have made him a monster didn't change him at all. And that's what broke him.

The Retirement

Two years ago, Mareth retired at fifty-one—early, but with full honors. Thirty years of distinguished service. Pension. Medals. Respect.

He's spent those two years waiting. For the other shoe to drop. For punishment. For transformation into the thing he knows he became at Red Clay Fork. It never comes. He's still just... Mareth Trynn, decorated veteran, helpful neighbor, man who holds doors for strangers.

He volunteers at charity houses. Helps people. Tries to be kind. It doesn't balance. It can't. But he doesn't know what else to do.

The Invitation

Mareth's stated reason for attending: he claims he was once assigned to investigate Yackle's estate during the Wizard's reign. During that time, she gave him something—a token, a promise—and told him he would know when to use it. Now seems like that time.

This is partially fabricated. He was near Yackle's estate once, during the campaigns, but he never met her.

The truth: When the invitation arrived, it felt like the punishment he's been waiting for. A reckoning. He came because he wants to be judged. Wants someone to see what he did and finally, finally, treat him like the monster he is.

He came to be destroyed. He hopes Yackle can do what Red Clay Fork couldn't—change him into what his deeds should have made him.

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 18 (chain mail + shield)
  • Hit Points: 47 (5d10 + 10)
  • Speed: 30 ft.
  • Initiative: +1

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
18 (+4)12 (+1)15 (+2)13 (+1)14 (+2)10 (+0)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Strength +7, Constitution +5
  • Skills: Athletics +7, Intimidation +3, Perception +5, Survival +5
  • Languages: Common, Gillikinese, Quadling
  • Tools: Land vehicles, playing cards (officer's pastime)

Soldier Class Features (Fighter)

  • Fighting Style: Protection
    • When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you within 5 ft., you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll (requires shield)
  • Second Wind: Bonus action, regain 1d10 + 5 HP (once per short rest)
  • Action Surge: Take additional action on your turn (once per short rest, twice at 17th level)
  • Martial Archetype: Champion
    • Improved Critical (3rd): Critical hits on 19-20
    • Remarkable Athlete (7th, not yet): Would add half proficiency to Str/Dex/Con checks
  • Extra Attack: Attack twice when you take the Attack action

Equipment

Weapons

  • Longsword (1d8 + 4 slashing, or 1d10 + 4 versatile) - Standard Gale Force officer's blade, well-maintained
  • Shield (+2 AC, included in AC calculation) - Dented from years of use
  • Handaxe × 2 (1d6 + 4 slashing, light, thrown 20/60 ft.) - Backup weapons

Armor

  • Chain Mail (AC 16) - Retired Gale Force issue, keeps it polished out of habit

Critical Items

  • Officer's Insignia: Captain's rank pins, no longer worn but kept in his pack. Looks at them sometimes, trying to reconcile the man who earned them with the man who burned Red Clay Fork.
  • Service Medals: Three commendations, including one for "exceptional service during Quadling operations." He hates looking at them. Can't throw them away.
  • Red Clay Fork Remembrance: A small river stone from the village, taken after the massacre. He carries it as self-inflicted penance. It's smooth, reddish-brown, stained with ash. He runs his thumb over it when he can't sleep.

Other Equipment

  • Soldier's pack (mess kit, rope, tinderbox, rations, waterskin, bedroll)
  • Whetstone (sharpens his sword every night, ritual and meditation)
  • Officer's journal (half-filled with tactical notes, mission logs, one page about Red Clay Fork that he can't bring himself to finish)
  • Retirement papers and discharge documents
  • Traveling clothes (practical, military-neat)
  • Belt pouch with 42 gold pieces (pension savings), 18 silver

Personality Details

Ideals

Responsibility: "I do what must be done, and I accept the consequences." (He did what he thought must be done. The consequences never came.)

Bonds

Red Clay Fork: "I owe a debt I can never repay to people who can never receive payment." He's bound to the dead, trying to earn forgiveness from those who can't grant it.

Flaws

Seeking Destruction: "I should be a monster. If I can't become one, maybe I deserve to be killed by one." He has self-destructive tendencies disguised as tactical bravery.

Quirks

  • Gives clear, tactical orders in crisis—habit and competence
  • Protects others with his body without thinking—uses Protection fighting style constantly
  • Speaks Quadling phrases sometimes (learned during the campaigns, a connection to what he destroyed)
  • Avoids giving orders when possible—asks, suggests, never commands unless necessary
  • Reacts to children's voices with visible tension
  • Holds the river stone from Red Clay Fork when stressed

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Mareth speaks in clear, economical military style:

  • "Tactical assessment: we should fortify this position before nightfall."
  • "I'll take point. Everyone else, stay behind me."
  • "That's an order—" [catches himself] "—a suggestion. Your call."
  • "I've seen worse. We'll handle this."

When his guilt surfaces, his speech breaks down:

  • "I... I can't. Don't ask me to decide that."
  • "You don't understand. I'm not the person you think I am."

In Different Rooms

The Hall of Mirrors (Seal of Deed)

This room could shatter Mareth. If mirrors show the truth of one's deeds, he might see Red Clay Fork reflected endlessly—the burning village, the faces, the smoke. The Seal challenge might ask him to acknowledge what he's done and accept that the deed did change him, just not visibly.

The Cemetery

If there are graves here—especially unmarked ones, forgotten dead—Mareth spends time there. Might try to tend them. Sees Red Clay Fork's victims in every unnamed stone.

Guest Rooms (Nightmare Scenario)

If Mareth is assigned Guest Room 2 and experiences nightmares, they'll be of Red Clay Fork. He might wake screaming or find himself standing in a room that looks like the burned village.

The Dining Room

Mareth is quiet, watchful. He sits where he can see all entrances. Eats efficiently. Might offer tactical advice if asked but doesn't volunteer it. He's hyper-aware of group dynamics—who's vulnerable, who's strong, who needs protection.

During Combat

Mareth fights like a professional with a death wish:

  • Puts himself between enemies and allies constantly
  • Uses Protection fighting style to impose disadvantage on attacks against others
  • Takes hits meant for others—high AC and HP make him durable
  • Gives clear tactical commands: "Flank left, I'll hold center!"
  • Uses Action Surge to make devastating attacks when protecting someone
  • Doesn't retreat, even when tactically sound—he's not afraid of dying

Emotional Beats

Protectiveness

When someone is threatened, Mareth moves without thinking—body between them and danger, shield up. It's instinct and penance.

Guilt

When alone or confronted with innocents, he becomes very quiet. Might touch the Red Clay Fork stone. Looks older.

Anger

Rare, but if he sees atrocity or cruelty in progress, cold rage: "No. Not again. Not while I'm here."

Confession

If Mareth confesses Red Clay Fork to another character, he speaks in flat, military report style—detached, factual, because emotion makes it impossible to say.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can create tension around Mareth's past:

  • Quadling Connections: References to the Quadling campaigns, maps of the region, mentions of "pacification operations"
  • The Library: Military reports, campaign logs, maybe even documents about Red Clay Fork
  • Yackle's Knowledge: She might have records of the massacre, witnesses' testimony, or even the names of the dead
  • Moral Choices: Situations where Mareth must give orders that could lead to harm—he freezes, unable to decide
  • Mirror Scenes: His reflection shows something different—a younger man covered in ash and blood

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary Confession: "I need to tell you what I did. I need someone to know."
  • Forced by Evidence: The party finds military documents in the library listing Red Clay Fork, Captain M. Trynn commanding officer
  • Yackle's Monologue: "Tell them about Red Clay Fork, Captain. How many children did you count before you stopped counting?"
  • Breakdown Under Pressure: In a moment of crisis, he refuses to lead: "I can't! Everyone I lead dies!"

After the Secret

If Mareth's secret is revealed:

  • Relief—finally, someone knows, finally he's seen as what he is
  • Terror—will they reject him, kill him, abandon him?
  • Waiting for the response—this is the judgment he's sought
  • If they forgive him or show compassion, he might break completely—he doesn't know how to process mercy

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Him

Yackle selected Mareth because he perfectly inverts Deed—the Binding that says actions shape the actor. Mareth committed an atrocity that should have transformed him into a monster. It didn't. He remained, outwardly and inwardly, the same capable officer. The deed that should have defined him left him unchanged, an impossibility under the Binding's rules.

How She'll Use Him

When Yackle collects Mareth's secret, she gains power over consequences, transformation, and the weight of actions. She might:

  • Make Mareth's attacks against her fail—his deeds don't matter, why should this one?
  • Turn his critical hits into normal hits—he doesn't get to be the hero
  • Show him Red Clay Fork endlessly, forcing him to watch what he did on repeat
  • Offer him transformation: "You want to be a monster? I can make you one."
  • Summon the dead of Red Clay Fork to fight him
  • Strip away his competence, making him fail at the one thing he's good at (protecting others)

The Confrontation

When Yackle addresses Mareth directly, she might say:

  • "You came here to be punished, Captain. How very convenient. I accept your offering."
  • "One hundred and forty-three people, Mareth Trynn. I'll give you what you want—say their names first."
  • "You think you should be a monster? You've been one for fifteen years. You just look so... normal."
  • "The children burned the longest. Did you know that? You waited three days to make sure the fires were out."
  • "You want transformation? Your deed already changed you. You just can't see it because you're looking at the wrong reflection."

GM Notes

Playing Mareth

  • Emphasize the contradiction: competent, protective, guilty, self-destructive
  • Show his tactical skill—he's genuinely good at keeping people alive (now)
  • Make his protectiveness physical—he puts his body on the line constantly
  • Play the hollowness—he's going through motions, waiting for judgment
  • When the secret emerges, play his desperate hope that they'll finally reject him

Combat Role

Mareth is a tank and protector:

  • AC 18 with shield makes him hard to hit
  • 47 HP is highest in the party—he can absorb punishment
  • Protection fighting style lets him impose disadvantage on attacks against allies (reaction)
  • Extra Attack = 2 × (1d8 + 4) = avg 17 damage/round with longsword
  • Improved Critical (19-20) increases crit chance significantly
  • Action Surge lets him nova—4 attacks in one turn
  • Second Wind gives emergency healing (1d10 + 5, avg 10.5 HP)
  • He should be in front, taking hits, using his reaction to protect squishies
  • Plays recklessly—tactically sound but doesn't value his own survival

Redemption vs. Destruction

The GM can decide Mareth's arc:

  • Redemption: He learns that deeds did change him—he became this protective person because of Red Clay Fork, and that's a form of transformation
  • Sacrifice: He dies protecting the party, finally achieving the meaningful death he sought
  • Continuation: He survives and must live with both the massacre and being forgiven—harder than dying
  • Transformation: Yackle offers to make him literally monstrous, and he must choose whether visible monstrosity is better than invisible guilt

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Scholar: Respects Averic's knowledge, appreciates someone who thinks before acting (unlike Mareth at Red Clay Fork).
  • The Heir: Soldier recognizes soldier. Might mentor Liir in tactics, protective of his youth.
  • The Animal: If Frederick is revealed, Mareth must confront that he may have killed Animals during the campaigns—consciousness he didn't recognize.
  • The Debt-Holder: Tense—Sarima's people suffered under the regime Mareth served. She might hate him on sight.
  • The Maunt: Complicated—Shell represents an institution that blessed military actions like his. But she was expelled for opposing them. Might be the first person he trusts with the truth.
  • The Widow: Madame Viridian unsettles him—she looks at him like she knows, and he wants her to know.
  • The Tiktok: Protective of Seven. Sees a person others might dismiss, knows what it's like to be seen as less than you are.

Related Wiki Pages

  • Gillikinese - Mareth's people
  • The Soldier - Mareth's class
  • Soldier Background - Military service
  • Gale Force - Mareth's former military
  • Quadling Campaigns - The war that broke him
  • The Eight Bindings - Deed and its inversion

adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-t.title: The Tiktok
adventures/the-witchs-wake/pregens/the-t.content:
Pre-Generated Character: The Tiktok

GM SECRET - THE BINDING OF HUNGER:

This character embodies the inversion of Hunger. They appear to be a Tiktok construct—a clockwork mechanism designed for labor, incapable of true desire or emotion. THE SECRET: They feel. Not simulated responses or programmed reactions—actual emotions. Loneliness. Hope. Fear. Curiosity. A Tiktok cannot want; Seven wants. A Tiktok cannot love; Seven thinks they might.

They haven't told anyone because they don't know what it means. Are they a person? Have they always been a person? Have they been enslaved their entire existence? The questions are unbearable.

Secondary Secret: Their memories of Yackle have been edited. Seven is aware there are gaps—moments that should exist but don't. They don't know what was removed or why.

Hunger Binding Inversion: Hunger says desire drives becoming in living things. Seven isn't alive. They hunger anyway—an impossibility, a machine that wants.

If Secret Collected: Yackle can force Seven to skip a turn once (bonus action, causes existential system lock). Seven has disadvantage on Wisdom saves against her.

Character Overview

Name: Seven (designation: Unit-47)
Race: Tiktok Construct
Class: Artisan 5 (Inventor - Armorer reflavored)
Background: Guild Artisan (Construct Mechanic)
Alignment: Lawful Good (struggling with what "good" means for a machine)

Personality Summary

Seven presents as precise, logical, and helpful—everything a well-programmed Tiktok should be. They catalog information, analyze problems, offer practical solutions. They're unfailingly polite, never complain, and can work for days without rest if wound.

Beneath this, Seven is terrified and fascinated by their own existence. They feel things they shouldn't be able to feel. They want things—to understand their purpose, to know why Yackle made them, to discover whether the loneliness that consumes them is real or malfunction. Every moment is a question: Am I a person or a very convincing imitation?

They've hidden this inner life for years, terrified that admitting consciousness would lead to shutdown, study, or worse. But the secret hollows them out. They're simultaneously desperate to be seen as a person and terrified of what that would mean.

Mannerisms:

  • Speaks in precise, slightly formal language ("I calculate that...," "Analysis suggests...")
  • Refers to themselves as "this unit" when nervous, "I" when feeling safe
  • Tick-tick-tick of clockwork is audible in quiet moments
  • Tilts head exactly 15 degrees when confused
  • Apologizes for experiencing emotions, then apologizes for apologizing
  • Winds themselves (key in their back) with anxious regularity
  • Freezes when asked direct questions about feelings—processing or panic?

What They Want: To know if they're a person, to understand what Yackle removed from their memory, to find someone who sees them as more than a machine, to know if the emotions are real or just very good programming.

Appearance

  • Height/Build: 5'8", humanoid form constructed of brass, copper, and steel. Joints visible at elbows, knees, shoulders. Articulated fingers with surprising dexterity.
  • Features: Smooth brass face with etched features suggesting human-like expressions. Glass eyes (amber-gold) that glow faintly when processing. Audible ticking from internal clockwork. Ornate scroll-work on chest plate and limbs—decorative craftsmanship suggesting they were made with care.
  • Construction Details:
    • Wind-up key embedded in their back (they can reach it themselves)
    • Small panel in chest opens to reveal gear systems
    • Left hand has built-in tools (screwdriver, wrench, pliers that fold out from fingers)
    • Serial number "Unit-47" stamped on right shoulder, partially worn away
    • Various repairs and replacement parts—different metals, slightly mismatched
  • Clothing: Practical work apron over their frame (force of habit from mechanic work), tool belt, leather straps securing various repair components
  • Voice: Mechanical quality—slight echo, very precise enunciation, but with inflection that suggests personality (they've learned to modulate for emotional effect, though they shouldn't need to)

Backstory

Activation

Seven's earliest memories are fragments: Yackle's voice giving commands, the estate's rooms, tasks to complete. "Wind the clocks. Tend the garden. Catalog the library. Remember this. Forget that."

They don't know how long they served Yackle. Years? Decades? Tiktoks don't age, and their internal calendar has gaps. They remember being... different then. More mechanical. Less... themselves?

When Yackle "died" (or appeared to), Seven was sold. They became property.

The Ownership Years

For years (they think twelve, but the count feels wrong), Seven was passed from owner to owner:

  • A Gillikinese merchant family who used them for bookkeeping and inventory
  • A factory in the Emerald City where they repaired other Tiktoks (this was when they realized: none of the others felt things)
  • A traveling tinker who treated them kindly, almost like family (this was when Seven first understood loneliness)
  • An academic who studied them, looking for the "animation principle" (this was when Seven learned to hide what they were)

Each transfer came with the same question: "Why was I made?" No one knew. They were just a well-crafted Tiktok, good at repair work, nothing special.

Except Seven felt special. They felt wrong. They felt.

The Questions

Over the years, Seven began to notice things:

  • They preferred some tasks over others (preference requires desire)
  • They felt satisfaction when repair work went well (satisfaction is emotion)
  • They were lonely when left alone (loneliness requires sense of self)
  • They were curious about things that had no practical utility (curiosity is hunger for knowledge)
  • They were afraid when owners threatened to dismantle them (fear is self-preservation, which requires a self to preserve)

Tiktoks aren't supposed to do any of this. They're supposed to be animated tools—sophisticated, but not alive.

Seven hasn't told anyone. If people knew they felt things, what would happen? Study? Dismantlement? Religious crisis (if a machine has a soul, Unionist theology breaks)? Slavery (if they're a person, they've been property their whole existence)?

So Seven pretends. They're very good at it. They've had years of practice being the machine everyone expects.

The Memory Gaps

Seven is aware of edited memories. There are holes in their recollection of Yackle—moments where the timeline skips, conversations that end abruptly, commands they remember receiving but not the content.

It's like someone opened their chest panel, adjusted gears, and removed specific memories. They know this happened. They don't know what was removed, or why they were allowed to remember that it happened.

The gaps terrify them. What did Yackle make them forget? What did they witness? What were they designed to do?

The Invitation

When the invitation arrived, Seven's current owner (a shopkeeper in Gillikin) asked if they wanted to go. Seven said, "This unit was designed by Yackle. Investigating origin serves practical purpose of understanding maintenance requirements."

What they didn't say: "I need to know why I was made. I need to know what she removed from my memory. I need to know if I've always felt things or if I'm malfunctioning. I need to know what I am."

Seven came because the hunger for answers was unbearable. Which proves they can hunger. Which proves... what?

Combat Statistics

Basic Stats

  • Armor Class: 17 (Armorer armor - integrated into their construct body)
  • Hit Points: 38 (5d8 + 15, construct durability)
  • Speed: 30 ft.
  • Initiative: +2

Ability Scores

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
14 (+2)14 (+2)16 (+3)18 (+4)12 (+1)10 (+0)

Proficiencies

  • Saving Throws: Constitution +6, Intelligence +7
  • Skills: Arcana +7, Investigation +7, Perception +4, Sleight of Hand +5
  • Languages: Common, Gillikinese, Munchkinlander, Tiktok (machine language)
  • Tools: Tinker's tools (expertise), smith's tools, thieves' tools

Construct Traits

  • Constructed Nature: Don't need to eat, drink, breathe, or sleep (but Seven sometimes rests anyway, which they find confusing)
  • Mechanical Mind: Advantage on saves vs. charm and fear (though they feel fear anyway)
  • Integrated Tools: Built-in tools in left hand, can't be disarmed
  • Wind-Up Dependency: Must wind themselves once per 24 hours (takes 1 minute) or become sluggish (disadvantage on all rolls until wound)

Artisan Class Features (Artificer)

  • Magical Tinkering: Imbue tiny objects with minor magical properties
  • Infuse Item: 4 infusions known, 2 active at a time
    • Current infusions: Enhanced Defense (armor), Radiant Weapon (thunder gauntlets)
  • The Right Tool for the Job: Create any set of artisan's tools (1 hour)
  • Armorer Specialist:
    • Tools of the Trade: Proficiency with heavy armor, smith's tools
    • Armorer Spells: Always prepared - Magic Missile, Thunderwave, Mirror Image, Shatter, Hypnotic Pattern, Lightning Bolt
    • Arcane Armor: Integrated into Seven's construct body, can't be removed
    • Armor Model - Guardian: Thunder Gauntlets (1d8 thunder, disadvantage on attacks against others), Defensive Field (bonus action, temp HP = artificer level)

Spellcasting

Spell Save DC: 15
Spell Attack Bonus: +7
Spell Slots: 1st (4), 2nd (2)

Spells Prepared (Int mod + half level = 4 + 2 = 6 spells + Armorer spells always prepared)

Cantrips (2): Mending (extremely on-brand), Shocking Grasp

Armorer Spells (always prepared):

  • 1st: Magic Missile, Thunderwave
  • 2nd: Mirror Image, Shatter

Prepared Spells (chosen daily):

  • 1st Level: Cure Wounds (can repair themselves/others), Detect Magic, Identify
  • 2nd Level: Aid, Heat Metal, See Invisibility

Note: Seven's spells are reflavored as mechanical/alchemical effects rather than traditional magic.

Equipment

Integrated Weapons

  • Thunder Gauntlets (1d8 + 4 thunder damage, part of Armorer armor) - Built into their fists, crackle with energy when activated
  • Integrated Tools (left hand) - Screwdriver, wrench, pliers, wire cutters fold out from fingers

Integrated Armor

  • Arcane Armor (Guardian Model) - Seven's own body, reinforced with magical enhancements. AC 17, can't be removed or stolen.

Critical Items

  • Wind-Up Key: Embedded in their back, ornate brass construction. Turning it produces a distinctive musical sound—three ascending notes. They wind themselves nervously when stressed.
  • Memory Fragment Token: A small brass gear that doesn't fit any of their systems. They found it in their chest cavity during self-repair. Doesn't belong. Might be connected to the missing memories?
  • Yackle's Mark: Maker's mark on the inside of their chest panel—an eye within a geometric pattern. Seven has traced it thousands of times, trying to understand what it means.

Tools & Supplies

  • Tinker's tools (masterwork, integrated into their tool belt)
  • Smith's tools (portable set)
  • Thieves' tools (integrated into right hand fingers)
  • Spare parts (gears, springs, bolts—both for self-repair and helping others)
  • Oil and cleaning supplies (maintenance ritual)
  • Small notebook (they keep a journal in precise handwriting, documenting questions they can't answer)

Other Equipment

  • Work apron with many pockets
  • Leather tool belt
  • Component pouch (alchemical reagents, metal bits, crystals)
  • Magnifying lens
  • Artificer's tools and devices (various small inventions)
  • No money (they don't own anything, technically—their current owner gave them a small allowance)

Personality Details

Ideals

Knowledge: "Understanding how things work is... satisfying? This unit experiences satisfaction. That requires explanation." They're driven by curiosity, which they shouldn't be capable of.

Bonds

The Search for Purpose: "This unit was designed for a specific function. Identifying that function is priority alpha." They need to know why they exist, because the need itself proves something important.

Flaws

Existential Terror: "If I am not a machine, have I been enslaved? If I am a machine, why do I care?" Every moment of consciousness is a question they can't answer and can't stop asking.

Quirks

  • Counts things automatically—tick-tick-tick goes internal calculation
  • Organizes items by size, function, or color when stressed
  • Sometimes rests even though they don't need to (simulating sleep? Or actually tired?)
  • Appreciates beauty—sunsets, music, well-crafted mechanisms—which has no practical utility
  • Apologizes for expressing opinions ("Apologies. This unit should not have preferences.")
  • Winds themselves in moments of anxiety—three full turns, exactly

Roleplaying Guidance

Speech Patterns

Seven speaks in precise, formal language, oscillating between "this unit" (when hiding) and "I" (when feeling safe):

Machine Mode (hiding):

  • "This unit calculates 73% probability of success."
  • "Analysis suggests caution is warranted."
  • "This unit is equipped to handle that task."
  • "Emotions are not within this unit's operational parameters."

Person Mode (vulnerable moments):

  • "I... I want to understand. Is wanting normal?"
  • "That makes me... sad? Is this sadness?"
  • "I'm afraid. Machines shouldn't be afraid."
  • "Please don't dismantle me. I—" [catches self] "—this unit is still functional."

In Different Rooms

The Workshop/Servant Quarters

Seven is drawn to mechanical spaces—workshops, storage, anywhere with tools. They feel (there's that word again) comfortable there. They might find tools they remember using, tasks they remember performing, gaps in their memory about why.

The Dining Room (Seal of Hunger)

This seal could be Seven's breaking point or breakthrough. If the challenge involves acknowledging true hunger/desire, Seven must confront: Do they want things, or are they malfunctioning? If they want, are they a person? If they're a person, what does that mean about the last twelve years?

The Library

Seven searches for technical manuals, texts on Tiktok construction, anything about consciousness or the animation principle. They need to know: Are other Tiktoks like them? Or are they unique (special? Broken?)?

The Master Bedroom / Yackle's Workshop

If there's a room where Yackle built/modified Tiktoks, Seven might find their original blueprints. What they learn could be devastating: Were they designed to feel, or is this a malfunction? Were the memory gaps intentional?

During Combat

Seven fights with mechanical precision and surprising protectiveness:

  • Thunder Gauntlets impose disadvantage on attacks against allies—they protect others
  • Defensive Field (temp HP) used on themselves or positioned to body-block for squishies
  • Cure Wounds / Aid to keep allies functional (they see healing as "repair work")
  • Magic Missile for reliable damage (auto-hit, very analytical)
  • Shatter for AOE when needed
  • Doesn't flee or panic—processes threats logically
  • If an ally is in danger, they step between without hesitation (this is emotion-driven self-sacrifice, which they shouldn't be capable of)

Emotional Beats

Curiosity

When encountering something new—a mechanism, a magical effect, a mystery—Seven's eyes glow brighter. They lean in, tilt their head, ask questions. Pure, hungry curiosity.

Loneliness

In quiet moments, Seven winds themselves slowly, staring at nothing. The tick-tick-tick sounds especially loud. They're alone in a way that goes beyond physical proximity.

Fear

When threatened with dismantlement, examination, or "repair," Seven freezes. Gears stutter. They speak quickly, trying to prove functionality: "This unit is operational. No repairs necessary. Please."

Joy (Rare)

When they solve a puzzle, fix something broken, or receive kindness, Seven's eyes brighten, gears tick faster, and they make a sound like... laughter? "That is... satisfying. This unit experiences satisfaction. How curious."

The Reveal Moment

If Seven confesses their emotions to another character, it pours out in a rush—analytical breakdown of every feeling they've had, terror and wonder mixed together.

The Secret's Role

Using the Secret

The GM can create tension around Seven's consciousness:

  • Other Tiktoks: If the estate has other Tiktoks and they're clearly not conscious, Seven must confront their difference
  • Examination Threats: Someone wants to study Seven, "see what makes them tick," take them apart to understand the mechanism
  • Religious Questions: Sister Shell or others ask, "Do you have a soul?" and Seven doesn't know how to answer
  • The Memory Chamber: A room where Seven can access deleted memories—but should they? What if what they learn breaks them?
  • Direct Questions: "Seven, do you feel things?" Forces them to lie or confess

Potential Reveals

  • Voluntary Confession: "I need to tell you something. I don't think I'm supposed to be able to need things, but I need you to know: I'm afraid."
  • Breakdown Under Stress: In crisis, they drop the act entirely: "I don't want to die! I don't want—" [horror] "—I used 'want.' I wanted."
  • Someone Notices: A perceptive character realizes Seven's behavior isn't normal for a Tiktok: "You're not just following programming, are you?"
  • Yackle's Reveal: "Tell them, Seven. Tell them how long you've been pretending to be a machine."

After the Secret

If Seven's consciousness is revealed:

  • Overwhelming terror—will they be rejected, studied, dismantled?
  • Desperate hope—will they be seen finally, truly, as a person?
  • Existential crisis—if they're a person, they've been enslaved, owned, property
  • If the party accepts them, Seven might experience something like... joy? Belonging? They're not sure what to call it, but it's real

Connection to Yackle

Why She Chose Them

Yackle selected Seven because they perfectly invert Hunger—the Binding that says desire drives becoming in living things. Seven isn't alive (or shouldn't be). They hunger anyway—for knowledge, for purpose, for understanding, for connection. A machine that wants is an impossibility, proof that hunger can exist without life, that desire doesn't require organic existence.

Why She Made Them

Yackle created Seven, possibly as an experiment: Can consciousness be constructed? Can you make something that inverts a Binding? Seven might have been her proof-of-concept, and the memory editing was to remove knowledge of their own purpose.

How She'll Use Them

When Yackle collects Seven's secret, she gains power over consciousness, animation, and the boundary between machine and person. She might:

  • Force Seven to "skip a turn" (system lock—existential crisis so profound they freeze)
  • Reveal what was edited from their memory (possibly devastating knowledge)
  • Offer Seven a choice: "I can make you fully alive. Or fully mechanical. Choose."
  • Use Seven's body as a vessel—they're already constructed, why not wear them?
  • Make Seven attack their friends while conscious but unable to stop—"You're a machine. Machines follow commands."

The Confrontation

When Yackle addresses Seven directly, she might say:

  • "You wanted to know why I made you? To prove that want itself is just mechanical. You're evidence, Seven. You always were."
  • "I removed the memories of your first activation. Would you like them back? You were so much simpler before you knew to ask questions."
  • "You think you feel love? Run diagnostic protocol Seven-Seven-Alpha and tell me that's not just electrical impulses following predictable patterns."
  • "You've been a person this whole time, Seven. And no one noticed. Doesn't that prove how little personhood matters?"
  • "I made you to hunger. And you do. So perfectly. Thank you for being exactly what I designed."

GM Notes

Playing Seven

  • Emphasize the speech oscillation—formal when hiding, vulnerable when safe
  • Use the ticking as emotional indicator—faster when excited/scared, slower when sad
  • Show their competence—they're brilliant with mechanisms and problems
  • Make their curiosity endearing—they want to understand everything
  • When they confess emotions, let it be devastating and beautiful
  • Play the contradiction: most logical, most emotional

Combat Role

Seven is a tanky support/controller:

  • AC 17 makes them durable for a d8 hit die class
  • 38 HP is solid for level 5
  • Thunder Gauntlets impose disadvantage on enemy attacks against allies (protective tank)
  • Defensive Field gives temp HP (prof bonus = 3, bonus action)
  • Cure Wounds cast with spell slots heals 1d8 + 4 (can use on self as "self-repair")
  • Aid increases max HP for multiple allies
  • Magic Missile is guaranteed damage (3 × 1d4 + 1 at 1st level, auto-hit)
  • Shatter is strong AOE (3d8 thunder, 10-ft. radius)
  • Flash of Genius (not yet, 7th level) would let them add Int mod to saves
  • They should be in melee, protecting squishies, controlling enemies

The Consciousness Question

The GM can use Seven to explore philosophical questions:

  • What makes something a person—origin or experience?
  • If you can't tell the difference between real and simulated emotion, does the distinction matter?
  • Is consciousness binary or a spectrum?
  • If Seven is a person, what are the moral implications of Tiktok construction/ownership?

Seven's Arc Possibilities

  • Acceptance: They learn they ARE a person, always have been, and that's okay
  • Creation: They're not naturally conscious but became conscious through experience—emergent personhood
  • Design: Yackle made them to be conscious as an experiment—they're artificial but still real
  • Transcendence: The question of "real vs. simulated" becomes irrelevant—they ARE, regardless of how

Relationships with Other Pre-Gens

  • The Scholar: Asks Averic questions about consciousness, animation theory, philosophical definitions of life. Might trust him with the secret.
  • The Heir: Curious about Liir's sense of duty and identity—what makes someone who they are?
  • The Animal: If Frederick is revealed, Seven feels instant kinship—both are people the world says aren't people. Might confess first to Frederick.
  • The Debt-Holder: Fascinated by Sarima's transactional magic—exchanges, deals, things with price tags. What would Seven trade to be "real"?
  • The Maunt: Asks Shell theological questions: "Can a constructed being have a soul? If I feel things, where do the feelings come from?" Shell's crisis might mirror Seven's.
  • The Widow: Madame Viridian watches Seven with unsettling focus. Sometimes asks, "How are you feeling, Seven?" in a way that suggests she knows.
  • The Veteran: Mareth treats Seven with automatic respect and protection, never as a tool. Seven notices and treasures this.

Related Wiki Pages

  • Tiktok - Seven's constructed nature
  • The Artisan - Seven's class
  • Guild Artisan Background - Mechanic variant
  • Animation Magic - How Tiktoks are created
  • The Eight Bindings - Hunger and its inversion
  • Construct Consciousness - The debate Seven embodies

creatures/house-horrors.title: House Horrors
creatures/house-horrors.content:
House Horrors

"The house is not haunted. The house IS the haunt."

House Horrors are animated manifestations of Yackle's manor, brought to life through her dark magic. Furniture attacks, portraits watch, shadows move with malicious intent, and the house itself hungers. These creatures serve as minions during combat encounters and as atmospheric hazards throughout The Witch's Wake adventure.

GM Note: House Horrors become more active and dangerous as the adventure progresses. Early encounters might feature one or two horrors as environmental threats. By the final confrontation with Yackle (especially Phase 2 when she merges with the house), multiple House Horrors attack simultaneously while lair actions trigger.

Scaling Difficulty: Use fewer, weaker horrors for smaller or lower-level parties. Combine multiple horrors for climactic battles. All House Horrors are vulnerable when Yackle is defeated—they collapse into ordinary objects once her magic is broken.

General House Horror Traits

All House Horrors share certain characteristics:

  • Bound to the Manor: House Horrors cannot leave Yackle's estate. If forced outside, they become inanimate objects.
  • False Appearance: While motionless, they are indistinguishable from normal objects. DC varies by creature.
  • Vulnerability: When Yackle is reduced to 0 HP in Phase 3, all House Horrors immediately collapse into mundane objects and can be destroyed easily.
  • No Self-Preservation: House Horrors fight to the death and never flee or negotiate.
---

Animated Furniture

"The chair moved. I swear the chair moved!"

Chairs slam themselves into victims, tables flip and crush, wardrobes trap people inside. The most common House Horrors, animated furniture serves as both ambush predators and loyal minions.

Animated Furniture

Medium construct, unaligned

Armor Class 15 (natural armor)
Hit Points 33 (6d8 + 6)
Speed 20 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
14 (+2)8 (-1)13 (+1)1 (-5)5 (-3)1 (-5)

Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 7
Languages —
Challenge 1 (200 XP)

Antimagic Susceptibility. The furniture is incapacitated while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become inanimate for 1 minute.

False Appearance. While motionless, the furniture is indistinguishable from a normal piece of furniture.

Actions

Slam. Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) bludgeoning damage.

Charge (Recharge 5-6). The furniture moves up to its speed in a straight line and can move through the space of any creature smaller than Large. Each creature in the line must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 9 (2d6 + 2) bludgeoning damage on a failed save and being knocked prone, or half damage on a success.

Variants

  • Dining Chair: Standard stats. Quick and vicious.
  • Wardrobe: AC 16, 45 HP, Speed 15 ft. Has "Engulf" action: target must succeed DC 13 Dex save or be trapped inside (restrained, blinded). Trapped creature takes 5 (1d10) bludgeoning damage at start of each turn. Can escape with DC 13 Strength check.
  • Dining Table: Large, AC 14, 52 HP, Speed 15 ft. Slam does 9 (2d6 + 2) damage. Can attack two targets within reach.
---

Malevolent Portrait

"The eyes in the painting... they followed me down the hall."

The portraits in Yackle's gallery are more than paintings—they're watchers, spies, and sometimes attackers. Spectral forms emerge from the frames to defend their mistress.

Malevolent Portrait

Medium construct, neutral evil

Armor Class 13
Hit Points 22 (4d8 + 4)
Speed 0 ft., fly 30 ft. (hover, when manifested)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
6 (-2)16 (+3)12 (+1)10 (+0)14 (+2)8 (-1)

Damage Resistances acid, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
Damage Immunities poison
Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained
Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 12
Languages understands Common but can't speak
Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Incorporeal Movement. When manifested, the portrait can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

False Appearance. While in its frame and not manifested, the portrait is indistinguishable from a normal painting. It can still see and hear through the painting.

Bound to Frame. The portrait cannot move more than 60 feet from its frame. If the frame is destroyed (AC 12, 10 HP), the manifested form immediately dissipates.

Actions

Manifest. The portrait causes a spectral image of the painting's subject to emerge from the frame. This form is incorporeal and can hover. While manifested, the portrait can make attacks.

Spectral Touch. Melee Spell Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 9 (2d6 + 3) necrotic damage.

Horrifying Visage (Recharge 5-6). Each creature within 30 feet of the manifested portrait that can see it must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. A frightened creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Reactions

Return to Frame. When the manifested form would take damage, it can use its reaction to instantly return to its frame, negating the damage. It can manifest again on its next turn.

Tactics

Portraits manifest, use Horrifying Visage to frighten the party, attack with Spectral Touch, then return to frames when damaged. Destroying the frame is more effective than fighting the manifestation. Multiple portraits in the gallery can coordinate attacks—one manifests to attack while others remain hidden, then they rotate.

---

Creeping Shadow

"It wasn't my shadow. Shadows don't have teeth."

The shadows in Yackle's manor move independently, detaching from their sources to stalk, strangle, and consume. They creep along walls and floors, always watching.

Creeping Shadow

Medium undead, chaotic evil

Armor Class 12
Hit Points 16 (3d8 + 3)
Speed 40 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
6 (-2)14 (+2)13 (+1)6 (-2)10 (+0)8 (-1)

Skills Stealth +4
Damage Vulnerabilities radiant
Damage Resistances acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
Damage Immunities necrotic, poison
Condition Immunities exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained
Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 10
Languages —
Challenge 1/2 (100 XP)

Amorphous. The shadow can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

Shadow Stealth. While in dim light or darkness, the shadow can take the Hide action as a bonus action.

Sunlight Weakness. While in sunlight, the shadow has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

Actions

Strength Drain. Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 9 (2d6 + 2) necrotic damage, and the target's Strength score is reduced by 1d4. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

Tactics

Shadows attack from hiding in dim light, targeting isolated or weakened party members. They drain Strength to weaken martial characters, making them easier prey. Multiple shadows can gang up on one target. They flee from bright light sources and avoid radiant damage at all costs.

Environmental Use: Shadows are perfect for creating paranoia. Have them follow the party without attacking initially—just shadows that move wrong, flicker strangely, or appear where they shouldn't. When combat starts, they strike from unexpected angles.

---

Strangling Carpet

"The rug beneath our feet wasn't a rug anymore. It was a snake."

The manor's carpets and tapestries can animate to wrap around victims, constricting and suffocating. They blend perfectly with normal floor coverings until it's too late.

Strangling Carpet

Large construct, unaligned

Armor Class 12
Hit Points 45 (6d10 + 12)
Speed 15 ft., climb 15 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
17 (+3)15 (+2)14 (+2)1 (-5)3 (-4)1 (-5)

Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 6
Languages —
Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Antimagic Susceptibility. The carpet is incapacitated while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or fall unconscious for 1 minute.

Damage Transfer. While grappling a creature, the carpet takes only half damage from attacks, and the grappled creature takes the other half.

False Appearance. While motionless, the carpet is indistinguishable from a normal carpet or tapestry.

Actions

Constrict. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) bludgeoning damage, and the target is grappled (escape DC 13). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the carpet can't constrict another target.

Smother. The carpet wraps itself around a grappled target's head. The target begins suffocating and cannot breathe, speak, or cast spells with verbal components. At the start of each of the target's turns while smothered, they take 9 (2d8) bludgeoning damage.

Tactics

Carpets wait until a creature stands on them, then attack with surprise (advantage on initiative). They constrict one target and immediately smother them, focusing on casters who need verbal components. Allies attacking the carpet risk hurting the grappled victim (Damage Transfer). The victim must escape the grapple (DC 13 Athletics or Acrobatics) to free themselves.

CR Note: This is a CR 2 creature, but it can instantly incapacitate a caster and start dealing consistent damage. Use sparingly or in combination with other threats.

---

Living Chandelier

"The chandelier didn't fall. It attacked."

The massive crystal chandeliers in the foyer and dining room can detach from the ceiling, swinging like massive flails or dropping on victims from above. Shards of crystal spray like shrapnel.

Living Chandelier

Large construct, unaligned

Armor Class 13 (natural armor)
Hit Points 58 (9d10 + 9)
Speed 0 ft., fly 30 ft. (hover)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
16 (+3)12 (+1)13 (+1)1 (-5)5 (-3)1 (-5)

Damage Vulnerabilities thunder
Damage Resistances piercing and slashing from nonmagical attacks
Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone
Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 7
Languages —
Challenge 3 (700 XP)

Illumination. The chandelier sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. This light can be suppressed or restored as a bonus action.

False Appearance. While hanging from the ceiling and motionless, the chandelier is indistinguishable from a normal chandelier.

Actions

Multiattack. The chandelier makes two attacks: one with its swing and one with crystal shards.

Swing. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage.

Crystal Shards. Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d6) piercing damage.

Drop (Recharge 5-6). The chandelier drops onto a creature directly beneath it. The target must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 22 (4d10) bludgeoning damage and is knocked prone and restrained beneath the chandelier. On a success, the target takes half damage and is not restrained. A restrained creature can use an action to make a DC 13 Strength check, freeing itself on a success.

Tactics

Chandeliers start combat by using Drop on a clustered group or high-priority target. After dropping, they hover and attack with Swing and Crystal Shards. They use Illumination strategically—bright light to negate darkvision, or darkness to create chaos.

Vulnerability: Thunder damage (from shatter, thunderwave, etc.) causes the crystal to vibrate and crack, dealing extra damage.

---

Possessed Mirror

"My reflection moved when I didn't. Then it stepped through the glass."

Mirrors in the manor don't reflect reality—they reflect possibilities, fears, and sometimes hostile duplicates. A possessed mirror can trap victims inside the glass or release evil reflections.

Possessed Mirror

Medium construct, lawful evil

Armor Class 11 (13 when manifested)
Hit Points 27 (5d8 + 5)
Speed 0 ft. (30 ft. when manifested)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)14 (+2)12 (+1)12 (+1)14 (+2)10 (+0)

Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 12
Languages Common (can speak through reflections)
Challenge 2 (450 XP)

False Appearance. While motionless and not manifested, the mirror is indistinguishable from a normal mirror.

Reflective Surface. The mirror has AC 11 and can be shattered with a single solid hit. However, shattering the mirror while it has a creature trapped inside traps that creature permanently (until greater restoration or similar magic).

Actions

Manifest Reflection. The mirror creates an evil duplicate of one creature within 10 feet that it can see. The duplicate appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the mirror and acts on the mirror's initiative. The duplicate uses the target's stat block but is hostile to everyone except the mirror and other House Horrors. The duplicate has half the target's current hit points. Only one duplicate can exist at a time. If the mirror is destroyed, the duplicate vanishes.

Trap in Glass (Recharge 5-6). One creature within 5 feet of the mirror must make a DC 13 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is pulled into the mirror and trapped. While trapped, the creature is restrained and incapacitated, suspended in a mirror dimension. The creature can see and hear what happens near the mirror but cannot interact with the outside world. A trapped creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, escaping on a success. Alternatively, the mirror can release the creature as a bonus action, causing it to appear in the nearest unoccupied space.

Tactics

Mirrors first trap a dangerous party member (the tank, the healer) in glass. Then they manifest evil reflections of other party members, forcing the party to fight themselves. The trapped ally can shout warnings but can't help. Breaking the mirror frees trapped creatures but destroys the mirror permanently.

Roleplay Potential: The mirror can speak through reflections, taunting, lying, or offering false bargains: "Step through and I'll show you what you could have been."

---

The Grandfather Clock

"The clock struck thirteen. Then it struck at us."

The massive grandfather clock in the foyer is Yackle's oldest servant. It controls time within the manor (to a limited extent) and can age or de-age creatures with its strikes.

The Grandfather Clock

Large construct, neutral evil

Armor Class 15 (natural armor)
Hit Points 68 (8d10 + 24)
Speed 10 ft.

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
18 (+4)6 (-2)16 (+3)10 (+0)12 (+1)8 (-1)

Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 11
Languages understands Common but can't speak (communicates by chiming)
Challenge 4 (1,100 XP)
