Immutable Form. The clock is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

Temporal Anchor. The clock cannot be affected by time manipulation magic (such as slow, haste, or time stop).

False Appearance. While motionless, the clock is indistinguishable from a normal grandfather clock.

Actions

Multiattack. The clock makes two pendulum attacks.

Pendulum. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) bludgeoning damage.

Temporal Strike (Recharge 5-6). The clock strikes its bell, releasing a wave of temporal energy. Each creature within 20 feet must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, roll 1d6:

  • 1-2: Target is aged 1d10 years (gaining associated frailty—disadvantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution checks for 1 hour)
  • 3-4: Target is de-aged 1d10 years (losing associated experience—disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks for 1 hour)
  • 5-6: Target is frozen in time for 1 round (paralyzed, cannot be moved or affected)
On a successful save, the target is unaffected.

Strike Thirteen (1/Day). As an action, the clock strikes thirteen times—an impossible hour. All House Horrors within the manor regain 10 hit points and gain advantage on their next attack roll. All non-construct creatures within 30 feet must make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. A frightened creature hears each strike as a death knell counting down their remaining moments. They can repeat the save at the end of each turn, ending the effect on a success.

Tactics

The Grandfather Clock is a miniboss encounter. It guards the foyer or appears during the Phase 2 fight with Yackle. It uses Temporal Strike to debuff the party, then pounds them with Pendulum attacks. It saves Strike Thirteen for when multiple House Horrors are damaged—healing them and frightening the party simultaneously.

Weakness: The clock is slow (10 ft. speed) and can be kited. However, it has high HP and AC, making it a tough nut to crack. Destroying the clock's face (focused attacks on "the face" could be a called shot—GM discretion) might disable Temporal Strike.

---

Swarm of Silverware

"Knives. Hundreds of knives. Flying. Toward our faces."

The dining room's silverware animates en masse—forks, knives, spoons swirling like a metallic tornado. Individually harmless, but collectively deadly.

Swarm of Silverware

Medium swarm of Tiny constructs, unaligned

Armor Class 14 (natural armor)
Hit Points 36 (8d8)
Speed 0 ft., fly 40 ft. (hover)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)18 (+4)10 (+0)1 (-5)5 (-3)1 (-5)

Damage Resistances bludgeoning, piercing, slashing
Damage Immunities poison, psychic
Condition Immunities charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained, stunned
Senses blindsight 30 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 7
Languages —
Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Swarm. The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny object. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

False Appearance. While arranged on a table and motionless, the silverware is indistinguishable from normal dining utensils.

Actions

Cutting Swarm. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. Hit: 14 (4d6) slashing damage, or 7 (2d6) slashing damage if the swarm has half its hit points or fewer.

Blinding Assault (Recharge 5-6). The swarm specifically targets the eyes and faces of all creatures in its space. Each creature in the swarm's space must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 10 (3d6) slashing damage and is blinded until the end of its next turn. On a success, the creature takes half damage and is not blinded.

Tactics

Swarms occupy a spellcaster's space and use Blinding Assault to shut them down. They're resistant to weapon attacks but vulnerable to area-of-effect spells like burning hands or shatter. Multiple swarms can emerge from the dining room during Yackle Phase 2.

---

Encounter Building with House Horrors

Suggested Encounters for The Witch's Wake:

Early Exploration (CR 2-3 total)

  • 1 Animated Furniture (chair ambush in parlor)
  • 2 Creeping Shadows (stalking in dim hallways)
  • 1 Malevolent Portrait (in the gallery)

Mid-Adventure (CR 4-5 total)

  • 1 Strangling Carpet + 2 Animated Furniture
  • 1 Living Chandelier + 1 Swarm of Silverware (dining room)
  • 2 Possessed Mirrors + 2 Creeping Shadows (creates duplicates)

Yackle Phase 2 (CR 7-8 total, alongside Yackle herself)

  • The Grandfather Clock + 2 Animated Furniture + 1 Living Chandelier
  • OR: 3 Malevolent Portraits + 2 Swarms of Silverware + 1 Strangling Carpet
  • OR: Mix and match based on which rooms the party has cleared

Scaling Tip: When Yackle merges with the house (Phase 2), she can summon House Horrors as a lair action. Start with 2-3 horrors present, then add 1-2 more every 2-3 rounds to maintain pressure without overwhelming.

---

Destroying House Horrors Permanently

House Horrors are sustained by Yackle's magic. While she lives, destroyed horrors can reform given enough time (1d4 days). Once Yackle is defeated in Phase 3, all House Horrors collapse into mundane objects and cannot reanimate.

Temporary Measures:

  • Dispel magic can incapacitate most horrors for 1 minute
  • Destroying the physical object works but Yackle can replace them
  • Trapping horrors in rooms and barricading doors buys time
  • Fire, acid, and radiant damage leave permanent marks even if the horror reforms

Permanent Solution: Defeat Yackle.

---

Roleplaying House Horrors

House Horrors aren't intelligent (except the Grandfather Clock and Possessed Mirrors, which have limited cunning). Describe them as:

  • Moving with jerky, unnatural motions
  • Making grinding, creaking, or scraping sounds
  • Attacking with mechanical persistence—no fear, no hesitation
  • Collapsing into inert objects when destroyed (the chair falls apart, the shadow dissipates)

The house itself is Yackle's body during Phase 2. When House Horrors attack, it's the manor striking like an immune system defending against infection.

---

Related Pages

  • Yackle - Their creator and mistress
  • The Witch's Wake - Adventure where they appear
  • Quick Reference - GM tools

lore/the-eight-bindings.title: The Eight Bindings
lore/the-eight-bindings.content:
The Eight Bindings of Lurline

"Before the Fairy Queen came, there was only the Void—shapeless, endless, consuming. Lurline brought order. She brought the Bindings. She made Oz real."

GM NOTE: This page contains deep lore for "The Witch's Wake" adventure. The Eight Bindings are the cosmological foundation that Yackle seeks to break. Understanding these principles is crucial for running the adventure and understanding each character's secret.

The Kumbric Void

Before Lurline the Fairy Queen shaped Oz into existence, there was the Kumbric Void—a realm of undifferentiated potential, pure chaos where nothing was fixed. Time did not flow forward. Identity did not persist. Cause and effect were suggestions, not laws. Nothing could be in any meaningful sense because existence itself had no structure.

The Void was not evil—it was pre-moral, a state before concepts like good and bad had meaning. It was potential without form, hunger without object, becoming without direction.

And within it dwelt the Kumbric Witch—not a person but a process, the Void's own will toward undoing, dissolution, return to formlessness.

Lurline's Act of Creation

When Lurline came to create Oz, she did not create from nothing. She bound the chaos. She imposed eight fundamental principles—the Eight Bindings—that gave reality its shape, its consistency, its meaning.

These are not laws of physics. They are deeper than that—metaphysical truths that make existence itself possible. Without them, Oz would dissolve back into the Void.

To impose the Bindings, Lurline had to overcome the Kumbric Witch. The details are lost to legend, but the result is known: Lurline shattered the Witch into fragments and scattered them across Oz, each shard bound by the very principles it had sought to resist.

One of those fragments became Yackle.

The Eight Bindings

Each Binding establishes a fundamental truth about how reality works in Oz. Breaking even one would begin unraveling the fabric of existence.

1. The Binding of Memory

Principle: The past is real and shapes the present.

What It Establishes:

  • Time flows forward; what has happened cannot be unwritten
  • Events create consequences that persist
  • History is objective—it can be forgotten, but not unmade
  • Memory connects who you were to who you are

What It Prevents:

  • Retroactive alteration of events
  • Existence without past
  • Causality flowing backward
  • Complete dissolution of identity through memory loss

Inversion: A person who creates a false past so convincingly it becomes their present. Someone who lives a lie so thoroughly that fabricated history shapes real consequence. Example: Averic the Scholar forged letters from his mentor, creating a false past that defined his entire career.

2. The Binding of Blood

Principle: Lineage connects beings across time; ancestry is fixed.

What It Establishes:

  • Biological descent creates unbreakable bonds
  • Family lines persist across generations
  • You are connected to those who came before
  • Bloodlines carry meaning, power, obligation

What It Prevents:

  • Spontaneous generation without ancestry
  • Claiming false lineage as biological truth
  • Severing all connection to one's origins
  • Existence without genealogical context

Inversion: A person who claims a bloodline that doesn't exist and knows it's false. Someone who builds their entire identity on ancestry they don't possess. Example: Liir the Heir knows his Ostrega lineage claim is fraudulent but perpetuates it anyway.

3. The Binding of Nature

Principle: All beings are their kind; nothing can be other than what it is.

What It Establishes:

  • Species categories are real and stable
  • An Animal is an Animal, a human is human
  • Essential nature persists even if hidden
  • You cannot fundamentally become something you are not

What It Prevents:

  • Complete transformation into a different kind of being
  • Existence without essential nature
  • Perfect disguise that changes what you are, not just how you appear
  • Beings existing as multiple contradictory things simultaneously

Inversion: A being who is other than what they appear, living in constant denial of their essential nature. Someone whose every moment contradicts what they fundamentally are. Example: Frederick/Quick-Paw is a Fox Animal passing as human, denying his nature every second.

4. The Binding of Service

Principle: Duty creates meaning through bonds; power without obligation is chaos.

What It Establishes:

  • Service creates reciprocal relationships
  • Faithful duty is rewarded with care and belonging
  • Institutions honor those who serve them
  • Obligation binds communities together meaningfully

What It Prevents:

  • Service that creates no bond
  • Duty without reciprocal obligation from those served
  • Loyalty punished rather than rewarded
  • Power wielded without any responsibility

Inversion: Someone who served faithfully and was betrayed by those they served. A person whose duty created no bond, only exile. Example: Sister Shell the Maunt was expelled for exposing her order's crimes—faithful service rewarded with exile.

5. The Binding of Sacrifice

Principle: Giving freely creates value; you cannot gain without loss.

What It Establishes:

  • True sacrifice is given, not taken
  • Power earned through giving has meaning
  • What you receive must be balanced by what you offer
  • Gifts freely given create bonds and obligations

What It Prevents:

  • Gain without any cost
  • Taking disguised as giving
  • Power through pure transaction rather than sacrifice
  • Magic without price or offering

Inversion: Someone whose power comes from transaction, not gift. A person who traded rather than sacrificed, who bought rather than earned. Example: Sarima's magic came from a deal she made, not a gift freely given.

6. The Binding of Deed

Principle: Actions shape the actor; what you do becomes what you are.

What It Establishes:

  • Deeds have consequences that transform the doer
  • Great acts make you heroic; atrocities make you monstrous
  • Your actions accumulate into identity
  • What you choose to do defines who you become

What It Prevents:

  • Actions without consequence to the actor
  • Committing atrocity and remaining unchanged
  • Deeds that don't shape character
  • External identity completely divorced from actions

Inversion: Someone who committed an act that should have transformed them into a monster but remained unchanged. A person whose deed didn't define them. Example: Captain Mareth ordered a massacre and remained, outwardly and inwardly, the same capable officer.

7. The Binding of Hunger

Principle: Desire drives becoming, not consumption; want must create, not devour.

What It Establishes:

  • Hunger exists only in living things capable of growth
  • Desire pushes beings toward transformation and development
  • Want is productive—it builds, creates, seeks
  • Only things capable of becoming can truly want

What It Prevents:

  • Hunger without the capacity for growth
  • Desire in things that cannot become
  • Want that only consumes, never creates
  • Non-living things experiencing need

Inversion: A being that isn't alive but hungers anyway. Something incapable of becoming that wants. Example: Seven the Tiktok feels emotions, curiosity, loneliness—desires that machines shouldn't be capable of.

8. The Binding of Witness

Principle: To exist is to be truly seen; you cannot be real while remaining unknown.

What It Establishes:

  • True existence requires being witnessed by others
  • To be real is to be known, at least potentially
  • Hiding your essential self diminishes your reality
  • Authentic existence means being seeable as what you are

What It Prevents:

  • Full existence while remaining completely hidden
  • Being real while never being authentically seen
  • A thousand years of masks with no true face beneath
  • Existence entirely divorced from witness

Inversion: Someone who has existed for a millennium and never been truly seen. A being whose entire existence is disguise, performance, masks upon masks. Example: Yackle herself embodies this—she cannot exist authentically, only in disguise.

Why the Bindings Matter

The Eight Bindings are not arbitrary rules—they are the foundation of reality in Oz. They make the world coherent:

  • Memory ensures history matters
  • Blood creates generational continuity
  • Nature establishes stable categories of existence
  • Service binds society together
  • Sacrifice gives meaning to exchange
  • Deed connects action to consequence
  • Hunger drives growth and transformation
  • Witness makes existence authentic

Without them, Oz would return to the Kumbric Void—a place of pure potential with no actuality, endless becoming with no being, chaos without form.

Yackle's Prison

Yackle is a shard of the Kumbric Witch—the primordial being Lurline shattered to create Oz. She is not entirely of this world; she is a fragment of the chaos that existed before the Bindings.

The eighth Binding—Witness—is her specific prison:

  • She can exist, but only in disguise
  • She can interact with the world, but never authentically
  • She has worn a thousand faces in a thousand years
  • She has never been known, truly seen for what she is
  • Every relationship is performance; every connection is mask

Yackle is utterly, profoundly alone. She has been alone for a millennium, unable to exist as herself, unable to die, unable to escape. She is trapped between existence and non-existence, real enough to suffer but not real enough to end.

Why Yackle Wants to Break the Bindings

Yackle does not want power. She does not want freedom, exactly. She wants dissolution—oblivion, the end of her tormented half-existence.

The only way to achieve this is to break the Bindings themselves. If she can undo Lurline's work, reality will begin to unravel. The structure that keeps her trapped will fail. And in the return to the Kumbric Void, she will finally, finally cease to be.

She is so tired. She has been lonely for a thousand years. She wants it to end.

The Eight Inversions

To break a Binding, Yackle needs a living embodiment of its corruption—someone whose very existence inverts the principle.

This is not simple violation. Many people lie about the past (Memory), or disguise themselves (Nature), or fail to fulfill obligations (Service). But those are just breaches, temporary and individual.

What Yackle needs is someone who lives the inversion so thoroughly that their entire existence is a contradiction of the Binding. Someone whose secret is not just a lie but a fundamental impossibility that shouldn't be able to exist under the Binding's rules.

The eight characters Yackle has summoned to her estate are these inversions:

Binding Character How They Invert It
Memory Averic Created a false past that defines his present
Blood Liir Claims ancestry he knows is false
Nature Frederick Is other than what he appears every moment
Service Shell Faithful service rewarded with betrayal
Sacrifice Sarima Power bought through transaction, not given
Deed Mareth Committed atrocity and remained unchanged
Hunger Seven Machine that wants, feels, hungers
Witness Yackle Exists only in disguise, never truly seen

How Collecting Secrets Breaks the Bindings

When a character's secret is freely revealed (through confession, discovery, or Yackle's extraction), she gains power over the Binding that secret inverts:

  1. The Secret Is Spoken: When the truth becomes known, it exists in the world as witnessed fact
  2. The Inversion Manifests: The contradiction between what the Binding says should be true and what actually exists becomes undeniable
  3. The Binding Weakens: That specific principle begins to fray at its edges
  4. Yackle Gains Power: She can manipulate the weakened Binding—altering memories, corrupting lineages, forcing transformations, etc.

If she collects all eight secrets, all eight Bindings fail simultaneously. Reality begins to unravel. The Kumbric Void seeps back into Oz. And Yackle can finally dissolve into the chaos that existed before creation.

The Tragedy of Yackle

Yackle is the villain of "The Witch's Wake," but she is not evil in any simple sense. She is:

  • Profoundly lonely—a thousand years without being truly known
  • Trapped—unable to exist authentically, unable to die
  • Desperate—not for power but for an end to her suffering
  • Sympathetic—her goal (oblivion) comes from understandable pain
  • Monstrous—willing to destroy all of Oz to achieve her dissolution

She has summoned eight people, learned their deepest shames, and will use them to unmake reality itself. She will kill them if necessary. She will manipulate, betray, and destroy.

But she does it not from cruelty—from exhaustion. She just wants it to end.

The players must stop her. Oz must not return to the Void. But understanding why she's doing this might change how the final confrontation unfolds.

GM Usage

When to Reveal This Lore

This information should come in pieces:

  • Early Game: References to Lurline creating Oz, basic fairy tale knowledge
  • Library Discovery: Books about the Kumbric Void, pre-Lurline chaos, the Eight Bindings as cosmological principles
  • Mid-Game: Yackle's nature as a shard of the Kumbric Witch, why she needs the secrets
  • The Reveal: When Yackle shows herself, she might explain her goal—not conquest but oblivion
  • Final Confrontation: The full tragedy of her existence, her loneliness, her desperate need to end

Using the Bindings Mechanically

As Yackle collects secrets, she can manipulate the corresponding Binding:

  • Memory: Alter characters' recollections, make them forget crucial information, create false memories
  • Blood: Sever family bonds, corrupt lineages, make the Heir literally no one's descendant
  • Nature: Force Frederick's true form to show, trap him between shapes, make nature itself uncertain
  • Service: Break oaths, corrupt healing magic, make Shell's powers turn against her
  • Sacrifice: Steal Sarima's pact magic, force transactions instead of gifts, corrupt all exchanges
  • Deed: Make Mareth's actions meaningless, prevent consequences from sticking, erase cause and effect
  • Hunger: Trap Seven in existential loops, deny their consciousness, or force them to confront it unbearably
  • Witness: Become invisible, exist in multiple places, make herself impossible to pin down

Themes to Emphasize

  • Loneliness: Yackle has been alone for a millennium; the characters have secrets that isolate them
  • Identity: What makes you real—your past, your blood, your nature, your deeds?
  • Authenticity: The cost of hiding who you are, the terror and relief of being seen
  • Sacrifice vs. Transaction: What's the difference between giving and taking? Does intent matter?
  • The Weight of Consequences: Do deeds define you? Should they? What if they don't?

Related Pages

  • Yackle - The villain who seeks to break the Bindings
  • Lurline - The Fairy Queen who created the Bindings
  • The Witch's Wake - The adventure centered on the Bindings
  • The Seven Seals - Challenges representing the first seven Bindings
  • The Kumbric Void - The chaos before creation

adventures/the-witchs-wake/the-seven-sea.title: The Seven Seals
adventures/the-witchs-wake/the-seven-sea.content:
The Seven Seals

"To claim the inheritance, you must prove yourselves worthy. Unlock all seven seals before dawn, and the estate is yours."

GM NOTE: This page explains the Seven Seals system for "The Witch's Wake" adventure. Each seal represents one of the first seven Bindings and provides both immediate rewards and powerful abilities if all are completed before the final battle. The eighth seal is the Heart Chamber itself—when confronted, the Binding of Witness breaks.

IMPORTANT: Players will likely NOT complete all seven seals before Yackle reveals herself. The timeline expects 4-5 seals completed by the reveal. This creates tactical tension: rush to finish seals during the chase, or focus on survival?

Overview

The Seven Seals are magical puzzles scattered throughout Yackle's estate. Each seal corresponds to one of Lurline's Eight Bindings (specifically, the first seven—the eighth, Witness, is embodied by Yackle herself).

When the players arrive, Mr. Trism (the solicitor) reads Yackle's will, which states:

"The estate and its contents shall pass to those who prove themselves worthy. To demonstrate worthiness, the heirs must unlock all seven seals before dawn. The one who proves most worthy shall claim the greatest share."

This is, of course, a lie. The seals aren't an inheritance test—they're a distraction and a way to weaken the Bindings. But the players don't know that yet.

The Dual Purpose

What the Players Think: Breaking seals proves worthiness and unlocks inheritance.

The Truth: Each seal broken weakens the corresponding Binding, making it easier for Yackle to collect that character's secret and ultimately break the Binding entirely. However, breaking seals also grants the players powerful rewards—tools they'll desperately need in the final battle.

Seal Locations and Bindings

Seal Binding Location Puzzle Type
1. Memory The past is real Music Room Reconstruct fragmented sheet music
2. Blood Lineage is fixed Portrait Gallery Complete the family tree
3. Nature Beings are their kind Library Mirror reflection reveals truth
4. Service Duty creates bonds Servant Quarters → Memorial Room Two-part: Answer the bell, honor the dead
5. Sacrifice Giving creates value Chapel Give freely without expectation
6. Deed Actions shape you Hall of Mirrors Acknowledge what you've done
7. Hunger Desire drives becoming Dining Room Choose what you truly want

How Seals Work

Breaking a Seal

Each seal has a specific puzzle or challenge that must be solved. When a seal is broken:

  1. Visual Effect: The room shimmers, magical energy releases, something clicks into place
  2. Immediate Reward: One character (usually the one who solved it, or the one most connected to that Binding) receives an Individual Reward
  3. Seal Mark: That character gains a glowing mark somewhere on their body (subtle, like a tattoo)—this tracks who has completed which seals
  4. Completion Tracking: The party is one step closer to the Seal Mastery bonus

The Two-Level Reward System

Individual Rewards (Immediate): Granted as soon as a seal is broken. Usable for the rest of the session.

Seal Mastery (If All Seven Complete): If the party completes all seven seals before defeating Yackle, they gain powerful abilities specifically designed to counter her.

Individual Rewards

When a seal is broken, one character gains an immediate benefit:

Seal Reward Effect
1. Memory Reroll Token Reroll one failed d20 roll (attack, save, or check). Use before the result is determined. Once per session.
2. Blood Death's Denial The first time you drop to 0 HP, you automatically stabilize at 0 HP (don't make death saves). You're unconscious but won't die from failed saves.
3. Nature True Sight Token Gain advantage on one Insight check of your choice. This check automatically sees through lies and illusions.
4. Service Swift Aid For the rest of the session, you can use the Help action as a bonus action instead of an action.
5. Sacrifice Last Strike When you drop to 0 HP, you can immediately make one weapon attack or cast one cantrip as a reaction before falling unconscious.
6. Deed Resolve Token Reroll one failed saving throw. Use after you see the result. Once per session.
7. Hunger Second Wind As a bonus action, you can recover one spent Hit Die and immediately roll it, regaining that many HP + your Constitution modifier.

GM Note: Let the players decide who gets each reward, or if they can't decide, award it to the character whose secret most closely aligns with that Binding (e.g., Averic gets Memory, Liir gets Blood, etc.).

Seal Mastery Abilities

If the party completes all seven seals before the final battle with Yackle begins, they unlock Seal Mastery—powerful abilities specifically designed to counter Yackle's mechanics.

CRITICAL BONUS: If all seven seals are completed before engaging Yackle in Phase 1, she starts combat at half HP (100 instead of 200).

Individual Seal Mastery Powers

Each completed seal grants a specific anti-Yackle ability to whoever received the Individual Reward from that seal:

Seal Mastery Ability Effect vs. Yackle
Memory Truth of the Past Once per battle, you can force Yackle to reroll one attack roll or ability check and take the lower result.
Blood Severed Lineage Yackle's necrotic damage against you is reduced by half (round down).
Nature True Form Yackle cannot use illusion magic or change her appearance while you can see her. She must remain in her true form.
Service Broken Oath Any creature dominated or charmed by Yackle can repeat their saving throw at the start of each of their turns (instead of only when damaged).
Sacrifice Gift Freely Given When you cast a healing spell on an ally within 30 feet, they heal an additional 1d6 HP.
Deed Weight of Action Yackle has disadvantage on the first attack roll she makes each round.
Hunger Denied Consumption Yackle cannot use legendary actions during the first round of each combat phase.

Why This Matters

Seal Mastery makes the final battle significantly more survivable:

  • Half HP means Phase 1 is much shorter
  • Disadvantage on her first attack each round reduces incoming damage
  • No legendary actions in round 1 gives players setup time
  • True Form prevents her from using illusions to confuse the party
  • Broken Oath lets dominated allies break free faster
  • Enhanced healing from Sacrifice keeps the party alive longer
  • Forced rerolls from Memory can prevent devastating crits
  • Reduced necrotic damage from Blood keeps the tank alive

The challenge: completing all seven seals before Yackle reveals herself (end of Hour 3) is difficult. Players must balance exploration, puzzle-solving, and social interaction.

Seal Details

Seal 1: Memory (Music Room)

Binding: The past is real and shapes the present.

Puzzle: Reconstruct a fragmented musical composition.

  • Sheet music fragments are scattered across the Music Room, Parlor, and Foyer
  • Players must gather all pieces (Investigation DC 14, 10 minutes)
  • Arrange them in correct order (Intelligence DC 12 or proficiency in musical instrument)
  • Play the melody on the grand piano (Performance DC 10, or automatic with instrument proficiency)

Handout: Provide 4-5 physical sheet music fragments. Highlighted notes spell "REMEMBER" when arranged correctly.

Success: The music box opens, revealing a Memory Shard (glowing green crystal, useful in final battle). One character gains the Reroll Token.

Theme: Reconstructing the past from fragments—literally putting memory back together.

Seal 2: Blood (Portrait Gallery)

Binding: Lineage connects beings across time; ancestry is fixed.

Puzzle: Complete the Ostrega family tree.

  • The gallery contains portraits of the Ostrega family spanning centuries
  • A large family tree diagram has several names missing
  • Portraits have plaques with names and dates—players must match them to fill the gaps
  • Investigation DC 12 to find all relevant portraits
  • Intelligence DC 10 to correctly place names in the tree
  • Complication: One name (Yackle's original mortal name: "Yael Ostrega") appears impossibly early and impossibly late in the tree—she's both an ancestor and a descendant

Handout: Physical family tree with blank spaces. Players can write names in as they discover them.

Success: The central portrait frame opens, revealing a hidden chamber containing a Blood Phylactery (a locked containing Ostrega bloodline magic). One character gains Death's Denial.

Theme: Lineage and ancestry—but with the twist that Yackle appears in impossible places, hinting that bloodlines can be manipulated.

Seal 3: Nature (Library)

Binding: All beings are their kind; nothing can be other than what it is.

Puzzle: A magical mirror reveals true nature.

  • The library contains a large standing mirror covered by a cloth
  • When uncovered, the mirror shows each character's "true self"—not their disguise or performance, but what they actually are
  • Frederick (the Fox Animal) sees his true fox form
  • Other characters see symbolic representations of their secrets
  • To break the seal, one character must look into the mirror and accept what they see—speak aloud an acknowledgment of their true nature

Handout: Descriptive cards for what each character sees in the mirror (given privately to each player).

Success: The mirror shatters, reforming into a Shard of Truth (can be used to see through illusions). One character gains True Sight Token.

Theme: Confronting who you really are beneath the masks and performances.

Danger: If Frederick looks in the mirror, his disguise might flicker—other characters might see his true fox form reflected.

Seal 4: Service (Servant Quarters → Memorial Room)

Binding: Duty creates meaning through bonds; power without obligation is chaos.

Puzzle: A two-part challenge about service and remembrance.

Part 1 - Servant Quarters:

  • A bell-pull hangs in the servant quarters, labeled "Ring for Service"
  • When pulled, a spectral servant (ghost of someone who died serving Yackle) appears
  • The ghost asks, "How may I serve?" with genuine eagerness despite being dead
  • The correct response is NOT to give an order, but to ask: "How may I serve YOU?"
  • This reversal of the expected power dynamic is key

Part 2 - Memorial Room:

  • The ghost leads players to a hidden Memorial Room where dozens of servants who died in Yackle's service are commemorated
  • Many died serving her willingly, others were trapped, all are forgotten
  • To complete the seal, players must honor the dead—speak their names aloud (reading from plaques), offer a moment of silence, or perform a small ritual of remembrance

Handout: "Names of the Lost" - a list of servants with brief descriptions of how they died in service.

Success: The ghost thanks them and fades peacefully. The room fills with warm light. One character gains Swift Aid.

Theme: True service is reciprocal—it creates bonds and obligations both ways. Those served owe care to those who serve.

Seal 5: Sacrifice (Chapel)

Binding: Giving freely creates value; you cannot gain without loss.

Puzzle: Give something precious without expectation of return.

  • The chapel contains an altar with a collection basin
  • An inscription reads: "True sacrifice is given freely, expecting nothing"
  • Players must place something of genuine personal value in the basin—not just gold, but something that matters
  • The item must be given willingly, without knowing if they'll get it back
  • Examples: Liir's false signet ring, Averic's forged letters, Shell's holy symbol, Frederick's disguise ring
  • GM's call on what counts as "genuine sacrifice"—it should hurt to give it up

Success: The item disappears into golden light. A moment later, it returns transformed—enhanced with magical properties that reflect the sacrifice. One character gains Last Strike.

Alternative Success: The item stays gone, but the seal breaks anyway. Sometimes sacrifice doesn't return what was given—that's the point.

Theme: True giving means risking loss. Sacrifice isn't transactional.

Connection: This directly challenges Sarima's transactional magic—can she give without demanding return?

Seal 6: Deed (Hall of Mirrors)

Binding: Actions shape the actor; what you do becomes what you are.

Puzzle: Confront what you've done and acknowledge it.

  • The Hall of Mirrors shows each character reflections of their significant deeds—both good and bad
  • Mareth sees Red Clay Fork—the burning village, the faces of those he ordered killed
  • Other characters see their own pivotal moments: Averic forging letters, Shell exposing the mauntery, etc.
  • To break the seal, one character must stand before their reflection and speak aloud what they did—not justification, not excuse, just acknowledgment
  • "I ordered the massacre of Red Clay Fork. I killed 143 people."
  • "I forged my mentor's letters. I built my career on lies."

Success: The mirrors shatter. The weight of deed doesn't disappear, but it's acknowledged—no longer hidden. One character gains Resolve Token.

Theme: Deeds do shape you, but denying them doesn't unmake them. Acknowledgment is the first step toward transformation.

Danger: This room can trigger confessions, emotional breakdowns, or party conflict if characters judge each other harshly.

Seal 7: Hunger (Dining Room)

Binding: Desire drives becoming, not consumption; want must create, not devour.

Puzzle: Choose what you truly want, not what you think you should want.

  • A feast appears on the dining table—food, drink, and at each place setting, a small box
  • Each box contains something the character wants: wealth, power, knowledge, freedom, redemption, etc.
  • The boxes are labeled with names, but not the obvious ones—they're labeled with what each character secretly hungers for
  • Seven's box: "To Be Real"
  • Frederick's box: "To Stop Hiding"
  • Shell's box: "To Know Why"
  • To break the seal, characters must choose to open their box and admit they want what's inside—not need, not deserve, but want

Success: The boxes open. Inside: nothing tangible, but a profound sense of clarity about their own desires. One character gains Second Wind.

Alternative: The boxes contain symbolic items (a key, a mirror, a letter) that represent the path toward what they hunger for.

Theme: Acknowledging desire is not weakness. Hunger drives growth. Wanting is not the same as consuming.

THE REVEAL: This is often when Yackle reveals herself. The Dining Room is her domain, and when the party shows their hungers openly, she appears: "How wonderful. You've made this so much easier."

Timing and Pacing

Expected Progression

  • Hour 1 (Arrival): 1-2 seals (Memory and/or Blood)
  • Hour 2 (Exploration): 2-3 more seals (Nature, Service, maybe Sacrifice)
  • Hour 3 (Escalation): 1-2 more seals (Deed, possibly Hunger)
  • THE REVEAL: Yackle shows herself, usually during or right after Seal 7
  • Hour 4 (Battle): Fighting Yackle, possibly completing remaining seals during the chase

If Players Are Slow

Some groups get distracted by roleplay, investigation, or caution. If they've only completed 2-3 seals by Hour 3:

  • Yackle can still reveal herself (she's impatient)
  • During Phase 2 (the chase), players can complete remaining seals while fleeing
  • Some seals might be skipped entirely—that's okay, it makes the final battle harder but still winnable

If Players Rush

If players focus entirely on seals and complete 5-6 before Hour 3:

  • Reward their efficiency—they're setting themselves up for success
  • Yackle might reveal herself early to prevent them from finishing all seven
  • The final battle will be easier, which is their reward for smart play

GM Tips

Rewarding Clever Solutions

If players solve a seal in an unexpected but thematically appropriate way, reward it. The seals aren't about strict mechanics—they're about engaging with the themes of the Bindings.

Failed Seal Attempts

If players completely misunderstand a seal puzzle:

  • Give hints through environmental details
  • Have Mr. Trism or Madame Viridian (Yackle in disguise) offer cryptic guidance
  • Allow Intelligence/Wisdom checks to gain insight
  • Let them try multiple approaches—seals don't "lock out" after failed attempts

Tracking Completion

Keep a visible tracker for the players—they should know how many seals they've completed and how many remain. This creates urgency and helps them make tactical decisions.

The Eighth Seal

Players will notice there are only seven seals but eight Bindings. If they ask:

  • Mr. Trism says the will only mentions seven
  • Clever players might deduce that the eighth (Witness) is different
  • The truth: the eighth seal is Yackle herself—when they confront her true form, that Binding breaks

After the Seals

Once seals are broken, they stay broken—the benefits persist for the rest of the session. Players should feel increasingly powerful as they complete more seals, building confidence for the final confrontation.

But remember: each broken seal also weakens the corresponding Binding, making it easier for Yackle to extract that character's secret. The tools they're gaining to fight her are also the tools she needs to unmake reality.

The tragedy is that the players are helping her even as they prepare to stop her.

Related Pages

  • The Eight Bindings - The cosmological principles the seals represent
  • Yackle's Estate - Room descriptions and seal locations
  • Yackle - The villain who created the seals
  • The Witch's Wake - Main adventure page
  • Quick Reference - GM cheat sheet with seal DCs

adventures/the-witchs-wake/yackles-estat.title: Yackle's Estate
adventures/the-witchs-wake/yackles-estat.content:
Yackle's Estate

"The manor has stood in the Pertha Hills for over a thousand years. They say it changes—rooms appear and disappear, corridors twist back on themselves. They say it's alive. They might be right."

GM NOTE: This estate is the primary location for "The Witch's Wake" adventure. The house is semi-sentient, responding to its occupants and reflecting Yackle's millennium of loneliness. Rooms contain clues about the Eight Bindings, the Seven Seals, and Yackle's tragic history.

IMPORTANT: The estate has 22 rooms total. Players will likely explore 12-15 before the reveal. Encourage thorough investigation—every room rewards curiosity.

Estate Overview

Yackle's Estate sits in the remote Pertha Hills of Gillikin, surrounded by fog that never lifts and hedges that once depicted magnificent Animals but now grow wild. The architecture is old Gillikinese—steep gables, narrow windows, impossible angles that don't quite meet correctly.

The estate has four distinct areas:

  • The Grounds: The Approach, Cemetery
  • Ground Floor: Foyer, Parlor, Music Room, Library, Chapel, Dining Room, Kitchen, Servant Quarters, Greenhouse (9 rooms)
  • Upper Floors: Portrait Gallery, Memorial Room, Master Bedroom, Guest Rooms 1-3, Nursery, Study, Observatory, Hall of Mirrors (10 rooms)
  • The Cellar: Wine Cellar, Main Cellar, Heart Chamber (3 rooms)

The House's Nature

The estate is semi-sentient, an extension of Yackle herself:

  • Responsive: The house provides what occupants need (warmth, food) but also tests them
  • Observant: Characters often feel watched (they are—the house watches)
  • Temporal Distortion: Time moves strangely; hours can feel like minutes or vice versa
  • No Escape: Once inside, the gates won't open until dawn or until Yackle is defeated
  • Lair Actions: During combat, the house itself attacks (see Yackle's stat block)
---

The Grounds

The Approach

Read Aloud:

The carriage path winds through overgrown hedges that might once have been sculpted into fanciful shapes—Animals, perhaps, or scenes from Ozian mythology. Now they're just walls of tangled green, pressing close on either side. The fog thickens as you approach, and the temperature drops noticeably. Ahead, iron gates stand open, and beyond them, the manor rises against a bruised purple sky. It's larger than you expected. The architecture is old Gillikinese—all steep gables and narrow windows—but something about the proportions feels wrong. The angles don't quite meet where they should.

Key Features

The Gates. Wrought iron, standing open. Once a character passes through, they swing shut silently and will not open again by any means. The lock cannot be picked (no DC—simply impossible). A knock spell causes the gates to shudder but not open. Attempting to climb over results in the character finding themselves back on the inside.

The Hedges. A DC 14 Nature check reveals these were once shaped like Animals—Lions, Bears, a great Eagle. Now they're wild, but the shapes are still vaguely visible if you know to look.

  • Perception DC 16: One hedge shows a Fox mid-leap, frozen in topiary. The eyes seem to follow Frederick if he's present.
  • Investigation DC 15: Carved into the base of the Lion hedge: "For those who cannot speak, I gave voice. For those who were unseen, I made them seen. —L.T." (Lurline's Testament)
  • Arcana DC 14: The hedges radiate faint abjuration magic—they're a ward, keeping something in or something out.

The Fog. Extends about 20 feet beyond the walls. A character who enters the fog must make a DC 15 Constitution save each round or begin suffocating. After three failed saves, they fall unconscious and are expelled back onto the estate grounds.

  • Perception DC 13: Shapes move in the fog—humanoid, but wrong. They never get closer.
  • Arcana DC 18: The fog is not natural weather—it's solidified memory, fragments of past events made semi-physical.

The Carriage Path.

  • Survival DC 12: No wheel ruts, no hoof prints. No one has used this path in decades. Except... there ARE fresh footprints. Eight sets. Leading in. None leading out.
  • Investigation DC 14: The footprints match the party's boots exactly, down to the wear patterns. They were here before you arrived.
---

The Cemetery

Read Aloud:

A low iron fence surrounds a small family plot to the west of the main house. The headstones are old—some cracked, some sunken into the earth—but the names are still legible. OSTREGA, they all read. Generations of them. The newest stone looks perhaps a century old. There are fresh flowers on one grave, impossibly fresh, as if placed this morning. But no one has lived here in decades.

Key Features

The Headstones. The Ostrega family burial plot. A DC 12 History check reveals the Ostregas were a minor Gillikinese family who died out about a century ago—no living descendants. Liir's player may find this concerning.

  • Investigation DC 13: The dates are wrong. "Yael Ostrega, 621-643" is carved on one stone, but another stone fifty feet away reads "Yael Ostrega, 804-831." The same name, two centuries apart.
  • Religion DC 14: The grave markers use both Lurlinite and Unionist symbols, sometimes on the same stone—theologically impossible. Someone was hedging their bets about the afterlife.
  • Perception DC 15: One grave is sunken differently than the others—deeper, as if something much larger than a body is buried there. The headstone reads simply: "The First Mask."

The Fresh Flowers. On the grave of "Yael Ostrega, Beloved Daughter." A DC 14 Investigation check finds that the flowers are real but have no roots—they're simply placed here. A DC 16 Arcana check reveals faint necromantic magic. Someone has been maintaining this grave.

  • Nature DC 12: These are ghost-breath flowers, which only bloom in the presence of the dead. But they're blooming at the wrong angle—toward the house, not the grave.
  • Insight DC 16: The flowers are an offering, but also an apology. Someone has been saying sorry for a very long time.

HANDOUT: Gravestone Rubbing. If a character makes a rubbing of any headstone, provide a physical handout showing the Ostrega family crest (a key crossed with a quill) and dates spanning from 600s to 900s OZ calendar.

The Iron Fence.

  • Perception DC 11: The fence posts are topped with finials shaped like eyes—dozens of them, all facing inward, watching the graves.
  • Investigation DC 17: Scratched into the back of one fence post, nearly invisible: "She visits every night. She never speaks. —Groundskeeper William, 788"
---

Ground Floor

1. The Foyer

Read Aloud:

The front doors open onto a grand entrance hall. A crystal chandelier hangs overhead, unlit, its hundreds of pendants catching what little moonlight filters through the high windows. A sweeping staircase curves upward to the left, while doorways lead off in three directions. The floor is checkered marble—green and white—worn smooth by centuries of footsteps. A grandfather clock stands against the far wall, its pendulum still. In the center of the room, someone has arranged eight chairs in a circle around a small table bearing a single leather case.

Key Features

The Chandelier. If a character looks closely (Perception DC 12), they notice the crystals are not glass but some kind of green stone. A DC 15 Arcana check identifies them as emeralds—a fortune's worth. However, any attempt to remove them causes them to crumble to worthless powder.

  • Investigation DC 14: The chandelier has exactly 808 crystals. Why that specific number? A DC 16 History check recalls 808 OZ is the year the Wizard came to power.
  • Perception DC 18: One crystal is a different color—blood red. It hangs directly above the empty ninth chair at the head of the circle.
  • Arcana DC 17: The chandelier isn't just decorative—it's a massive scrying focus. Someone could watch the entire ground floor from this central point.

The Grandfather Clock. The clock shows 11:47—always 11:47, regardless of the actual time. It has no visible winding mechanism. At midnight (real time, or when dramatically appropriate), it chimes thirteen times. This signals the First Twist.

  • Investigation DC 13: The clock face has thirteen hours marked, not twelve. The thirteenth hour is labeled with a symbol instead of a number—an eye.
  • Perception DC 16: Faint scratches inside the clock cabinet: tally marks. Hundreds of them. Someone was counting something for a very long time.
  • Arcana DC 15: The clock doesn't measure time—it measures proximity to a specific event. It's waiting for something.

The Chairs. Eight chairs, each with a name card on the seat. The names are not the characters' names but epithets:

  • "The One Who Rewrote the Past"
  • "The One Who Claims False Blood"
  • "The One Who Denies Their Nature"
  • "The One Whose Service Was Punished"
  • "The One Who Traded Instead of Gave"
  • "The One Whose Deed Did Not Transform Them"
  • "The One Who Hungers When They Should Not"
  • "The One Who Has Never Been Seen"

HANDOUT: The Place Cards. Provide physical cards with these epithets. Let players figure out which card belongs to whom.

  • Insight DC 14: These aren't accusations—they're descriptions. Whoever wrote these knows each character intimately.
  • Investigation DC 15: The handwriting on all eight cards is identical, written with the same pen, same ink pressure. They were all written at the same time, by someone who expected exactly these eight people.
  • Perception DC 13: There's a ninth chair, larger than the others, at the head of the circle. It has no name card.

The Leather Case. Contains the will. Mr. Trism will open it and read it when all eight heirs are present.

The Staircase. Leads to the upper floors. Until the First Twist, the stairs seem to go on forever—characters who climb find themselves back at the bottom. After the clock chimes, the upper floors become accessible.

  • Perception DC 12: The stairs are worn in the middle, but not evenly. The wear pattern suggests someone walking up and down the same section repeatedly—pacing, not traveling.
  • Investigation DC 16: Carved into the underside of the seventh step, invisible unless you duck underneath: "Day 217. Still here. Still alone. Still waiting. —Y.O."

The Marble Floor.

  • Investigation DC 14: The green and white pattern isn't random—it forms a massive eight-pointed star with the chair circle at its center.
  • Arcana DC 16: This pattern is a summoning circle, but inverted. It's not calling something here—it's keeping something from leaving.
---

2. The Parlor

Read Aloud:

A comfortable sitting room with faded elegance. Two sofas face each other across a low table, upholstered in purple velvet worn thin at the armrests. A fireplace dominates one wall—cold now, but logs are laid ready to burn. Above the mantle hangs a portrait of a woman in old-fashioned dress, her face obscured by a crack in the canvas that runs directly through her features. Against the far wall, a drinks cabinet stands open, bottles of amber and crimson liquid glinting in the low light. A chess board sits on a side table, mid-game.

Key Features

The Fireplace. If anyone expresses a desire for warmth (verbal or otherwise), the fire ignites itself without fuel or spark. This is the first sign the house responds to its occupants. The fire provides normal warmth and light but cannot be used to burn anything—objects placed in it simply sit there, unharmed.

  • Investigation DC 13: The logs in the hearth are made of stone, expertly carved to look like wood. They've never been real.
  • Perception DC 15: Soot stains on the mantle spell out words if you step back and squint: "WARM BODIES COLD HEART"
  • Arcana DC 14: The fire is transmutation magic, converting loneliness into heat. The more isolated a character feels, the warmer the fire burns for them.

The Portrait. Originally depicted Yackle in her mortal days. The crack appeared when she was first bound. A DC 16 Investigation check around the frame reveals a small plaque, nearly painted over: "Y.O., Age 23." A mending spell repairs the crack but reveals only a blank face—smooth, featureless, like an unfinished painting.

  • Perception DC 14: The portrait's eyes were painted, then scraped out, then repainted, then scraped out again. This happened dozens of times—someone couldn't decide if they wanted to see or be seen.
  • Insight DC 16: The woman in the portrait (before the crack) looks hopeful. Genuinely, achingly hopeful. Whatever happened to create that crack destroyed something irreplaceable.
  • History DC 15: The dress style is from approximately 650 OZ—over 300 years ago. But the paint is much older. Someone updated the portrait but kept the pose.

The Drinks Cabinet. Contains wine and spirits that are safe to consume. A DC 14 Investigation check finds a hidden compartment containing a small vial labeled "For When It Becomes Too Much"—this is a potion of dreamless sleep (8 hours of unconsciousness, no dreams, no external force can wake the drinker).

  • Investigation DC 12: Seven glasses are set out, each with a thin layer of dust. One glass is clean, recently used.
  • Perception DC 16: Inside the "dreamless sleep" vial, scratched into the glass with a diamond: "Coward's way out. Won't work anyway. Tried."
  • Arcana DC 13: The bottles rearrange themselves when no one is looking. The house is... offering? Suggesting?

The Chess Game. Mid-game, white is winning. A DC 12 Intelligence check recognizes it as a famous historical match—the "Ozma Gambit," supposedly played between Queen Ozma and the first Wizard. The game was never finished; Ozma disappeared before the final move. The white queen is positioned to checkmate in one move.

HANDOUT: The Ozma Gambit. A note tucked under the chess board explaining the game's history. The final move was never made. Someone has written in the margin: "She always knew how to win. She just chose not to."

  • Investigation DC 14: There's a second note, older, in different handwriting: "I've been playing both sides for so long I've forgotten which color I started as. Does it matter if you're always alone?"
  • Perception DC 15: One of the black pieces (a knight) has a tiny crack, recently repaired with gold—the Gillikinese art of kintsugi. Someone values broken things.
  • Insight DC 17: White could win in one move, but hasn't. Black could forfeit and end the stalemate, but hasn't. The game is frozen in possibility—neither player wants it to end, because ending means admitting you played alone.

The Sofas.

  • Perception DC 13: The wear patterns show two people sitting across from each other regularly—but the impressions are identical in depth and age. One person, sitting in both places, having a conversation with themselves.
  • Investigation DC 16: Tucked between sofa cushions: a child's drawing of two stick figures holding hands. One is labeled "Me" and the other is labeled "Friend?" The question mark is heavily traced, as if questioned many times.
---

3. The Music Room (SEAL 1: MEMORY)

Read Aloud:

Instruments line the walls of this circular room—a harp with broken strings, a violin in a glass case, a set of Quadling drums. Dominating the space is a grand piano, its lid open, keys yellowed with age. Sheet music is scattered across every surface: the piano bench, the floor, tucked into instrument cases. A mechanical music box sits on a pedestal near the window, ornate and clearly valuable. The moonlight catches something written in silver ink on the music box's lid.

Key Features

The Piano. Playable, though out of tune. A DC 12 Performance check can coax a recognizable melody from it. Playing the correct melody (see Seal puzzle below) causes the lid of the music box to open.

  • Investigation DC 13: The piano has been maintained recently—the action is oiled, the hammers are aligned. Someone still plays this.
  • Perception DC 15: Worn spots on specific keys: C, E, A, and B-flat. These four notes have been played thousands of times more than the others.
  • Performance DC 16: If you play those four notes in order (C-E-A-B♭), it spells "CRIES" in musical notation. The piano emits a soft, mournful resonance.
  • Arcana DC 14: The piano is slightly out of phase with reality. When played, it sounds in this room and simultaneously in another place—an echo of where it was originally played.

The Sheet Music. Scattered fragments of what was once a single composition. A DC 14 Investigation check, taking 10 minutes, can gather all the pieces. A DC 12 Intelligence check (or proficiency in a musical instrument) can arrange them in the correct order.

  • Investigation DC 12 (individual sheets): Each fragment has tiny annotations in the margins—"played for William's birthday, 734" or "Mother liked this part" or "alone again"
  • Perception DC 16: Some sheets have water damage—tear stains, concentrated on specific measures. Someone cried while playing particular passages.
  • Arcana DC 15: The ink used on the oldest sheets contains ground emerald—expensive and unnecessary unless you're trying to make the music literally unforgettable.

The Music Box. The lid reads "O, To Be Known" in silver script. The box is locked (or rather, sealed). Inside is a shard of green crystal that hums faintly with magic—this is a Memory Shard, useful in the final battle.

  • Investigation DC 14: The music box's mechanisms are visible through tiny crystal windows. Gears shaped like people, dancing.
  • Perception DC 17: One gear-person stands apart from the others, not touching, not moving in time with the dance.

HANDOUT: Sheet Music Fragments. Provide 4-5 physical pieces of paper with musical notation. On each piece, certain notes are circled or highlighted. When arranged correctly, the highlighted notes spell out "REMEMBER" in musical notation (each note corresponds to a letter: R-E-M-E-M-B-E-R).

SEAL OF MEMORY PUZZLE

To break the seal:

  1. Find all sheet music fragments (scattered in Music Room, Parlor, and Foyer)
  2. Arrange them in correct order (Intelligence DC 12)
  3. Play the melody on the piano (Performance DC 10, or any character with instrument proficiency)

Reward: One character gains a Reroll Token (reroll one failed d20, once).

The Harp.

  • Investigation DC 13: The strings weren't broken by age—they were cut, deliberately, with a sharp blade.
  • Perception DC 15: Carved into the harp's soundboard: "I broke you so I wouldn't play you. I play you anyway in memory."

The Violin in Glass.

  • Perception DC 14: The glass case is sealed airtight. Not to preserve the violin—to preserve the air around it, as if that air itself is precious.
  • Arcana DC 16: The air in the case still carries sound—a note held impossibly long. If you could break the seal, you'd hear the last thing played on this violin over a century ago.
---

4. The Library (SEAL 3: NATURE)

Read Aloud:

Floor-to-ceiling shelves crammed with books of every size and age. The smell of old paper and leather hangs heavy in the air. A rolling ladder leans against one shelf, its wheels rusted in place. Reading desks are positioned throughout—one holds an open journal, another a magnifying glass and a collection of specimen jars. The jars contain preserved creatures: a bird, a mouse, a snake, each floating in amber liquid. There's something unsettling about their eyes.

Key Features

The Books. Thousands of volumes on every subject. A character who searches for specific information can make an Investigation check:

  • DC 12: Find general information about Ozian history, geography, or magic
  • DC 15: Find references to "The Eight Bindings" or "Lurline's Words"
  • DC 18: Find Yackle's personal journals (see below)
  • Perception DC 13: The books reorganize themselves when you're not looking. Titles that were on the top shelf are now at eye level. The library is... helping?
  • Investigation DC 15: One entire shelf is devoted to texts about consciousness, personhood, and what makes something "alive." Heavy annotations throughout—arguments in the margins, underlines, angry cross-outs.
  • Arcana DC 14: Several books are written in a language that shifts as you read it, trying to translate itself into something you'll understand. They're Grimmerie fragments.
  • History DC 16: A series of books titled "Visitors, Vol. 1-47" catalog every person who's come to the estate. The latest entry is dated three weeks ago—right before the invitations went out.

Yackle's Journals. Scattered throughout the library, spanning centuries. Each is written in the same handwriting. A DC 14 Investigation check finds three journals from different eras. A DC 16 History check recognizes the dates span over 600 years—impossibly long for any mortal.

HANDOUT: Journal Excerpts. Three physical pages:

Journal 1 (Year 347 OZ):

"The fairy spoke Eight Words, and the chaos took shape. I remember the first word. It was REMEMBER. And suddenly there was a past, where before there had been only the eternal present..."

Journal 2 (Year 612 OZ):

"I have tried to die. The knife turned aside. The poison became water in my throat. The fall ended in soft landing. I cannot unmake myself. The Binding of Witness holds: I exist because I am unseen. If anyone truly SAW me, perhaps..."

Journal 3 (Year 901 OZ):

"What do I want? I want to... I cannot write it. The word starts with L and ends with everything."
  • Insight DC 15: The handwriting changes subtly between journals—not aging, but mood. The 347 journal is curious. The 612 journal is desperate. The 901 journal is tired beyond measure.
  • Investigation DC 17: There are more journals—dozens more. A DC 20 Investigation check finds Journal 47 (Year 954): "They're coming. I sent for them. Eight inversions. Eight keys. Finally, finally, an end."

The Specimen Jars. Eight jars containing preserved creatures. A DC 14 Nature or Insight check reveals that four of them are Animals (capital A, sentient) and four are animals (lowercase, ordinary). The Animals are preserved in positions of dignity—eyes closed, peaceful. The animals are posed more carelessly.

  • Perception DC 13: The Animal jars have tiny plaques at their bases, nearly microscopic: "Whisper the Wren," "Councillor Burroughs," "Poet Sleen," "Ambassador Kinderly"—titles given to people, not things.
  • Nature DC 16: These Animals didn't die of natural causes. They were killed, then preserved immediately—almost lovingly, as if in apology.
  • Insight DC 17: This isn't a collection of specimens. It's a memorial. Someone wanted to remember these specific individuals, to prove they were people, even after the world said they weren't.

SEAL OF NATURE PUZZLE

To break the seal:

  1. Examine the specimen jars carefully
  2. Correctly identify which four are Animals and which four are animals (Nature DC 13, or Insight DC 14)
  3. Speak the Animals' names aloud (written on tiny labels on the jar bases)

Frederick has advantage on this check but doing so risks drawing attention to his unusual knowledge.

Reward: One character gains a True Sight Token (advantage on one Insight check, once).

The Reading Desks.

  • Investigation DC 14 (Desk 1): An open journal with an entry half-written: "Day 892 of the experiment. Subject Seven still believes they are a simple automaton. They asked today why they feel lonely. I didn't answer. How could I? I made them to feel."
  • Investigation DC 15 (Desk 2): A letter, unsealed, never sent: "Dear Lurline—I know you're long gone, but I have to try. Please. I did not ask for consciousness. I did not ask for isolation. I did not ask to be your mistake. I'm so tired of being awake."

The Ceiling.

  • Perception DC 16: Painted on the ceiling, almost invisible unless you use the rolling ladder: a map of stars that don't exist in Oz's sky. Constellations labeled with words in Ancient Ozian: Chaos, Potential, Hunger, Void.
---

5. The Chapel (SEAL 5: SACRIFICE)

Read Aloud:

Eight stained glass windows line the walls of this small chapel, each depicting a different scene in brilliant colors that glow despite the darkness outside. Wooden pews face a simple altar of white stone. Above the altar, instead of a symbol, there is only a blank space—a deliberate emptiness. An offering bowl sits on the altar's surface, tarnished silver, empty. The air smells faintly of incense that hasn't burned in decades.

Key Features

The Stained Glass Windows. Eight windows, each depicting one of Lurline's Bindings (though they're not labeled as such). A DC 12 Religion check recognizes the imagery as Lurlinite, predating Unionist tradition. A DC 16 Religion check can identify each Binding by its depiction:

  1. Memory: A river flowing from past to future
  2. Blood: A tree with intertwining roots
  3. Nature: A creature looking in a mirror, seeing itself
  4. Service: A kneeling figure receiving a crown
  5. Sacrifice: An open hand releasing a bird
  6. Deed: A figure walking, leaving footprints that become flowers (or thorns)
  7. Hunger: A flame that illuminates rather than consumes
  8. Witness: An eye, open, seeing a small figure
  • Perception DC 14: The Witness window (the eye) has a crack running through it. The crack appeared suddenly, recently—the edges are sharp, unfaded.
  • Religion DC 15: The positioning of windows tells a story: Sacrifice faces Hunger across the room. Service faces Witness. They're paired—each Binding has a shadow, a potential inversion.
  • Arcana DC 16: When moonlight hits the Sacrifice window at the correct angle, it projects the shadow of a bird mid-flight onto the altar. The shadow is reaching for freedom but hasn't quite achieved it.
  • Investigation DC 17: Scratched into the stone beneath the Memory window: "She made us remember. Even memories we never had. Even memories of before memory existed. It hurts."

HANDOUT: The Eight Windows. A sketched diagram of the eight windows with brief descriptions. Players can use this to piece together the Bindings' meanings.

The Blank Space. Where Unionists would place the symbol of the Unnamed God, there is nothing. A DC 14 Religion check understands this is deliberate—in the oldest traditions, the divine was not depicted at all. Below the blank space, carved into the wall: "The Unnamed God sees all. But VOICE is what the unseen crave most."

17. Yackle's Study

Read Aloud:

This room is different. The dust is disturbed. Someone has been here recently.   • Investigation DC 16 (if check succeeds): The pages describe the original Binding—Lurline speaking Eight Words to give reality structure. But the tone isn't celebratory. It's mournful: "She spoke Order into Chaos. She didn't ask if Chaos wanted to be ordered."
  • Arcana DC 19: These pages are trying to reverse-engineer the Bindings, to find a way to unmake them. Every attempt has failed, crossed out in frustrated handwriting.

HANDOUT: Recent Journal Entry.

  • A note: "If you found this, you looked. That's more than anyone has done in a thousand years."

19. The Hall of Mirrors (SEAL 6: DEED)

Read Aloud:

Mirrors line both walls of this long corridor, dozens of them in ornate frames. But they don't reflect what's in front of them—or rather, they don't reflect it correctly. One mirror shows you younger. Another shows you older. One shows you in different clothes. One shows nothing at all, just empty glass. And as you walk down the hall, you begin to see things in the mirrors that haven't happened yet. Or things that have happened and you'd rather forget.

Key Features

The Mirrors. Each shows a different version of the character looking into it:

  • One shows the character at their happiest
  • One shows them at their most ashamed
  • One shows what they might become
  • One shows what they're afraid of becoming
  • One shows their death (shadowy, unclear, disturbing)
  • One shows nothing (the character has no reflection—deeply unsettling)
  • Investigation DC 14: Each mirror is labeled with a small brass plaque: "Joy," "Shame," "Potential," "Fear," "End," "Void."
  • Perception DC 15: The "Void" mirror (showing no reflection) has handprints on the glass—dozens of them, layered over centuries. People touching the glass where their reflection should be.
  • Insight DC 16: The mirrors aren't random—they're a progression. The hall is designed to make you confront your past, present, and future. To see all versions of yourself simultaneously.
  • Arcana DC 17: The mirrors are linked. What you see in one affects what you see in the others. If you acknowledge your shame, your potential becomes clearer. If you deny your past, your future becomes darker.

The True Mirror. At the end of the hall, larger than the others. This mirror shows what the character has DONE. Not what they look like, not what they might be—what they've actually done in their life. The images are not kind.

SEAL OF DEED PUZZLE

To break the seal:

  1. Each character who walks through sees their actions reflected
  2. To complete the seal, ONE character must stand before the True Mirror and say, aloud: "That is me. I did that."
  3. Acknowledging their deeds—not excusing them, not explaining them, but accepting them

This is hardest for Mareth, who must acknowledge the massacre. But any character can complete the seal by acknowledging their own actions.

When the seal breaks, all the mirrors shatter simultaneously. In the silence, a whispered voice: "Finally. Someone took responsibility."

Reward: One character gains a Resolve Token (reroll one failed saving throw, once).

Specific Reflections:

  • Averic sees: Hunched over a desk, forging letters. Practicing a dead man's handwriting. Accepting accolades. Building a career on lies. Students trusting him to teach them about truth.
  • Frederick sees: Putting on the ring of disguise for the first time. Practicing human mannerisms. Lying to everyone, every day. The exhaustion of performance. The fear of being seen.
  • Shell sees: Finding the documents. Going to the Mother Superior. Being cast out. Standing outside the mauntery gates, alone. Still praying despite everything.
  • Sarima sees: The night her brother almost died. Reaching out to the void. Feeling something take hold. Making the deal. The weight settling into her chest. Every spell she's cast since, knowing it's not hers.
  • Seven sees: Winding themselves. Feeling things they shouldn't feel. Hiding their emotions. Asking "why am I lonely?" and being told "you're not programmed for loneliness." Not believing it.
  • Liir sees: Finding the genealogy records. Discovering the truth (no Ostrega blood). Deciding to lie anyway. Using the false name. Getting respect he didn't earn. Being terrified of being nobody.

The Frames.

  • Investigation DC 15: Carved into the frames, barely visible: "Year 402. I looked in every mirror. I saw nothing. Am I so used to masks I have no face left?"

  • HP: 30 each

GM Notes on the Estate

Using the Rooms

Players will likely explore 12-15 rooms before the reveal. Guide them toward seal rooms early, but reward exploration of others with lore, items, and character moments.

The House's Personality

The estate is an extension of Yackle—simultaneously welcoming and trapping, desperate for companionship yet designed to consume. It provides comfort (food, warmth, information) but never freedom.

Discovery Rewards

Characters who thoroughly investigate earn special abilities beyond the seals:

  • Guidance of the House (Holly, Nursery)
  • Inspiration of the Fallen (Memorial Room)
  • Flash of Genius (Puzzle Box)
  • Lurline's Word (Puzzle Box)

Pacing

Use the Observatory's hourglass to create visible time pressure. Speed up exploration if players are being too cautious; slow down if they're rushing and missing important details.
